PETITION.TITLE: Public Order in the Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned shows that:
There is widespread concern at the increasing breakdown of public order in the A.C.T.
This breakdown is shown by the recent increase in reports of violent assault-one of which concerned the tragic death of a young man at a school fete.
The involvement of groups of youths in some of these assaults causes particular concern.
Such behaviour is affected by the ready availability, to young people, of alcohol and video and films which depict extreme violence.
Your petitioners therefore ask the Parliament to:
Make unlawful the creation of a public nuisance by loitering.
Ensure the enforcement of laws which prohibit the public consumption of alcohol by under-age persons, and
Legislate to restrict the production, distribution and sale of material which depicts extreme violence.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Bjelke-Petersen (from 134 citizens), Chaney (from 148 citizens), Knowles (from 130 citizens), Lewis (from 150 citizens), Macklin (from 136 citizens), Robert Ray (from 134 citizens) and Reid (from 179 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Polychlorinated Biphenyl High Temperature Incinerator: Koolyanobbing, Western Australia
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

That the proposed Polychlorinated Biphenyl High Temperature Incinerator threatens to damage agriculture and with subsequent effects on trade in the Shire of Vilgarn, Western Australia, and could have possible adverse effects on the health of the residents of the area.

Your petitioners therefore most humbly pray that the Senate request the Commonwealth Government to use its influence with the Western Australian State Government to prevent the building of PCB High Temperature Incinerator at Koolyanobbing, Western Australia.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Pensions
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled:
The Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 October 1986 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government.
This cut has reduced the base for future adjustments. The Government has promised to restore the base as soon as economic circumstances permit.

Having regard to the state of the economy as portrayed by members of the Government in recent months and the interaction between Social Security pensions and the above mentioned adjustment, your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to restore the pension base for the calculation of future adjustments and that the restoration be effected in conjunction with the Social Security adjustments in November 1987.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;
that we call upon the Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Identification Card and Taxation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
We, the undersigned citizens, respectfully showeth:
That we are totally opposed to the introduction of the Labor Government's Identity Card;

that this form of national and compulsory identification will be intrusive, costly for taxpayers and business and will not be effective in combating the growing problems of tax evasion, illegal immigrants or social security;

that we are deeply concerned at the Labor Government's inability to provide effective and efficient methods to combat tax and social security fraud without resorting to expensive, ineffective and authoritarian measures which are alien to the Australian way of life;
that we call upon the Labor Government to improve management systems within the Australian Tax Office and other Departments to crack down on tax evasion and fraudulent practices.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom Charge for Directory Assistance
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
We consider the Federal Government's decision to have Telecom charge for the cost of `Directory Assistance' enquiries will greatly disadvantage the sick, elderly and the handicapped.

Specifically, it will impose an unjustified financial burden on those with sight impediments and reading difficulties, such as the elderly. It will also disadvantage physically handicapped people and persons confined due to illness.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should urge the Government to:
Reverse its decision to have Telecom charge for `Directory Assistance' enquiries.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation

PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: Metered Calls

1. We oppose the introduction of metering of local telephone calls by Telecom;

PETITION.TITLE: Proposed Pre-school Fees: Australian Capital Territory
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:

The $6.00 per week fee imposed on Government preschool parents is inequitable. We feel the fee will cause genuine hardship to many families of young children and it ignores the contribution that parents make financially to preschools at the moment. It will affect the enrolment of children at preschools next year, with a likely outcome being the closure of some ACT preschools. It will also affect the voluntary financial commitment parents already make to preschools, without which they could not function on a day to day basis. We believe that preschools are very cost effective in respect to their multi faceted role in educational, social, health, emotional and physical development. We envisage the long term effects of the fee to be a reduction in the quality and frequency of preschooling with the preschool sector degenerating into a user pays system for those who can afford it.
We call on the Senate to urge the Hon John Brown to abolish the fee.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I present to the Senate the following petition, which is not in conformity with the Standing Orders as it is not in the correct form, from 1,354 citizens praying that broadcasters of ethnic Russian programs in New South Wales continue to serve the Russian Orthodox religious community by continuing to include in such programs a large component of presenters and content provided by and for members of the Russian Orthodox Faith:

SPEECH.PARA: Mr. B. Johns,
Executive Director
Special Broadcasting Service,
4 Cliff Street,
MILSON'S POINT. N.S.W. 2061
17th November 1987
From: Group of concerned listeners of ethnic broadcasts in Russian
Dear Sir,

We are listeners of ethnic broadcasts in Russian in the cities of Sydney, Newcastle and Wollongong. These broadcasts have been headed and co-ordinated for the past 12 years or so by the highly respect Doctor Igor Galitsky and his able assistants-the Russian Orthodox priest, father Mikhail Konstantinov, and Miss Natalia Koudrin, and we would like to express our thanks to them for the interesting and informative programs during this entire period. Likewise we wish to confirm our complete satisfaction with the contents of these programs, which conform with and are entirely in keeping with the spiritual and cultural needs of the majority of the Russian community.

As with any other truly ethnic radio-transmission, ethnic Russian broadcasts demand that its co-ordinators (or head of the section) and their staff be original Russians, both by birth and by their national historical roots. Likewise, as the Russian Orthodox religion pre-dominates in the overwhelming majority of Russian ethnic community, it is vital that in addition to being Russian by birth the co-ordinator (or head of the section) and his assistants be of Russian Orthodox faith to enable them to satisfy the spiritual needs of the Russian community. Any other candidates, irrespective of how well they know Russian language, would be unable-by virtue of their nationality and religion-to adequately express and satisfy the needs of the Russian ethnic community in their programs.

It is especially important for the co-ordinator (or head of the section) and his staff to be Russian by birth and to belong to Russian Orthodox faith because of the coming Jubilee in 1988-One Thousandth Anniversary since Russia was baptised and became Christian. The Jubilee celebrations will be universally conducted by Russian Orthodox churches throughout the world. Illustration of the essence and importance of this big event in the Christian world, as well as the essence and importance of celebrations connected with it in different countries, will naturally be reflected in the contents of Russian ethnic radio-transmissions by illustrating the specific character of the same and by singling out Christian Orthodox thematics. It is self-evident, therefore, that the compiling of such radio transmissions, co-ordinating them to illustrate and depict Russian Orthodox thematics, can best be achieved by a co-ordinator (or head of the section) and his staff belonging to Russian Orthodox faith, who are familiar not only with the religion but with its influence on the life and consciousness of overwhelming majority of Russian ethnic community.

In view of the above, we would request that the co-ordinator (or head of the section) and his assistants of Russian ethnic radio-transmissions be chosen from Russian people belonging to Russian Orthodox faith. This will meet the cultural needs founded on moral Christian principles and satisfy spiritual and cultural needs of all members of Russian ethnic community.

We would also like to point out that other national ethnic broadcasts (e.g. Polish and Jewish) are headed, as a rule, by people belonging to the same faith as the majority of their listeners, and this fact gives us hope that you will not allow the Russian community to be discriminated against on grounds of religion.

Unfortunately, many members of the Russian community misunderstood the advertisements the way they appeared in the press and on radio. They understood that S.B.S. required additional staff and did not realize it was a radical re-structuring of the entire broadcasting group, and therefore not many people reacted by sending in applications and expressing interest in the positions advertised. We feel that to have a fair and equitable representation these positions should be re-advertised to allow the Russian community an opportunity to express interest and take part in the re-structuring of the Russian broadcasting group, which, after all, concerns in the first instance the Russian community and Russian community only.

As in any other ethnic broadcast, the Russian ethnic program has as its aim the servicing of cultural, religious, national historic and linguistic needs of the Russian ethnic community, fundamentally and overwhelmingly composed of Ethnically Russian Orthodox People.

We appreciate that many nationalities also listen to the Russian program, but the main purpose of this program is to satisfy the cultural, religious and linguistic needs of the Russian Community. The program is also to inform and entertain and to be sensitive to the Russian community needs, as well as to inform and entertain all the other listeners to the Russian language program.

We therefore request that the broadcasters, and especially the head of the Russian broadcasting section be selected not only on the basis of their linguistic knowledge of the Russian language, but mainly on the basis of their belonging to and representing the Russian Ethnic Christian Community, which undeniably represents the predominant part of Russian speaking listeners of the Russian ethnic radio-transmissions.
Yours faithfully,

DEBATE.TITLE: GREAT BARRIER REEF MARINE PARK REGULATIONS

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I give notice that, 10 sitting days after today, I shall move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Regulations (Amendment), as contained in Statutory Rules 1987 No. 247 and made under the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Act 1975, be disallowed.
I seek leave to make a short statement.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today is the last day on which a protective notice can be given to protect the freedom of action of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Environment, recreation and the Arts while it considers Administrative Appeals Tribunal review rights, strict criminal liability and the clarity of drafting in these regulations. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a short statement of our specific concerns.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.
The statement read as follows-

The Committee has raised 5 matters with the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, Senator the Hon. Graham Richardson. Firstly, certain applicants for permission to use a Marine Park in a way that might restrict reasonable public use of the Park, may be required to advertise that fact. The provisions do not set out what this requirement might entail and they are, therefore, somewhat inadequate. The Minister has been asked if they require amendment. Secondly, some information demands imposed by the Great Barrier Reef Marine Park Authority are limited to requirements that are expressly ``reasonable''. Other provisions are not so limited on their face. While all such requirements would be read down to reasonable limits by a court, the express inclusion of this qualification has an important and useful declaratory and presentational effect. The Minister has been invited to consider this. Thirdly, an unusual strict vicarious criminal liability is imposed on any master, owner or shareholder of a ship or aircraft which is involved in any infringement of the law in the Marine Park. The relevant provision (regulation 19A) states that such a person ``shall be deemed to be guilty . . . and punishable . . . whether or not the person did the act that constitutes the offence''. The Committee has sought the Minister's advice on the necessity for the very wide scope of this provision which could fix innocent persons with serious criminal liability. Fourthly, no right is given to review a refusal to grant permission to take certain fish (regulation 14). Possibly analogous review rights are conferred elsewhere (regulation 18 (2A)). The Committee has sought an explanation. Fifthly, the Committee has sought the Minister's advice on whether relevant provisions are adequate to provide for proper notification of review rights. Such notification is dependent on a prior obligation to notify a person of the relevant decision. That prior obligation appears to be missing from regulations 15, 18 and 21B concerning reviewable discretionary decisions to permit the discharging of waste, to permit the use of diving equipment for research purposes or to permit animals (other than guide dogs for the blind) to be taken onto Marine Park islands.

DEBATE.TITLE: STANDING COMMITTEE ON FINANCE AND PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coates Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the following matter be referred to the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration: the central administration of the Australian Government.

The purpose of this reference is to vest the Standing Committee on Finance and Public Administration with the necessary mandate to fulfil its responsibilities to the Senate properly. The Committee's three existing standing references relate largely to the non-departmental sphere of public administration-statutory authorities, et cetera. The new standing reference will enable the Committee to conduct inquiries in the departmental field of public administration. In framing the new reference, the Committee has had special regard for its particular responsibility to oversee the central departments of the Government, namely, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Finance. Important agencies covered by the portfolios include the Auditor-General's Office and the Public Service Commission, the roles and responsibilities of which are integral to central administration.

Following implementation of the Administrative Arrangements Act 1987, involving inter alia the abolition of the Public Service Board, there is now a new structure for the management of the Australian Public Service. Functions previously the responsibility of the Public Service Board are now performed by the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, the Department of Finance, the Department of Industrial Relations and the Public Service Commission. Some have also been devolved to departments. The new term of reference will allow the Committee to monitor the working of the new arrangements and to conduct under its umbrella those relevant inquiries which may from time to time be necessary.

Amongst the issues which the Committee might consider investigating are the equal employment opportunity program, the Senior Executive Service, the use of consultants and the role of the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet as a co-ordinating department. I inform the Senate that the first matter which the Committee intends to deal with under this reference is the scrutiny program, which is referred to in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet's 1986-87 annual report at pages 35 to 38.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

DEBATE.TITLE: SOCIAL SECURITY AND VETERANS' ENTITLEMENTS AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I had almost completed my remarks on the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 last evening, but, in view of a procedural matter that was brought to my attention after the conclusion of business, I wish to reiterate the point of the amendment of which I now give notice. This amendment will be moved when the second reading of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is formally put. It relates to those young people who receive the job search allowance of $25 to $50 a week and the Government's requirement that these people pay $2.50 per prescription, which amounts to roughly 10 per cent of their average weekly earnings if they are on the lower end of that scale and receiving $25 a week.

SPEECH.PARA: Yesterday I drew attention to the fact that, while these costs relate to those who are seeking work, some of these people may be suffering from diseases which require constant medication but which are not inhibitory to their working, provided they have that medication. I refer to such diseases as asthma, diabetes, epilepsy and others. I pointed out the cost of $2.50 per prescription was 10 per cent of weekly income for those of $25 a week. Given the limitation on the number of scripts, this amounts to $62.50 per year, or approximately 1 1/2 to 2 1/2 weeks of income. I drew a parallel between this situation and that faced by someone on average weekly income which, in August, was $394 a week. Under comparable circumstances the average worker would be paying either $491 of $985 for yearly prescriptions if he were expected to pay 1 1/2 or 2 1/2 weeks of those earnings for a prescription.

In the light of the charge which the Government proposes to levy on young people who are suffering these chronic illnesses, I foreshadow the Australian Democrats motion which will be put at the second reading of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). As I explained last evening, we are doing this because the Health Insurance Act 1973 and the amalgamation of the various amendments which have been made to that principle Act are in such a mess that in the time available we could not get a suitable amendment worded. Our motion will seek to add to the end of the second reading motion the following words:
Social Security and Veterans Bill
but the Senate is of the opinion that recipients of the job search allowance should be entitled to free pharmaceutical benefits without any further income test.
In support of that I point out that in terms of the cost to the individual recipients the amount would be quite significant, but in terms of cost to the Government it would be extremely small.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bjelke-Petersen Sen F.I.

TALK.START.PARA: —In taking part in this cognate debate today, I wish to address the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill 1987. In doing so, I point out that I have had and still have a great deal to do with nursing homes. Quite apart from serving with a number of other senators on the Senate Select Committee on Private Hospitals and Nursing Homes, I have had the privilege of opening very many retirement villages and nursing homes in Queensland from time to time. I have always been very concerned about the care of the elderly and I have no doubt that many other senators feel exactly the same way. As the aged population becomes even greater, so the care of this group in the community becomes a more demanding problem.

SPEECH.PARA: Let us put the problem in perspective. By the year 2021, some five million Australians are expected to be aged 65 and over. Going by present funding arrangements, this type of population aging is expected to increase government outlays on the aged by 131 per cent between the years 1981 and 2001. That certainly is a big increase, in anybody's language. Right at this moment we are in a crucial phase in terms of policy arrangements which will set the tone for the next 20 or 30 years.

The Opposition is concerned about some of the ramifications of this Bill. However, the Opposition has no problem with the overall policy direction. There is a concern, though, about the discretionary power that appears to be granted to the Minister. It seems that in drafting this legislation, there has been a minimum of consultation between the Department of Community Services and Health and the nursing home industry. I know that the Australian Nursing Homes Association has many criticisms of the Bill. It stated in its submission:
The Government constantly declines to consult, preferring to suffer the constant mess and aggravations of its blind pursuit of what is now simply change for the sake of change.

The Nursing Homes Association is also concerned about the discretionary power that appears to be granted to the Minister. It is concerned about clause 27, which was supposed to clarify ministerial power to review the Secretary's decisions. It also refers to a clause which proposes to introduce a harsh penalty when the Department is approaching the defining of the records required to be maintained. It says that the definition is highly questionable and highly disturbing. Many other concerns have been raised by other nursing home operators. They say that they were not consulted and have many serious and valid concerns about the effects of this legislation.

Some of the problems that I see are in the Government's plans to set standards for the aged care industry that it does not intend to meet itself; to duplicate State government regulations concerning care quality in aged persons homes; to take away any appeal rights that nursing home proprietors have concerning bureaucratic decisions; to force nursing homes to keep records in a manner and form intrusive, excessive and costly for nursing homes but of no relevance to Commonwealth funding requirements; and to prevent private investors providing aged persons hostel beds. It seems to me that that would be a very reasonable thing to do. The effects of the Hawke Labor Government's latest legislation will be to force nursing homes with fewer than 30 beds to close under the new funding arrangements, and to make it impossible for any voluntary organisation to provide respite care. I received a letter, as no doubt did many other senators, from the Scone District Nursing Home, which expressed dismay and disillusionment at this legislation.

Clauses 29 and 30 present considerable concern because they are very wide in their application and, in effect, give what some people have considered to be too great police powers to departmental officers. Powers to visit a nursing home at any time and to question any person, under threat of six months in gaol, a fine of $1,000 or both, certainly are very intimidating. So far as I am aware, the Department has already been instrumental in prosecuting some nursing home proprietors who deserved it, so it would seem that the present legislation is able to cope with that sort of control.

There is further concern that assessment teams will regularly reassess patients and attempt to discharge them from homes. It is always to be hoped that people will get better, but so often in old age that is not the case. It is often the case that people in nursing homes have nowhere else to go. Their homes have been sold, their families live far away, and where else can they go? Of course, sometimes it is not as simple as black and white. Sometimes the hand of human kindness has to be extended and a sympathetic view of the situation taken into account. The older sectors of our community deserve tremendous respect and the best of services that we as a tax paying community can provide. But I am also a realist; I realise that, if the Government is already spending twice as much today on an old person as it is spending on a young person, the situation will certainly be compounded 20 years from now when an even larger proportion of our population will be over 50 years of age.

There is another problem that I see, which relates to the decision of the Government to reduce the number of nursing homes in Australia. I accept that more hostels will be allowed and that the Government thinks that it is better to have hostels than more nursing homes. But what we have to be careful about is that we do not turn hostels into second class nursing homes. I was in Ayr some time earlier this year and looked at its lovely nursing home. The people there said that they believe that, if we have more hostels than nursing homes, we have to have the nursing care necessary for the people who go into those hostels when there are not enough nursing homes provided. Friends of mine were telling me only recently that they have parents who are getting on in years and will soon be too old to stay in their own home. They have been looking for a retirement or nursing home into which they can go. They do not want to go just yet but are looking for a suitable home. They have been told that there is a four-year waiting list for such homes. I do not believe anybody wants to go into a nursing home unless it is absolutely necessary. The Government seems to be saying, `There are too many people in nursing homes; let us get them into hostels'. One point that the Government has to be really sure about is that not just hostels are provided where there is not enough nursing care for the older people. We sometimes wonder where our older people will be able to live out their last years. People cannot always have their mothers or fathers living with them in their homes; perhaps for health reasons it is just not possible. That is something to which the Government has to pay attention.

I pay tribute to all the people who work in nursing homes and hostels looking after the elderly people in our community. I often visit them and I appreciate that it is a big job that they are doing, helping to keep our elderly citizens happy. I believe that the correct way to go is for the private operators and the taxpayers-that is, the Government-to join together to provide the kind of nursing home services that will be increasingly vital in our aging community. We should be encouraging free enterprise nursing homes to continue doing what they are already doing so well in the community. Of course, the Government must provide a core of necessary care for the elderly so that those who are not in a position to pay out a lot of money are still provided with the care that they need. However, in doing so, we should not neglect the very important role that private enterprise can and must play in the provision of nursing home care in what is becoming a very young country full of old people. I support the amendment that has been moved by the Opposition to the motion for the second reading of the Bill.

In addition, I want to say a few words about the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) which is also before the Senate as part of this cognate debate. Mr Tim Fischer, the shadow Minister for Veterans' Affairs, has raised some concerns in the other place about clauses 63 and 64 and the effect of an application date rather than a review period being included. The Opposition understands that the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) will address those concerns. I simply remind him of them and ask him to comment on them when he makes his reply.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion add:
``, and the provisions of subclauses 3 (10), 11 (2) and 76 (2) be referred to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs''.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating cognately three Bills directly related to the aftermath of the September Budget. Once again, in the dying stages of the Parliament, we are rushing through significant legislation that affects deeply the lives of a great many people in our community and, perhaps most significantly, people who depend in very large measure, and rather distressingly in ever-increasing numbers, upon government for, in particular, income support and assistance in times of need. My colleagues Senator McLean and Senator Coulter have addressed the major issues dealt with in the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) and the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill and those aspects of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) that relate to the area of veterans' entitlements. I shall address my remarks to the social security aspects of the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2).

SPEECH.PARA: As I said, this is Budget legislation. Following the election the Budget was introduced in September, a month later than usual. That Budget was generally well received by the community. The feature of the Budget that was sold quite strongly in the community was the family package. Of course, during the election campaign that package had been promoted strongly by the Australian Labor Party and particularly by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Indeed, the introduction of this family package is welcome, in particular those aspects of it that deal with matters of concern and that are designed at least to enable the Government to meet its election promise that by 1990 no Australian child need live in poverty. However, I think it is important to question whether those measures in this legislation that form part of the family package are destined to be effective. I refer to such measures as the new family allowance supplement payment and the indexation of that payment. Of course, those measures are welcome. The Government estimates that one million children will enjoy a better standard of living as a result of that payment. Again, that assertion can and will be questioned.

It is proposed to increase child payments for families that depend on income support, and such payments also will be indexed automatically. The family package will extend rent assistance. As a result of this legislation families on unemployment and sickness benefits-this is a measure that the Australian Democrats have been pushing for for some time-will receive housing assistance right from the time they receive their first benefit payment. The Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) claimed in his second reading speech that the package provides for more money to be made available for disabled children. That is another assertion that will be questioned by the Australian Democrats. The legislation seeks to provide general support for disadvantaged families, and in particular working families, through the family allowance supplement.

However, some contrasts can be found between the claims made and the effects of those claims. Attention needs to be drawn to those matters. Though the September Budget was generally quite well received, largely because of the inclusion of the family package, it must be remembered that it came hard on the heels of the May mini-Budget, which was not well received and which imposed some very draconian measures, some very tough cut-backs and some very worrying extensions of the powers and influence of the Department of Social Security on the lives of ordinary Australians.

I turn specifically to the issue of children in poverty. Just last weekend I had pointed out to me specific cases of provisions passed by this Parliament as a result of the May statement now causing children living in poverty to be very adversely affected-in spite of the measures before us today, in this legislation, as a result of the current year's Budget. What is happening is that, as a result of the increased powers of the Department of Social Security resulting from the measures introduced in the May statement-particularly those powers relating to debt recovery, and the family allowance supplement, which the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) and the Government put before us as a payment for children-the supplement has been found to be subject to withdrawal by the Department in cases where the Department claims overpayment. A specific case in Victoria, which was made public last weekend by welfare workers, involved a woman with four children aged from six months to 13 years. She was threatened with the loss of her family allowance if she would not sign a Social Security form stating that she owed $7,600 more than she had already agreed to pay with deductions of $41 per fortnight from her unemployment benefit.

So at the same time as the Prime Minister and the Minister for Social Security are bruiting abroad their commitment to eradicate child poverty, the Department of Social Security, having been granted the power automatically to withhold family allowance payments, puts that claim in jeopardy. The question is: Does this mean that the basic principle of the family package-that every Australian child should have a right to an adequate standard of living-does not apply to the innocent children of Social Security debtors? That really is the issue involved in the family allowance and the family allowance supplement. The Social Security Act of 1947 states that family allowance is payable for `maintenance, training and advancement of the child'. Yet it appears that the Department can use its power to withdraw the family allowance to threaten and intimidate. In fact, it appears that one of the most draconian debt collectors in our community is now the Department of Social Security.

We believe that the family allowance and the family allowance supplement must be protected from use as debt collection bargaining tools if the Government's attack on child poverty is to be more than a false promise. I have been given another example of this in Victoria. It involves a couple who were bankrupted four years ago. The debt to the Department was included in the bankruptcy case. They were discharged after three years and in November they were informed by Social Security recovery officers that the family allowance would be reduced to repay the debt to Social Security. The couple were correctly informed that when they bankrupted the family allowance could not be taken by Social Security to repay the debt. So Social Security appears to be overriding the bankruptcy and ignoring the fact that the couple declared themselves insolvent in an attempt to start anew and provide their children with an adequate standard of living. It appears that the powers given in the mini-Budget are being overused.

At the committee stage of this Bill we will move amendments dealing with other instances where the provisions of the May statement are causing concern through their being administered in ways which are distressing in many cases and anomalous in others. We believe that, while the Government claims that this legislation reflects an understanding of the problems of the poor and disadvantaged, in particular children, this legislation must be looked at in the context of previous legislation and its implementation.

Before I move from concerns about the environment in which we are looking at this legislation and the impact it will have, I need to highlight the way new powers were created for the Department of Social Security in the May statement, powers we are now seeing being implemented and having an effect on people in receipt of Government pensions and benefits. The Secretary of the Department can now compel the production of information about the grant of a pension, benefit or allowance from either the recipient or a third person. That issue causes great concern. It is a broad, unfocused, catch-all provision and it imposes an obligation upon persons to whom requests are made to divulge such information as the Secretary requires and any documents in their custody or under their control. So the Department can compel neighbours, work colleagues and so on to provide details about a recipient's movements or habits and can compel outside authorities such as banks and reference agencies to divulge information. When one understands that all families in receipt of the family allowance-most families in Australia-are clients of the Department of Social Security, one sees that this is a major concern for a great many people.

It is also possible through provisions of the mini-Budget legislation for the Department to divulge information on a much wider scale to other government departments, outside organisations or individuals. When these items are put together there is considerable concern. I might say that concern about these specific issues is being expressed by many of the people and groups who were concerned about issues surrounding the development of the ID card legislation. It is that intrusion, that access to and dissemination of information that is of major concern. As I have said, it does impinge on the lives of a great many ordinary Australians and must be questioned when we see examples of its causing distress to ordinary people, particularly as to the lives and economic well-being of their children.

Provisions of this legislation regarding the under-18 unemployed relate directly to the announcement and actions taken as a result of the mini-Budget. We will be addressing some of those issues in detail during the committee stage. However, there is a major concern in that area. We are faced with a Government which is claiming to be economically very responsible and at the same time to have great care for and a sense of responsibility about the people who rely on the Government for their care and in particular for their income support. It rather rankles when at the same time as we are giving support to young people-young people living in families and perhaps most particularly young people who for one reason or another are not able to continue to live with their families-that support is being reduced bit by bit, being eaten away. Senator Coulter has already foreshadowed a second reading motion in support of those young people.

The under-18 unemployment benefit has been removed. This legislation provides for the establishment of the job search allowance and increases in the work test requirements for those young people. In principle it is probably quite easy to argue that we only want to help these young people get into the work force. At the moment we are all very labour market oriented. We have to give the Government some credit for moves it is making to establish training programs and to establish a feeling and a sense that we are working towards a more appropriately trained and educated community. Unfortunately, it seems a headlong rush in the case of those young people whose unemployment benefit has been removed and another group in the community which was affected by the mini-Budget and will be further affected by measures in this legislation-sole parents who are mainly women of mature or maturing age. Their benefits have also been suddenly removed very much against their expectations. The benefits of these women have been removed at a time when their children are in the age group which I have just been talking about-generally the under 18 years age group. A great deal of family stress, particularly financial stress, is being caused by the combination of these measures.

While these decisions may seem to be rational economic decisions and while they allow, in large measure, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) to stomp around the country bragging about the fact that next year there will be a Budget surplus and that this Budget-the legislation for which we are now addressing-will largely be a balanced Budget, that is all too much from our point of view as it is at the cost of the very same people about whom I have been talking. Last week Mr Keating was quoted as saying that a saving of $200m was likely to be paid out for the unemployment benefit as a result of stronger employment and the success of the Government's crackdown on fraudulent unemployment benefit claims.

I understand that figures are now coming in with regard to the group of people who are affected by the reduction in their entitlement to the supporting parent benefit and the widows' pension entitlement. Figures are showing that vastly fewer people are receiving these benefits and that is not surprising. First of all, there is the element that they are not entitled to them any more and there is also the element that many women are now placed in an invidious position of having to choose-for economic reasons, to save the Government money-to stay, all too often, in a relationship or to enter into another relationship which, if it is not unsatisfactory, is sometimes quite dangerous. There have been many public statements of concern by people who work in this area and who are acquainted with such women and children. Perhaps women are being placed in this position as a result of this Government's policies and the sort of legislation which we addressed in May equally as quickly-in fact we addressed it with more haste-as we are addressing this legislation today and the legislation which will continue to be put in front of us.

Young unemployed people continue to be hit. Just yesterday two community youth support schemes (CYSS) in Victoria were closed down without any notice being given. It was a matter of great distress the previous week when I was called to the Elwood CYSS group which, in the first week in December, was unsure about whether it had received any funding. It could get no advice from the Minister's office or from the proper authorities in its State. Finally, yesterday, it was closed down not only at a moment's notice but also without any reasons being given. It has not had a report. It was under review-it knew that-but no report from that review has been provided.

Young people, who do not very often fit in with the sorts of structured education and training programs which are provided and which the Government tells us it will increasingly provide, are using those facilities. I want to know from the Minister what is being provided for those young people and the women in rural centres around my State, and no doubt in other States, who are now not eligible for their benefit and who are now said to be able to be trained by new training programs for which money was allocated, and it continues to be allocated, but which do not yet exist. If they do exist, all too often they exist hundreds of miles away from the people who need them, leaving people no choice whatsoever but to join the unemployment queues along with their teenage children. A great many questions have to be asked and will be asked about this area.

As I have said, the Australian Democrats will move a series of amendments to this legislation. If a theme runs through the amendments which we will move, it is this: they point up the areas in which the Government, as the Treasurer has said, is making savings out of the welfare sector. Some of the savings are incredibly nit-picking and miserable. Another instance is the techniques that were used in the Budget 12 months ago of delaying indexation. This time those measures affect the unemployed.

We saw this happen with pensions, which have never caught up. I have to say that I support the pensioner movement. Given that we have a balanced Budget, given that we are looking at a surplus, pensioners are asking for their catchup. I congratulate the Caucus, which apparently has seen some rationality on the issue of the salaries of members of parliament. I do not believe that we deserve a catchup while pensioners and unemployment beneficiaries under 21 are looking down the barrel of a 12-month delay on a Government election promise of the indexation of the unemployment benefit, not to mention the under 18-year-olds who are still stuck on their $25 or maximum of $50 job search allowance. An increase in salary for parliamentarians is quite out of the question as far as I am concerned.

I read this morning that the deal on superannuation will not come off. Again I congratulate the Caucus members who were responsible for that decision. I assume that Senator Cooney, who is nodding, is one of the people responsible for this decision and I congratulate him if he is. It is intolerable that, Budget after mini-Budget after Budget after mini-Budget, this situation continues. The non-payment of a year's indexation entitlement will save the Government tens of thousands, hundreds of thousands or millions of dollars and it all adds up. These savings are at the expense of people who depend on government.

The point has been made in this debate that too many people depend too much on government. That may well be the case but while people have no option, there is no question that the Government has a responsibility to act. If there is a problem, if we want balanced Budgets, if we want Budget surpluses, there are other areas to look at. The Democrats have always exhorted the Government to look at other areas. For instance, we still see no action on negatively gearing foreign borrowings for company takeovers, largely unproductive company takeovers that do nothing for Australian employment. We say that some $2 billion-probably by now with inflation the figure is $3 billion-could be in the Government's coffers. But no, the Government would rather save its money by going back on its promise to index the benefits of the unemployed and by taking measures such as those in this legislation, and which will be the subject of a proposed amendment by the Democrats. The assets test provision will be extended to sickness and special benefits on a sudden death basis, not on a sliding scale as it is with the age pension. If one is a sickness or other beneficiary, as opposed to pensioners who are on a sliding scale, one's assets reach the cut off point, one is literally that-cut off. We consider that this is appropriate in the circumstances.

The Government seems to be attracted to that kind of saving, rather than looking to see where it can make money in a much more honourable fashion to balance its Budget or have a surplus if that is what it decides it needs. Again it seems that there are some positive moves in this direction. I would not want to hit the Government about the head if it does not deserve it. If Senator Walsh were here he would list the litany of wonderful tax reforms-the capital gains tax, which was supported by the Democrats; the fringe benefits tax, which was supported by the Democrats; the assets test, which was supported by the Democrats; and the corporate tax inquiry which is under way and was welcomed by the Democrats. Today's news that we are going to do away with the rort of trekking off to conferences or of establishing Australian-based conferences overseas is the sort of thing the Government should be doing-not the sort of nit-picking that it is doing in this Budget to save welfare money out of the welfare sector and redistribute it, even the redistribution being inequitable, as I have shown in some earlier examples.

It is interesting to the Democrats that those people who have been badly affected and who are now faced with the Government's strong labour market bias in its welfare policies are to become the concern of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training, chaired by Kathy Sullivan, that Committee having an inquiry into the ways in which social security pensioners might be got back into the work force. I think that is interesting because the Government, beginning with the mini-Budget and continuing until now, has been talking all the time about its labour market initiatives. In fact, the memo that we got from the Department of Employment, Education and Training about the removal of the sole parent benefit was headed `Labour Market Initiatives'. That is what all these things are. The Government does away with the under-18 unemployment benefit, backs down on indexation and does away with the sole parent benefit, and calls them labour market initiatives. We do not know where the market is and we do not know what kind of labour we need for those markets and how to train the people for them; nevertheless, we do it. So the House of Representatives Committee has decided that it will put before itself this reference to see how it can help the Government work out how it is going to do this.

However, I am a bit disturbed by the first words of the reference to that Committee. It is looking at the cost-effective means of facilitating and encouraging entry or return to the work force for social security pensioners. I am worried about that because I hope that the House of Representatives Committee will not take the same attitude that the Government takes when it comes to cost-effectiveness. Cost-effectiveness is risky and can cause enormous distress if it is carried to the sorts of extremes that it is being carried to at the moment in the area of social security recipients.

As I have said, there are some initiatives by the Government which we have supported and which we will continue to support. One of the other initiatives we were looking for was a wealth inquiry, which would go further than that corporate tax inquiry that is taking place. I am a little disturbed that it appears there has been a Government decision to establish a social justice unit, I believe within the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet. I am disturbed not from the point of view that I do not think there should be social justice, or that the Government should not establish a unit to look at social justice, but because I am a Victorian and because we have in Victoria a Labor government which has been running on the issue of social justice. For two years it has been established as a formal part of the Victorian Government's process. However, the problem is that we get a lot of pretty words and even a lot of pretty pamphlets, brochures and papers, but unfortunately there is really no claim yet that I think could justifiably be made in that jurisdiction of any action of substance. The Director of the Victorian Council of Social Service said:

The challenge for community organisations is to take the rhetoric, treat this as only a beginning and pry open the possibilities of developing the agenda further. If social justice is to have any hope of sharing the political agenda with economic policy-
at the moment we have to remember that that is economic rationalisation-
community organisations will have to campaign long and hard to turn the tide.
That was a comment on the Victorian social justice strategy. I think it is equally relevant in the area of any social justice unit that might be set up here. I do sound that note of caution.

It is really in the area of administration of these moves by the Government that I think I have already expressed most concern. It is not a concern which I hold to myself. I would like to mention the concern of the Colac Community Development Association, whose annual meeting I attended in one of the weeks we were not here last month. This body incorporates a number of organisations and individuals involved with community work and is concerned about the administration, even of the family allowance supplement, which I welcome. It does not know, and is asking for advice on, how the supplement will be dealt with in the case of casual, seasonal and intermittent earnings where there may not, for instance, be a pay slip, where income can fluctuate greatly from week to week and where the latest tax return could be a year old and no longer applicable. Amongst my amendments are some which would help to address the administration of this sort of problem. It is a matter of concern to the Democrats that once again this kind of Budget legislation has to be dealt with with some haste, and a range of issues will continue to be addressed by us in the committee stage of this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I asked the Minister in charge of this legislation, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), whether I could have just five minutes to speak on this package of Bills. It had not been my intention to speak, but certain comments that Senator Walters made in her contribution last night have compelled me to make a few remarks. Senator Walters waxed long about the family allowance supplement (FAS). She claimed that the FAS was introduced to buy votes. Certainly the possible introduction of the family allowance supplement was announced at a campaign opening. But that is not far different from the practice of the previous Government, which often did something similar, usually an announcement that the Government intended to purchase some defence equipment. The matter I want to stress is that the Government has introduced a scheme which will help all low income earners. To belittle the scheme, as Senator Walters did so nauseatingly last night, shows a total lack of compassion for the less fortunate in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: This brings me to the second matter. Senator Walters made great play out of a person doing overtime. She clearly implied that workers should seek out and do overtime. I would like to pose this question: Why should people have to be encouraged to do overtime? I would like to use a personal experience from my early childhood. I came from a very poor family. We did not know that we were poor until later years, because everybody in the suburb in which I lived was poor. My mother was originally a teacher, but in those days there was an archaic provision that, if a female married teacher tried to obtain employment, the State Government would not employ her. At that stage the State Government was quite willing to bring back male teachers who had retired some years ago to help out with the classroom problems, but it would not employ a married woman teacher, so employment was not available to her.

My father was a carpenter, and those who follow the scriptures know that that is a noble calling. The building industry, however, does not provide continuous employment, and a family of five often had to live on unemployment benefits of around #2 per week. How we would have welcomed a family allowance supplement scheme such as the one we are introducing.

Let me go back to overtime. When I was able to understand my father's working hours, I realised that he was working 44 hours per week-eight hours per day from Monday to Friday and four hours on Saturday. The workers in those days used to call Saturday the `dumpy day' because they worked only four hours on that day. After a long battle, this was reduced to 40 hours per week. My argument is: If a condition of 40 hours per week is achieved, why should it be jettisoned by people having to work overtime? Workers in Australia are not crazy like members of parliament, many of whom work for 80 hours a week and sometimes look for even more. Workers in Australia understand the concept of quality of life. There is much more to life than working. They understand the need to be with their families, to be able to help their children during their formative years. I can remember when my father eventually had to work overtime as the family grew older and the demands became greater. We all suffered. His quality of life suffered because he was not with his family for as long as he would have liked to have been, as did that of the rest of the family. They were denied his company. At that time we would have welcomed a scheme like the family allowance supplement which would have eliminated the need for my father to seek work beyond the hard-won 40 hours per week.

Let us not forget that thousands of families are still in such a parlous financial situation. Any move to help them increase their quality of life is to be applauded. For Senator Walters to nit-pick, as she did last night, is churlish. She should get out and obtain first hand information about the problems of low income families.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I begin my response by first going to matters concerning veterans in the first of the three Bills being discussed in this cognate debate-the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Mr Humphreys, has asked me to make some statements on his behalf to give assurances to the Returned Services League (RSL), which has indicated that it supports the passage of the Bill providing that these assurances are made. I am happy to make them. The RSL has raised with the Minister a concern about the inclusion in the Bill of the provision for assessing a veteran's eligibility for an intermediate or totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) pension on the application day, which would pre-empt consideration by the Veterans' Entitlement Act monitoring committee of the issue of whether eligibility for a pension at a particular rate should be able to be assessed up to the time at which the determining authority is making its decision.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister has asked me to assure the Senate that it is not intended to pre-empt the monitoring committee's report. The purpose of the amendments is as stated in the Minister's second reading speech. I assure the Senate that it is not the intention of the Government by these amendments to tighten further the eligibility criteria for TPI pensions. Furthermore, in response to the RSL's representations, the Minister has undertaken to write to the monitoring committee specifically on this issue. He will be asking the committee to consider and report on the question of whether assessment of a particular rate of pension should be only at a particular point in time or, alternatively, over a period of time up to the date the determining authorities make their decision.

I stress to the Senate that this is not a simple issue as, if it were possible to assess up to date, there may be factors which could result in a veteran being disentitled to eligibility for payment of a particular rate of pension during the period. The RSL recognises that these difficulties will require careful consideration by the monitoring committee. The policy issues related to assessment up to date that have been raised by the RSL represent a modification of the law as currently interpreted by the tribunals and the court. These are best dealt with following full examination by the monitoring committee.

Having regard to the undertaking I have given on behalf of the Minister, the RSL has advised that it is not opposed to the passage of the legislation in its present form. The National Secretary of the RSL, Mr Ian Gollings, has raised certain concerns about the TPI amendments contained in the Bill. The Minister has asked me to reaffirm the assurances in relation to those matters given by him and by Mr Michael Lee, the member for Dobell, on his behalf during the debate in the other place. I refer honourable senators to pages 2297-8 and 2322 of the House of Representatives Hansard of 18 November 1987. I reaffirm the assurances given on those pages.

A further question that has been raised concerns the effect of the new paragraph 19 (2) (a) on that part of the existing criteria for the granting of a TPI pension which requires that there be a determination in force, that the degree of a veteran's war-caused incapacity be 100 per cent of the general rate. The intention of the amendments is that a repatriation determining authority will, in examining whether a veteran satisfies the TPI criteria on the application day, have regard to any pre-existing determination that the veteran is 100 per cent incapacitated on that day or at the time the TPI question is being considered in determining whether the veteran was 100 per cent incapacitated on the application day. In either case the determining authority will then move on to consider whether the other aspects of the TPI criteria were met on the application day. I reassure the Senate and the RSL that it is not the Government's intention that a determination of 100 per cent incapacity must have been in force before the application day.

I move on to some other concerns that have been expressed about this legislation. I want to refer to some of the comments referred to by Senator Sheil in his amazing contribution to the debate yesterday. He made some comments about the attitude of Australians, in particular unemployed Australians, to work. The overwhelming evidence indicates that the great majority of unemployed in this country want to work and have taken active steps in the last month to try to find employment. That fact comes from an Australian Bureau of Statistics survey on the job search experience of unemployed persons in June 1986, when 98.5 per cent of unemployed persons reported having taken active steps to find work during the previous month. A recent Australian Market Research Pty Ltd study of sole parents, commissioned by the Department of Social Security, found that 55 per cent of sole parents indicated that they were likely to attempt to find a job in the future.

I move on to some of the other claims Senator Sheil made. The claim that by giving extra subsidies or benefits to groups we were making the problem worse was best expressed by his statement that if we continued to increase benefits for Aboriginals we would finish up with more Aboriginals. I hope that remark was made in jest. I cannot believe that it was serious. Just in case it was-judging by the tenor of Senator Sheil's other remarks it may have been-let me say that infant mortality rates for Aboriginals are still staggeringly high, far higher than they are for the rest of us. There are still real problems for us to overcome in this area. Fortunately, under our enlightened administration there is at least an attempt.

I am not sure what to say about Senator Sheil's sole campaign to remove unemployment on the Gold Coast. We were told that due to his efforts we now had a great many more people washing down yachts, cleaning Rolls-Royces - -

TALK.START.PARA: —And Mercedes.

—And Mercedes. Furthermore, we were told that we ought to be encouraging them to seek work as butlers-this was one of the trades that were dying due to our reliance on the welfare state. Perhaps we could create a society in which half the people owned the yachts and the Rolls-Royces and the other half cleaned them. Somehow I doubt that will come about. I have not bought my first boat or Rolls-Royce yet, which I think puts me in line with the great majority of Australians. Senator Sheil somehow believes that these are easy solutions. They are rubbish. The real problems that have developed in Australia, particularly in manufacturing industry over the past three or four decades, relate to so many years of mismanagement by previous conservative administrations when there was total reliance on the sheep's back and industry was left to look after itself. Unfortunately, that has created long term structural problems which, again, this Government is attempting successfully to rectify.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Sheil's suggestion that we should not give more money to the Brotherhood of St Laurence and other organisations because they were, in some way, contributing to a continuation of the problem, strikes me as incredible. I would have thought that the more money we could give these bodies, the more the poor could be helped. If that could be done no one on this side of the House-and I would hope not many on the other side of the House, apart from Senator Sheil-would even begin to disagree.

I turn to the comments that Senator Walters made yesterday. She raised some particular problems about poverty traps. In particular, we discussed whether a person on $330 a week with two children was having too much tax taken out of that money. I concede that there is a narrow range within the income ranges for family allowance supplement (FAS) eligibility where the marginal tax rate is 110 per cent. This is the range in which the Medicare levy is being shaded in at 20 per cent and the marginal tax rate is 40 per cent. As FAS is withdrawn at the rate of 50c in the dollar, the theoretical marginal tax rate is therefore 110 per cent. However, in practice, increases in income of less than 25 per cent will not affect FAS entitlement for up to six months and in most cases the 20 per cent Medicare shading arrangements will not apply to each dollar earned but will relate to total taxable income received during the financial year. Very few pensioners and beneficiaries have incomes within the relevant ranges and only a small percentage of the other 200,000 FAS recipients could be theoretically affected.

Senator Walters asked a specific question, as I mentioned earlier, and I will ensure that she receives a proper written answer. It is a matter which is now being investigated by the Department of Social Security, as it has been in a general way for some time. Senator Walters has just arrived, so I can tell her that while it has not been possible overnight to get the answer she requires, she will get a written one as soon as possible. I intend to ensure that she will receive it very soon as she has shown great interest in this matter. I ask for a little patience, but hopefully not too much.

TALK.START.PARA: —Could I have it during the committee stage?

—I am not sure that it will be ready that soon. We are attempting to get the information as soon as possible. I turn to the comments of Senator Powell, who raised some issues of recovery mechanisms available to the Department of Social Security and connected this with the Government's commitment to ensure that no child would be in poverty by 1990. I think she is really complaining about the debt recovery powers of the Department which were introduced in the May economic statement. I see that she is nodding in agreement.
—A lot of people are worried about it.

—Where there has been overpayment by the Department and recovery is under consideration there is a broad discretion to decide not to recover the overpayment if, for example, this would create hardship for the family. There is no inconsistency whatsoever between the debt recovery provisions and the commitment to remove child poverty. A watering down of the debt recovery powers, which I suppose is what Senator Powell contemplates, would only assist the people against whom the powers should properly be used. It would certainly not assist those who are in poverty. Senator Powell also mentioned the announcement that a social justice unit would be established in the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, as opposed to a wealth inquiry. Senator Powell might wait and see what happens before she pours cold water on that initiative.
—It was lukewarm water.

—All right, lukewarm. I apologise for a gross overstatement of the position. If we await the results of that initiative, we might find there is no need to pour anything on it. Having said that, I think it is also true to say in relation to wealth inquiries that, in light of what happened on the stock exchange in the last six weeks, the most such an inquiry would achieve would be that we would know where to find the wealth.

SPEECH.PARA: I turn now to the other pieces of legislation, given that Senator Vanstone did not go into the argument about the 2 1/2 per cent rule. I assume she will do so in the committee stage and I will answer the point then rather than repeat myself. I move on to the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2). First, let us look at the problem of the job search allowance and the Australian Democrats' amendment covering the payment of free pharmaceutical benefits. Let us look at what job search allowance recipients will receive as from 1 January. It is an impressive list, when one considers what they received in the past. They will receive $50 a week if they are independent, as judged by social security tests but subject to normal benefit income tests. If they are not independent, a parental income test will be applied, which can reduce the allowance to a minimum of $25 a week. It must be remembered that $50 a week is the same amount as unemployment benefits for 16- and 17-year-olds. This brings the unemployment benefit for 16- and 17-year-olds into line with education allowances.

The Bill provides that persons in receipt of this allowance will receive free pharmaceutical benefits if they are sick and unable to work. The same concession is extended to unemployed persons who are sick and unable to work. They receive sickness benefits and hence free pharmaceutical benefits. The safety net looks after recipients who need regular medication. Job search allowance recipients who exceed 25 scripts, costing $62.50, will thereafter receive free pharmaceutical benefits in any calendar year. It would be inequitable to provide free pharmaceutical benefits to one group of unemployed persons and not extend the same benefits to all unemployed and their dependants. The Democrats' amendment would, therefore, create significant anomalies. For instance, persons receiving a job search allowance and living at home with well-off parents-and I think there are a number who would want to do that-would be in a more advantageous position than a school age child of a person whose sole income is unemployment benefits. Unemployed persons and their dependants, on average, use seven pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS) prescriptions per year. To provide free PBS scripts to all these persons would cost approximately $18m a year. It is difficult to estimate the cost of giving job search allowance recipients free PBS scripts. The 16-to 17-year-old age group is generally recognised as being perhaps healthier than other age groups-certainly the age group to which I belong. Obviously people in this group would be making fewer demands on the public purse than would people in older age groups. No statistics are available on usage by this group. However, it follows that there would be fewer scripts written for them; it would be expected that job search allowance recipients would need fewer scripts than the seven scripts for the unemployed group as a whole. It is not considered unreasonable that job search allowance recipients make some contribution to the cost of their PBS scripts, as do all other persons receiving unemployment benefits. No doubt I will have a little more to say about that in the committee stage, if the matter is pursued.

I turn to a number of points raised during the debate on the Community Services and Health Legislation Amendment Bill. There are three sets of Opposition amendments and I want to try to deal with them. I think the best way is to take Senator Vanstone's criticisms one by one; some were also referred to by Senator Bjelke-Petersen. It might save a little time if I go through the criticisms rather than look at the amendments. The first is the criticism that the Bill does not allow private entrepreneurs to receive Commonwealth hostel subsidies. Under the legislation private entrepreneurs were excluded from the outset. It must be remembered that the legislation was first produced in 1954 by a coalition government. Since 1954 there have been 26 years of coalition government, a not inconsiderable period-indeed, for some of us on this side of the House definitely not an inconsiderable period. During those 26 years no attempt was made to amend the legislation to include private entrepreneurs. It must be acknowledged that standards of care in existing private hostels are poor in many cases-not in all cases, but in many. The Commonwealth does not wish to promote a continuation of that. The Australian Affiliation of Voluntary Care Associations (AAVCA) made the following comment on the Opposition's attempt to include this provision during passage of the Bill:
. . . there are concerns felt by the voluntary sector as to the kind of care being received by residents in hostel type accommodation presently being provided by the private sector . . .

That sums up the Government's attitude. The next criticism is that the Government has failed to consult the nursing home and hostel industry about aged care reforms and the changes in the Bill. It is true that the industry did not receive a copy of the Bill prior to its introduction into Parliament, but we would not want to be accused of a contempt of Parliament. Since March last year there have been 19 full days of consultation between the Department and the national voluntary care body, the AAVCA. There has been similar level of consultation with the private sector nursing home body, the Australian Nursing Homes Association. I will quote from that Association's views a little later. In April and October this year there were detailed public consultations in all States and the Australian Capital Territory. There has been a succession of consultations with the national consumer bodies and the trade union movement. One wonders just how much consultation the Opposition thinks the Government ought to indulge in on this occasion. I would have thought that the litany I have just given suggests that there has been an enormous amount of consultation.

Both Senator Vanstone and Senator Bjelke-Petersen commented on the removal of the Minister's discretion to determine nursing home fees. Obviously the Government wanted to ensure consistency, but I am surprised because normally Opposition members object to the inclusion of a Minister's discretion in legislation. Given the number of times that I and other senators have sat here and listened to Opposition members complain, I find it extraordinary, to say the least, that on this Bill they are suggesting the opposite. I am not sure whether the Government's desire for consistency in nursing home fees is practised by the Opposition when it comes to its own use of the chamber. In eliminating the discretion, the Bill will help to safeguard nursing home proprietors in the future against some other Minister-perhaps not so enlightened as the current Minister-who might otherwise be tempted to do favours for individual proprietors or, the opposite, victimise some unfavoured individual proprietors.

The next criticism was that the Bill duplicates State regulations. Except for very limited provisions that generally relate to retirement villages in some States, the States do not regulate hostels at all. Some State governments have held back from legislating, leaving it to the Commonwealth Government, which provides the funds, to do the job itself. Therefore, I think that I can be fairly dismissive of that criticism.

The next criticism, which I think is the main one in the time I had to listen to the debate, is that the Bill imposes on proprietors some unne-cessary and costly financial reporting requirements. While it is true to say that most proprietors are honest, it is also true to say that some are not and that they attempt to defraud the taxpayer or frail aged residents. After carefully considering the Bill, the AAVCA had something to say which I think is relevant:

The AAVCA cannot support anything less than a full and fair investigation of all those matters that pertain to the good care of residents. The AAVCA can have no part in seeking to assist those who by fraudulent means `rip off' either or both the taxpayer and or the residents.

Next I refer to a quotation from the Australian Nursing Homes Association. I think that Senator Bjelke-Petersen was wrong to suggest that the Association was opposed to the Bill. She may have been talking to a section of the Association; there is a splinter or ginger group. Contrary to the view that the Association opposes the Bill, let me quote Mr John Gillroy, the Executive Director of the Australian Nursing Homes Association. He said:

We concur with the Government's endeavours to tighten the net against those who follow unacceptable practices . . . Somewhere, somehow, sometime, the line has to be drawn. As an industry group, we have been asking the Department and the Government for two decades to get rid of the rotten apples. We can hardly now object when they finally act on our advice.

That is the truth of what that Association had to say: it is more than happy. Because of time constraints I will not go through quotations from the Pensioners Federation, the Accommodation Rights Service and so on, but generally speaking this provision is supported.

Senator Coulter, I am pleased to say, indicated that the Australian Democrats were pleased to support the Bill. He went through a number of points, but said that there was some scepticism about the Government's genuineness on the needs based planning system. He also criticised the adequacy of consultation. I hope I have covered the consultation point. On the other point, the Government has already enacted legislation to introduce the needs based planning system for the nursing home program and further legislation on hostels will be introduced in the autumn sittings.
