The Aged Care Advisory Committee has been established in all States to provide industry, consumer and professional inputs to improve service planning. I thank Senator Coulter for his support, and I hope that my explanation can allay some of his fears.
Amendment agreed to.
Original question, as amended, resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 3, 11 and 76-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The assets test presumes that people with substantial benefits apart from their own home apply those assets to produce income for their support and that, in cases where substantial assets are held but produce little or no income, the owners will choose to rearrange their affairs before they call upon the taxpayer or the community for income support through a pension system. However, it is acknowledged that there are instances where a person is unable to rearrange his or her financial affairs, or could not be reasonably expected to do so, before calling on the taxpayer. Consequently, there are special provisions included so that people are not placed in severe financial hardship due to the normal application of the assets test.

SPEECH.PARA: These hardship provisions allow for the value of particular assets to be disregarded and for the rate of pension payable to be determined in a special manner. However, a deemed annual rate of income may be taken into account in determining the rate of pension payable under the hardship provisions. The deemed income is the amount that could reasonably be expected to be derived from or produced with the use of the assets which have been disregarded for hardship purposes.

These provisions are of particular significance to rural properties. Deemed income is assessed in relation to farm properties if it is considered that the person is not receiving a reasonable commercial return from the property. It is accepted that a person is receiving a reasonable commercial return when, firstly, the property is being worked to its full capacity, and, secondly, the person's share of the income from the property is commensurate with his or her contribution to the operation of that property. I understand that the Department of Social Security manual provides that in general deemed income of 2.5 per cent of the net value of assessable assets is maintained as it relates to the net amount which could be received if the property were leased on a commercial basis. This is a rate of return which is considered a reasonably achievable net return in most situations and consequently has been adopted for the convenience of the Department and clients.

This Bill provides that the deemed income formula will be 2.5 per cent of the value of property disregarded or the commercial market value, whichever is the greater. This will be a significantly stricter arrangement than we have at the moment. At present the application of the deemed income provision in hardship cases is discretionary. This Bill removes that discretion. In every case where the hardship provisions are invoked, the deemed income formula will be applied to any disregarded property, whereas in the past it may have been applied. This will undoubtedly result in significant injustice for a significant number of rural dwellers. Similar arguments apply in relation to clause 76 (2) as it relates to veterans. Accordingly, the coalition has referred clause 11 (2), clause 76 (2) and clause 3 (10), which are the clauses dealing with this matter, to the Standing Committee on Community Affairs to assess the impact on pensioners and veterans. In order that the Government may have the remainder of the Bill while the Committee considers the impact of those clauses on pensioners-particularly rural Australians and veterans-these clauses need to be removed from the Bill. In order to achieve that I seek leave to move my amendments together.
Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 3, leave out subclause (10).
(2) Page 10, clause 11, leave out subclause (2).
(3) Pages 53 and 54, clause 76, leave out subclause (2).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise in support of the amendments moved by Senator Vanstone. I do so, having supported the amendment to the second reading motion and the referral of the question of the deeming of income from assets for further consideration. It is the case that this move of the Government is causing great concern, not just from the point of view of people in the rural sector; people in the welfare rights movement with whom I have had considerable consultation over other areas of this legislation have also expressed concern on this issue from the point of view that, as with the rural sector, the measure could exclude some assets which could not reasonably be expected to be sold in the circumstances. The Australian Democrats believe that the provisions which applied previously are adequate. There was a measure of discretion available, which we believe was appropriate. The mere fact that the Government has been the loser in some appeal cases does not indicate to us necessarily that this very structured proposal for a set level of 2 1/2 per cent deemed income is an appropriate response. In this issue we are talking about people who have assets but who for one reason or another are not necessarily deriving income from those assets. We believe that the previous situation which obtained was more likely to be able to meet the needs of people in those circumstances. It is true that the most obvious group of people affected tends to be those in the area of primary production, people who own land from which they are at least attempting to get an income or from which they have had an income at some past time in their life. But they are not the only people affected; there are people in urban situations who are similarly affected.

SPEECH.PARA: In supporting Senator Vanstone's amendments, I am quite sure that the Government will characterise our support as some kind of opposition to an assets test. I am afraid that the success of the amendments before the Committee-it is a rather rare occurrence for the Opposition to be successful in amending Budget legislation, but it is an occurrence that is welcomed by the Australian Democrats-will be characterised as our opposing the assets test. That is not the purpose of the amendments, and that is not the purpose of moving these amendments on behalf of the farming community. I remind the Senate that the National Farmers Federation was a lone voice among business organisations in support of the principle of assets testing. The amendments are simply addressed to the application of matters affecting assets testing and the deeming of income. We believe that those matters are not being handled well by this legislation.

When this legislation was debated in the House of Representatives, questions were raised about this issue, quite properly, by some honourable members on behalf of their constituents. The Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys) responded by saying, `the pension system is there to make sure that Australians have adequate income support. It is not there to subsidise inheritances'. The Australian Democrats agree with that statement. However, we need to consider the point that has been made to me by the National Farmers Federation and by individuals-not just those in the farming community but also small business people-about the assets test in general, and that is that in fact thousands of city-based pensioners have family homes that are exempt from the assets test. Some of those homes are valued at more than $200,000 or $300,000. Those prospective inheritances are quite demonstrably being heavily subsidised. Just picture for a moment a family with aging parents with considerable assets, which might be spread across a range of properties and belongings, making sure that mum and dad in the dying stages of their lives buy a mansion in Toorak worth $2.5m to live in. That sort of thing is possible. It is unfair to people in the rural community to be always seen as grasping and greedy when they raise genuine concerns about their ability to maintain their lifestyle and to maintain a continuing interest, and even a continuing family interest, in rural properties.

I believe the proposed amendments are reasonable. My one concern is that the Opposition has not moved an amendment to clause 11 (3). I shall pursue that matter myself, as I believe that the amendments moved by the Opposition, which I support, relate to pensions rather than to benefits. I think that technically has escaped the attention of the Opposition, unfortunately. On behalf of the Australian Democrats, I support the move embodied in the amendments. I welcome the fact that the Opposition is looking at this issue and showing genuine concern about it. The Australian Democrats have had considerable discussions about it and it was our intention to move such an amendment ourselves. However, on this occasion we are happy to support the Opposition's amendments.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am disappointed at the attitude adopted by the Australian Democrats. I shall briefly give some background to this matter. Some of the decisions handed down by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal have meant that in some cases no income at all has been imputed. The ordinary imputed income under the assets test is 10 per cent, but in some cases no income at all is involved. This has meant that in the case of a farmer who has retained a valuable farm which is not producing income, for the purpose of leaving it to his children, no income has been imputed when he died. Even though the farmer had the capacity to support himself from the proceeds of selling or mortgaging the farm, he was not required to do so. Rather, the public purse was called upon to support him because he wanted to hand the farm on to his children. It is not the purpose of any social security system to support such people. I am disappointed indeed that so many people opt to follow that practice.

SPEECH.PARA: Though I share Senator Powell's concern that the present system has caused worry to some people, the reality is that such people are covered by the pension loans scheme anyway; all of these cases are covered by an existing arrangement. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal has been generous to some of these people. The effect of this legislation will be to clear up the situation while at the same time keeping in place the pension loans scheme so that the full pension can be paid to the farmer and his wife while they are alive and, upon their death, the public purse will be reimbursed. I would have thought that was a more reasonable approach. Only a small number of cases are involved.

The Opposition dismissed as minuscule the projected saving of $2m. That is typical of its attitude to expenditure restraint, and I suppose it is typical of what happened under the first Lynch razor gang: it always ran away from the problem. The huge expenditure savings achieved by the Government have been effected only by each item being examined individually. All of these amounts of $2m add up to a very significant sum. For the record, 32 assets test hardship applications have been determined by the Administrative Appeals Tribunal; 17 were successful, affecting 24 people. Obviously it is expected that some of these people will have their entitlement reduced. However, all of them would have been eligible to receive payments under the pension loans scheme. I cannot understand why the Australian Democrats are prepared to support the amendments.
Amendments agreed to.
Clause 3, as amended, agreed to.
Ordered that further consideration of clauses 11 and 76, as amended, be postponed.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I now ask Senator Powell to give an indication of how she wishes to proceed. She has not yet moved any of the amendments circulated in her name.

—I intended to move my circulated amendments as the relevant clauses were called on. I should perhaps inform the Committee that we are working under difficulties, in that because of pressures being placed on the parliamentary staff-not the least of which is the unavailability of a reprinted principal Act, to which Senator Sheil referred last night-the amended version of my amendments has not yet been circulated. In substance, they merely seek to make amendments in respect of some technicalities. Though the numbering of my later amendments might be different from that appearing on the present circulated list, I think we can proceed. Those three clauses having been taken together, I assume that we will now proceed from clause 3. In that case, my first amendment is to clause 7.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The TEMPORARY CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank Senator Powell for advising the Committee on the way in which she thinks we should proceed.

INTERJECT.PARA: Clauses 4 to 6-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 7 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Page 6, subclause 7(1), leave out paragraph (a), insert the following paragraph:
``(a) by omitting subsection (8);''.

This amendment relates to a measure introduced in the May mini-Budget which sought to impose a six-month rule in respect of couples separated but living under the same roof. Since that measure was introduced it has been found, as was anticipated, to be causing considerable stress, particularly financial stress, in individual cases. The Australian Democrats believe that the rule should be abolished. It strikes particularly against low income people who are forced, upon separating legally, to remain in the same house if neither of them can find another place in which to live. Also many women are put at a disadvantage in property negotiations during divorce proceedings if their only option is to move out. Divorce proceedings can often take longer than the six-month period allowed for in this provision. I might add, too, that parents who continue to be responsible for their children may decide to stay together, living under the same roof, for a considerable period. Such decisions should not be impeded by a legislative provision such as this. If a couple decide between themselves that they are to separate in a marital sense-that is, they separate emotionally from each other but not from their children-and decide to maintain a situation that they believe is best for their children, with some kind of joint living, though separate, which is provided for under law, the Australian Democrats do not believe that a provision such as this should stand in their way. I stress that my concern also relates to the financial hardship which can occur as a result of this provision. My amendment therefore seeks to remove that provision.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clause 8 (Insertion of new section).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Page 8, clause 8, lines 19 to 38, proposed sections 3a (4) and (5), leave out the proposed subsections and insert the following subsections:
``(4) Where a person, whether before or after the commencement of this subsection, receives an amount of income, being an amount of a capital nature but not being:
(a) income from remunerative work undertaken by the person: or
(b) a return from an accruing return investment;

the person shall, for the purposes of this Act, be taken to receive one fifty-second of that amount as income of the person during each week in the period of 12 months commencing on the day on which the person received that amount.
(5) Where a person makes, at any time before 1 January 1988, an accruing return investment:
(a) with a friendly society; or
(b) of a kind where a return is not available until the end of a period of at least 12 months after the investment was made or until realisation of that investment;

and the person receives an amount by way of return on that investment the person shall, for the purposes of this Act, be taken to receive one fifty-second of that amount as income of the person during each week in the period of 12 months commencing on the day on which the person received that amount.''

This amendment, the first of a number we have of a similar nature, arises from a concern about the legislation as it is written. The concern about this clause was raised with the Australian Democrats by the Friendly Societies of Australia Federal Council. It relates specifically to the drafting of this legislation. The legislation makes it clear that after 1 January 1988 safe investments will be counted as income earned for pension eligibility, whether or not it is realised. However, this legislation has created uncertainty as to whether income accrued on capital guaranteed investments purchased before 1 January 1988 and market-linked investments will be exempt for pension eligibility purposes until that income is realised. This is a major concern, of course. Most of us will have seen the very heavy promotional program that has been undertaken to encourage people to take advantage of this commitment, which the Government said was to last until 1 January.

We do not oppose the new treatment of some post-1 January 1988 investments. The Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) explained the intention of the legislation in the second reading speech. He said that the Bill contained measures to clarify the treatment of income from investments and to ensure that people with deferred income, including income from friendly society bonds, are not advantaged over pensioners and beneficiaries with more straightforward forms of income such as those from bank deposits. As I said, we do not oppose this new treatment. But we have looked at the concerns regarding the drafting of this legislation, and the drafting really does not clarify that position. The friendly societies, I understand, have discussed this problem with the Department of Social Security, which claims that the existing drafting is necessary but that the interpretation will be such as to exclude both pre-1 January 1988 capital guaranteed investments and market-linked investments whenever they are purchased.

As I said, we have a number of amendments today which relate to the question of the legislation being somewhat imperfect and to people being asked to rely upon the interpretation within the Department. The Australian Democrats had a similar problem with the issue of German restitution payments. The Minister said that the problem would be solved by directing the Department of Social Security to interpret the legislation so as to exclude the restitution payments. We accepted that at that time. However, problems with that matter have occurred and the Minister has recently assured the Federation of Australian Jewish Welfare Societies that the legislation will be changed next year. We are saying to the Government in respect of this matter: `You have said before that it will be all right-that you would instruct the Department to interpret the legislation in a particular way. This does not always work'. There is at least that example to indicate that this procedure has not worked. We think it would be tidier and more efficient to fix the legislation here and now. Further, since the legislation is going back to the House of Representatives-given the passage of the amendments just dealt with-we cannot see any reason why the minds of people investing in friendly society bonds before 1 January, not to mention the friendly societies themselves, should not be set at rest by the simple passage of this amendment.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 9 and 10-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 11 (Financial hardship).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (4) Page 10, paragraphs 11 (3) (b) and (c), lines 34 to 43, leave out the proposed paragraphs.
(5) Page 11, subclause 11 (3), proposed subparagraph 7 (4a) (a) (i), line 32, after ``2.5% of the value'' insert ``or such lesser percentage of the value as may be prescribed''.

At least one of the amendments circulated in my name related to the amendment to sub-clause 11 (2), which has now been passed. I have not moved that amendment, but wish to pursue the amendments dealing with paragraphs 11 (3) (b) and (c) and sub-paragraph 7 (4a) (a) (i). The reason for pursuing these two amendments is that they apply to the question of deemed assets in relation to beneficiaries, whereas sub-clause 11 (2) related to pensioners. This concerns me, particularly as it is a feature of this legislation that assets testing is being extended to beneficiaries, which has not happened before. I have a further amendment which relates specifically to that matter. I wish simply to say that the same concerns which applied and which were articulated in relation to sub-clause 11 (2) also apply in this case. Simply because a separate part of the Bill relates to beneficiaries, it is necessary to pursue my amendment to sub-clause 11 (3).

I mentioned this matter to the Opposition spokesperson in this place. I understand the difficulties of someone here communicating with a spokesperson in the other place, and I understand that even now some communication is taking place at that level. But, as time is of the essence, it appears that we will not get Opposition support on this one, in spite of the fact that this amendment really involves the same provision for beneficiaries as the one which we, with the Opposition, just supported on behalf of pensioners. So I will pursue these two amendments and I would have been happier had they been supported by the Opposition.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I feel it is appropriate to clear up one point. There is no confusion on the coalition side with respect to these amendments. We have made it quite clear to the Australian Democrats that we will not support them. No negotiations are taking place at the moment, and I understood that Senator Powell was clear on that point. She appears not to be, so I now seek to put on the record that that is the case.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendments (Senator Powell's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Clauses as amended, agreed to.
Clauses 12 to 16-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At page 15, after clause 16, add the following new clauses:
`16a. Section 27 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting paragraph (b)'.

Again, this amendment is designed to pick up a problem arising from amendments to the principal Act in the May mini-Budget legislation which provided that people would have to prove a 50 per cent incapacity before they would be eligible for benefits. At that time questions about the practicality of this were raised by the Australian Democrats and by people in the welfare sector concerned with people with disabilities. They were concerned with the impracticality of demonstrating a disability to any given level, and 50 per cent seemed somewhat arbitrary in any case. It has been drawn to my attention that this provision has caused practical problems, not to mention individual emotional stress resulting from financial hardship. I have moved this amendment to continue the Australian Democrats' opposition to this provision and to highlight the problems it is already causing and we expect it will continue to cause to the disabled in our community.
Amendment negatived.
Clauses agreed to.
Clauses 17 to 20-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 21 (Carer's pension).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (7) Page 18, paragraph 21 (e), proposed paragraph (a) of definition of ``severely handicapped person'', line 4, leave out the proposed paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(a) has a physical, intellectual or psychiatric disability; and;''.
(8) Page 18, clause 21, proposed paragraph 39 (3) (b), lines 5 to 9, leave out the proposed paragraph.

This section of the legislation relates to the extension of the carer's pension which was announced in the Budget. The announcement of the extension of the carer's pension was greeted by the Australian Democrats-including me-with great delight because in the last stages of the former Parliament I moved amendments to social security legislation in an attempt to implement extensions to the carer's pension. At that time I made the point that if anybody in the community is prepared, on a daily basis, to give constant care and attention to an individual who needs that care and attention, and provided no income support is otherwise available, that person should receive the support of the community. At that time I quoted statistics to demonstrate that in the area of the rather distressing burgeoning of the acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) epidemic to extend the carer's pension could be seen as an economy measure on behalf of the Government because it costs considerably more for the very ill and the dying to be cared for in institutions. I also made the point that this is the sort of direction that Government policy is taking. An amendment moved in May that people should be cared for in their own home was not supported by the Government or the Opposition. However, the carer's pension was extended in the Budget.

Quite clearly, in this legislation the restrictions on those people who are eligible to receive the carer's pension have been removed and we certainly welcome that measure. However, there are concerns about this section of the legislation and they arise from sub-clauses which have defined the broader definitions of people who can receive the carer's pension. The definition of those who are to be cared for has been changed and, by being changed, has been limited. The criteria for the kind of care which those people can receive has been changed and limited and the amendments I have moved address those two issues.

I refer, firstly, to amendments to clause 21, paragraph (e) sub-paragraph (a) which will substitute the definition that a person has a physical or intellectual disability. This raises another area of amendment to previous government legislation-the disability services legislation which was passed late in 1986-in which definitions were changed. The people involved in supporting the disabled in the community have wanted changes to the legislation because previous principal Acts have been in terms of physical and mental disability. There has been lobbying for changes in that definition.

At the time the disability services legislation was before the Parliament there was a great hue and cry because the definition of disability had been changed to `physical or intellectual disability' which is in this legislation. A whole category of the disabled had been left out, that is, the psychiatrically disabled. It is a category of people which, since the International Year of Disabled Persons, has been recognised as being a significant and recognisable group within the disabled community, a group of people who had been consulted prior to that legislation being introduced but who had been left out of it. On that occasion both Senator Peter Baume and I moved amendments to change the definition of `disabled' to include the psychiatrically disabled. The Democrats and the Opposition supported those amendments and they were included in the legislation.

On this occasion and in another provision in the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 once again the psychiatrically disabled are being excluded. I for one am not prepared to tolerate that. I have received a telex from Russell Hunt, the Executive Director of Disabled People's International, who supports this amendment and the amendment that I will move later to the child disability allowance which raises the same issue. I point out, perhaps with some distress, the response from the Minister at the time, Senator Grimes, who, having had these amendments passed by the Opposition and the Democrats, indicated that it was his intention to ignore that fact. He said:
The way I administer the legislation in fact it will not cost anything at all.

I am concerned if the attitude which Senator Grimes took at the time to the extension of the definition to the psychiatrically disabled is the motivation behind these definitions being left out in this legislation. I do not believe that that is the reason; I believe that it is an oversight on behalf of the Government. It is utterly inconsistent that the psychiatrically disabled should be left out on this occasion, as they were previously, because we will now have two pieces of legislation with differing definitions of the word `disability'. As I have said, Disabled People's International, the people at the Australian Council for Rehabilitation for Disabled, who supported the amendment when it was moved previously, support it again now. I think it is a mere technicality and I will be absolutely astonished if the Government does not support at least the amendment to clause 21 paragraph (e) sub-paragraph (a) of my series of amendments.

I understand that the Opposition may once again support the Democrats on this matter and, if so, I would welcome it. It may be necessary for us to take separately sub-paragraph (a) of this amendment if that is the case. The definitions contained in sub-paragraphs (i) and (ii) are also areas of concern which are addressed by this amendment. Previously the carer's pension was made available to people who were looking after those who were defined as being severely handicapped and who needed constant care and attention. This legislation changes that definition to state `frequent attention in connection with the person's bodily functions or constant supervision to prevent injury to the person or to another person permanently or for an extended period'. The concern is that that changed definition is likely to lead to a restriction in terms of the people who may be cared for and the carer being eligible to receive a carer's pension. If that is the case, in light of these two redefinitions, any claim that the carer's pension is being extended would be a cruel deception to people in the community who, like me, applauded the announcement of this measure before we saw the legislation. For instance, organisations such as the Australian Federation of AIDS Organisations wrote to me with great delight when that announcement was made and thanked the Democrats for their actions in May. They suggested that this Budget decision was the fruition of that exercise and they would be bitterly disappointed if, by these definitions being restricted, access to the carer's pension was not, in the overall picture, actually extended.

I have moved the amendments so that the technicality of psychiatric disability having been omitted can be addressed by the Government and so that it can assure the people concerned that those who are being cared for will be cared for under the same definition as they were previously under the carer's pension.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to take up the points raised by Senator Powell about the Democrats' amendment No. 7, because she has continually made the statement that the category of psychiatrically disabled is being left out. This is simply not true. Apparently the amendment has been moved because of a concern that the replacement of the word `mental' by the word `intellectual' narrows the meaning so that in some way psychiatric conditions are excluded. There has been no narrowing of the meaning of the section at all. People with psychiatric disabilities are covered by this clause. The change was made because the Government had received from the Australian Council for the Rehabilitation of Disabled, an organisation to which Senator Powell referred, advice that the word `mental' was offensive to some groups in the community-in fact to a significant section-with which this provision had to deal.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the only other thing I can say is that in the implementation of these criteria the system will be operated in such a way that we would not exclude anyone who qualified under the previous arrangements. The Government's opposition to the amendment stems from the fact that, firstly, we believe it is not necessary, that no one is being excluded; and secondly, the change to the wording had simply been misunderstood. We have reacted to community concern, in a proper way I think, and the problem is that that proper way has been misunderstood.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am very pleased to hear what Senator Richardson has just said, but very disappointed to hear the conclusion he draws from those remarks. If in fact there is no intention to reduce the benefit, he should have concern about dotting the i's and crossing the t's and making the matter quite clear. In my mind there is a very distinct difference between intellectual and psychiatric disability, and it is certainly open to interpretation that psychiatric disability does not include intellectual disability.

SPEECH.PARA: I draw Senator Richardson's attention to the fact that about 4,000 people are killed each year on Australia's roads. While the number injured is not that well categorised, we suspect that it is something like 10 times that number; and among those there are large numbers who suffer head injuries. A number of those people suffer no intellectual impairment whatsoever but, because of frontal lobe injuries, suffer quite severe psychiatric and personal disabilities which would not, in my mind, be covered by the words `intellectual disability. Therefore, the inclusion of `physical, intellectual or psychiatric disability' makes the matter quite clear and puts it beyond the ability of anybody to misinterpret those words. I therefore ask Senator Richardson to reconsider his remarks and to draw the appropriate conclusion, that is, that the amendment is quite appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hesi-tate to take more time of the chamber, but I vividly recall the debate during the disability services legislation. At that time I had not been a member of this chamber for very long and was absolutely distressed by the lack of understan-ding of senior members of this chamber, some of them either medical practitioners or married to medical practitioners, who constantly during the debate talked about mental illness and mental disability and confused `intellectual' with `psychiatric', `mental' with `psychiatric', and `illness' with `disability'. There is tremendous confusion in this area, and that was clearly displayed in the chamber. I have been exhorted time and again to support one or other of the sides of this chamber on legislation. I exhort the Minister, and through the Minister his advisers, to look again at this. There is in the community a genuine group-and it is not a very large group; I made that point last year in the debate-to whom, by pushing them beneath the surface, whether that is intended or not, we are doing a disservice. They do exist. They are a separate category of the disabled, and that cannot be denied. The discussion papers from the Department of Community Services and Health which preceded the disability services legislation made that quite clear. The community has a bad record, and the Government an even worse record, in recognising this group of disabled people. I put in this final plea to the Minister and his advisers: This legislation is going back to the House of Representatives. The insertion of two words, here and in the child disability allowance area, will clean up at least that. I think it is the very least the Government could do in this instance.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Powell has moved two amendments to clause 21. I will put the two amendments separately to the Committee. The question is that amendment No. 7 be agreed to.

INTERJECT.PARA: Amendment agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 12.30 p.m., pursuant to sessional order I shall report progress.

INTERJECT.PARA: The Chairman having reported accordingly-
Sitting suspended from 12.30 to 2.15 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the answer he gave to my question on Monday in which he said that he had been present at a meeting between the Prime Minister and the Chairman of the Australian Broadcasting Corporation (ABC). During the answer he denied that pressure had been brought to bear on Mr Somervaille concerning a then pending Four Corners program on Sir Peter Abeles. I ask the Minister: Was he present for the whole time Mr Somervaille was in the Prime Minister's suite? I further ask: Was the name of Sir Peter Abeles raised while he was there, and if so by whom and in what context?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was there for the whole time of the conversation which, I believe, is the source of the speculation that has arisen on this matter. Beyond that I do not propose to go into any detail of what was said on that occasion. I simply rely on Mr Somervaille's own public statement made yesterday and released in response to an extremely ill-judged and extravagant comment from the late Opposition spokesman on media matters, Mr Ian Macphee, the relevant portion of Mr Somervaille's release being in the following terms:

ANSWER.PARA: At no time has the Prime Minister or any other Minister applied or tried to apply pressure on me in matters relating to program content or in any other matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My supplementary question relates to the answer that has just been given and the answer given by Senator Evans on Monday. On Monday Senator Evans was prepared to tell the Senate that to his certain knowledge the Prime Minister had not sought to influence the content of the program. He was further prepared to tell the Senate that concern had been expressed about the desirability of a high quality being maintained in ABC programming. I ask the Minister: In light of his forthright comments that he and the Prime Minister should not be seeking to influence the programming content of the ABC, why is he not prepared to give us the facts in this matter? What has he got to hide?

—I have absolutely nothing at all to hide. I have given a sufficient statement of the facts of the matter to answer comprehensively, completely and credibly the kind of scuttlebutt, allegation, innuendo, imputation and generally extravagant misallegation that we have heard from the Opposition in this matter. I have nothing more to say.

—Can the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training advise what proportion of students who begin studies at an Australian university actually complete their studies and graduate? Are comparable figures available for colleges of advanced education? Is the Government satisfied with this level of graduation from our universities and colleges of advanced education and, if not, what can be done to improve the current situation?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have some information that will assist Senator Colston. Really accurate information about graduate rates in Australia's universities and colleges of advanced education is not available. However, in the mid-1970s the graduate rate was estimated at about two-thirds of intake. Some recent studies have suggested that graduate rates for the higher education system as a whole may now be as high as 75 per cent if transfer and subsequent re-entry is taken into account. There is no breakdown between colleges of advanced education and university rates at this stage. Other estimates, however, put student attrition rates for some higher education institutions and disciplines as high as 40 per cent. Preliminary data from the current national review of the engineering discipline, for example, show completion rates to be 59 per cent for universities and 45 per cent for advanced education institutions.

ANSWER.PARA: The answer to Senator Colston's question as to whether the Government is satisfied with this rate of completion is no. The Government believes that there is scope for improvement in completion rates in higher education. Senator Colston may be aware that the issue is taken up in the higher education policy discussion paper which will be tabled by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training today. The paper argues that the success of institutions in addressing the issue of completion rates will become more important in the context of resource allocation processes that will focus increasingly on assessment of overall institutional performance. Measures that might be addressed to improve graduation rates are dealt with in the policy discussion paper. As a first step in the process it will be necessary to collect more reliable information in this area and this will be a high priority for the Department of Employment, Education and Training.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Minister for Justice that this morning the Senate passed my motion condemning the Government for its cowardly and despicable action in hiding behind the statute of limitations in its defence against claims for compensation arising out of the HMAS Voyager disaster. In view of the fact that the Government has previously admitted liability, that two years ago it agreed to waive the statute and that Mr Justice O'Bryan of the Victorian Supreme Court has severely criticised the Go-vernment's apparent approach, will the Minister, on an issue that cries out for natural justice, take the matter back to the Government for reconsideration so that those people seeking compensation can have their day in court?

—I will not take the matter back to the Attorney-General for his further consideration; he has given very serious consi-deration to the issue involved in deciding to plead the statute of limitations. Honourable senators will be aware that the incident out of which these mainly mental and psychiatric conditions are said to arise occurred in 1964, at which time there was a general indication by the then Attorney-General to the survivors and their families and to the families of those who died that the Commonwealth would be prepared at that stage to accept their claims. Many settlements were undertaken at that time. As I explained yesterday, the Government and the Attorney-General have not done anything extraordinary or unusual. The Government has pleaded the statute of limitations, which is available in Victorian jurisdiction and which is expressed in terms recognising that it is very likely to prejudice a party if evidence goes stale over a period of years. I think that the statute itself in Victoria speaks of three years in relation to these sorts of claims. In deciding whether to plead the statute of limitations, the Commonwealth has always taken the view that it should take the term of longest duration available under any statute of limitations in Australia, and that is six years. Clearly, 23 years have passed since this incident and the sorts of evidence that would be available to the Commonwealth in order to rebut the claims put forward by these survivors would clearly be very difficult to assemble. In that situation, the sort of prejudice which would arise if these claims were litigated is very apparent. The Attorney-General made his decision for that reason and I do not believe that he intends to reconsider the matter.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is not the Minister dissembling when he says that the claim goes back some 23 years when, in fact, previous governments were bound by a decision of the High Court of Australia which restricted any action that might have been taken in that period? Secondly, was not the statement that was made two years ago clear to the point that it waived any statute and that Mr Justice O'Bryan, having taken on the case, has criticised the Government for employing that defence? Thirdly, why did the Government not divide on this issue when the motion was put before the Senate this morning?

—It is true that Mr Justice O'Bryan of the Victorian Supreme Court made some critical comments on the fact that the Commonwealth had decided to plead the statute. But there was no great argument before him as to the reasons why the Commonwealth had pleaded the statute. He took it upon himself to substitute his judgment for that of the Attorney, who is the correct repository of the necessary exercise of judgment and discretion in this instance. He found that there had been no waiver by the Commonwealth in the sense that the Commonwealth was estopped by any previous decision by departmental officers to settle in one or two cases. The Commonwealth was not estopped from pleading the statute. That is a clear part of his finding as a matter of law. His other comments are not matters which, strictly speaking, are within his capacity as a judge. Those decisions have been made by the Attorney-General and I do not believe that they are to be reconsidered.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in my gallery of a former distinguished senator, Minister and ambassador, Sir Robert Cotton. On behalf of all senators, I welcome him to Canberra, particularly as he is here because of his involvement with the political exchange program.

INTERJECT.PARA: Honourable senators-Hear, hear!

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Has the World Heritage Committee considered the Federal Government's nomination of Uluru National Park to the World Heritage List? If so, has it added that unique part of Australia to that prestigious list?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President--
—This is the Minister in continuation.

—I am not in continuation; this is the first attempt of the day, as a matter of fact. The World Heritage Committee, I am pleased to inform the Senate, has approved the inscription of Uluru on the World Heritage List. I know that on behalf of all senators I can express our delight at that occurrence. It is formal recognition of the significance of a magnificent area-an area that was originally nominated by this Government. I am sure that all senators will share in our delight.

ANSWER.PARA: The nomination was suggested by the traditional owners, for whom many features of the national park hold special significance. The rock itself, the Olgas and the surrounding areas have special significance for all Australians. Certainly, the number of people who are visiting those areas is growing at an extraordinary rate. The listing will not interfere with the rights of traditional owners.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will it interfere with the monorail?

—Now that Senator Puplick has asked that question, I digress. The new management plan, which we will have a good look at, will not include a specific section on monorails. I have always doubted that construction would go ahead, and I still find it difficult to believe.
—You are a two-rail man, aren't you?

—Take it easy, Senator. The honour that has been given the area, and indeed the country, also presents us with a special responsibility to preserve and manage it in a fitting and proper manner. The Australian Government relishes that task, and along with the traditional owners we shall embark upon it.

ANSWER.PARA: It is interesting to note, though, that the Committee praised the way in which the traditional owners have been involved in planning. It also praised the Australian Government for its role in the management of the park. I am delighted to hear that, given that over the next few hours the Committee will also consider Kakadu stage 2. I know that a Minister of the Northern Territory Government has seen fit to drop over to Paris to oppose that listing, for all the wrong reasons. I am sure that he and his officials have had a nice trip and their visit to the Louvre may have been magnificent; but I doubt very much whether their trip will affect the listing.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think he means the loo.

—I said `the Louvre', not the loo-although he may have been in there too. Finally, special mention was made by the World Heritage Committee of appreciation of the efforts of the Government to reintroduce to the area species which unfortunately not only have been endangered but also have disappeared since European civilisation. The Government intends to continue that program. All in all, this is another result not only for which the Government can take credit but also for which the Australian people can give thanks.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Is it a fact that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has asked for the views of the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy on proposed cable logging near Clumner Bluff, next to the Walls of Jerusalem National Park in north-western Tasmania? Is the Minister aware that the operation is proposed for an area on the Register of the National Estate? Is he further aware of the numerous times that the Tasmanian Forestry Commission has lost control of regeneration burns and other fires, resulting in destruction of adjacent forests? If so, is he confident that the nearby timber, including the world's largest remaining forest of the rare pencil pine, will remain unburnt? If he cannot give absolute assurances that the pencil pine will be safe, will he ensure that the logging operation will not proceed, especially since the logging site is part of the National Estate? If not, why not?

—Two days ago Senator Sanders told me-or, to be more accurate, my office-that he was going to ask a question like this. But he did not do it then or yesterday. At that stage Mr Kerin's office was contacted. The answer on Monday was that the ceiling in the part of the building which houses the relevant branch of what is now the Department of Primary Industries and Energy had fallen in and that, because there was a bit of asbestos up in the ceiling, the building had been evacuated and, therefore, either there was nobody there who could be contacted to write an answer, or a typewriter could not be found to type it out. That was the situation two days ago. I do not know what has happened since but I will see whether I can find out.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to the differing economic and labour market conditions in various parts of Australia. In view of this, what are the prospects for an individual-say, a very senior State parliamentarian such as a former Premier-finding alternative work in Queensland compared with the rest of Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —An ordinary Queenslander looking for a job faces bleak prospects. Probably the best single indicator of the prospect of a person getting employment is the ratio of people seeking employment to the number of job vacancies. The national average is almost 11 per cent. In Queensland the figure is almost 22 per cent. In other works, an ordinary Queenslander has about half as much chance of getting a job as have Australians overall. If one is lucky enough to live in Victoria or New South Wales, the prospects are enhanced significantly. In Victoria there are just over seven people seeking employment for every job vacancy; in New South Wales the figure is just over 9 1/2.

ANSWER.PARA: The latter hypothetical part of the question touched on somebody who is not an ordinary Queenslander but an ex-Premier of Queensland. I noticed that it was being reported last week that the former Premier was about to take a high profile appointment in the private sector. I must say I was surprised at that.

TALK.START.PARA: —As an also-ran, you could have given him a job in CSIRO, I suppose.

—No, I do not think that is likely. I do not think that even a coalition government, if we should ever have one, would give him a job in the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation. Indeed, I was surprised that it was even being reported that he was about to take a high profile job anywhere in the private sector. I cannot imagine the private sector giving that individual any important position, unless it was to become, say, the executive director of the hydrogen car corporation or the Milan Brych cancer clinic.

—I ask a supplementary question, Mr President. I would like Senator Walsh to clarify that answer. Was he saying that in Queensland there are 21 unemployed persons for every job vacancy? How does that compare with the national average?

—I said in fact that there were almost 22-21.8 to be precise-unemployed people in Queensland for every job vacancy recorded. The national average is just under 11, or 10.7, if one wants to be precise. In other words, it is twice as difficult for a person looking for a job to get one in Queensland as it is in the rest of Australia on average.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. I preface my question to the Minister by referring to the meeting of the Organisation of Petroleum Exporting Countries (OPEC) which was to commence in Vienna today and which is occurring within the context of the growing prospect of a downturn in the economy of the United States of America, as well as a forecast drop in world demand for oil, in the wake of the recent collapse of international stock and foreign exchange markets. In that connection I note also the reported decision by Saudi Arabia not to cut its oil production in 1988, despite over quota production by other OPEC producers and a likely increase in new supply from non-OPEC producers. Does the Minister agree that in these circumstances there appears to be a significant probability of an appreciable fall in world oil prices next year from the current benchmark of $US18 a barrel? If so, would the Minister expect to see a flow-on to other international energy commodity prices, and most particularly coal? Finally, will the Minister indicate what domestic economic policy adjustments will be appropriate-and how soon-to ensure that Australia's already critical foreign debt and balance of payments positions do not deteriorate further in the face of this worsening external trade environment for Australia's energy exports?

—Just over three years ago I kept myself fairly well briefed on these subjects, as Senator Evans would have kept himself fairly well briefed on them about six months ago. I am no longer so well briefed. Therefore, I would not pretend that I could give any sort of definitive answer to the question. Of course, I have heard the standard news reports canvassing the possibilities that Senator Stone mentioned in his question. I was asked whether an appreciable fall in oil prices would be likely to flow on to coal prices. I think the answer to that question is, in the long term, yes. I am less sure what would happen in the short term. Obviously in the short term a fall in the price of oil in isolation would have an effect on Government revenue, unless the lower excise collections on crude oil were offset by increases in excise on refined product, which is present Government policy. As to our trade account, since Australia is, I believe, still a significant net importer of oil--
—Energy.

—I said that I was dealing with oil alone. Australia is a significant importer of oil. A fall in the price of oil in isolation obviously would result in our balance of payments position being a little better. I shall obtain from Mr Kerin a more up to date and definitive answer to the question.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister not agree that when the international price of oil fell very sharply indeed earlier this year-I think it got down to as low as $US7 a barrel at that time for a brief period-there were very considerable flow-on consequences for our coal export prices in the contract negotiation processes that took place a few months after that occurrence? Second, will the Minister not agree, notwithstanding his erudite exposition on our energy balance so far as oil is concerned, that insofar as total energy is concerned, including coal, Australia is a very significant energy exporter? Will the Minister therefore respond to my question, which was directed to the total energy component of our balance of payments?

—I did respond to the question. I said that a substantial fall or an appreciable fall in the price of oil was likely in the long term to adversely affect the price of coal. I am less sure of what the short term effects would be.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Justice. In view of the tragic and horrifying rampage by an armed man in Melbourne yesterday, resulting in the death of eight people and his own ghastly suicide, can the Minister inform the Senate of the current position with respect to national firearms control?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —First of all I express, I am sure on behalf of all senators, my sympathy and condolences to the families of those innocent people who were yesterday so senselessly massacred in this terrible assault at the offices of Telecom Australian and Australia Post. I am sure that everyone would consider that we need to take steps to ensure that a 22-year-old who is frustrated in some argument with a friend does not turn to a rifle and inflict grievous harm and even death on innocent citizens in order to impose his own solution on what is obviously for him a frustrating situation.

ANSWER.PARA: It is clear that, as a nation, we need a much more stringent approach to the question of firearms control. We need controls by way of licensing the persons who are to have legal ownership and possession of firearms and other weapons, and we need to have a system of permits relating to the different types of weapons that might be possessed. Bringing these matters together, it is quite clear that weapons-particularly lethal weapons such as high powered rifles and automatic and semi-automatic weapons-should perhaps be made available only to those who are members of registered, recognised and reputable firearms associations. The idea that, as is the case in my home State of Tasmania, any person can simply go into a gun shop and, by merely asserting that he or she is over 16, obtain a high powered weapon and ammunition across the counter is absolutely intolerable. I am sure that this idea will be rejected by all thinking people around Australia.

I am not so naive as to suppose that even the most stringent laws will prevent a deranged or obsessed person from getting hold of a weapon and inflicting grievous bodily harm and perhaps death on those with whom he or she is having an argument or, as is so tragically the case in these mass killings, wreaking havoc amongst the innocent. Every action possible should be taken to make it extremely difficult for a person to come upon a rifle or some other weapon as a very readily available means of settling an argument or expressing his or her frustration. It is true that at a meeting of the Australian Police Ministers Council held in Hobart less than a fortnight ago the following resolution was passed, with Queensland and Tasmania not concurring:

. . . recognising that the absence of national uniform controls over the acquisition and possession of firearms weakens the effectiveness of the controls existing in individual jurisdictions, each member of the APMC seeks to implement legislation . . . to require-
(i) the licensing of a person to possess firearms;
(ii) the obtaining of a permit to purchase firearms;
(iii) the registration of all longarms; and
(iv) ammunition to be sold only to persons authorised to possess a firearm . . .

Quite clearly, these are only very sketchy, tentative first steps towards a national approach. But they demonstrate a recognition that State boundaries are very artificial when one is talking about the movement of weapons and persons around Australia. We do need a national approach. I certainly hope that Tasmania and Queensland will reconsider their position in light of yesterday's tragic incident. I am not seeking-and I do not believe anyone is really seeking-to get technical uniformity in every respect in regard to licensing and permits throughout Australia, but we do need to have a national consensus and approach.

With due respect to our American parliamentary colleagues in the gallery and young political leaders from America, I do think that we in Australia want to avoid the cultural and social situation that prevails in the United States of America where it is thought to be a constitutional right to bear arms. I believe that in Australia we regard the bearing of arms, and should regard the ownership and possession of firearms, as a privilege, as a concession by society to some rural recreational shooters and to those who need a weapon for a security reason, but certainly not as a right. Certainly we do not regard it as a right which overbalances or outweighs the rights of innocent citizens to go about their lawful pursuits-their work and their recreation-without the fear of being in jeopardy of an assault which can occasion such grievous bodily harm or even death, as occurred yesterday.

I believe that the people of Australia, shocked by yesterday's massacre, will give political support to those governments which do implement a more stringent regime in this regard. The Federal Government has limited powers in regard to the import of weapons and in its own jurisdiction in the Australian Capital Territory, but we stand ready to facilitate and to support any moves by governments around Australia in the various jurisdictions to implement more stringent controls.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. Did the Minister issue a Press release on 3 December in which he said financial assistance for any workers displaced as a result of job losses in the timber industry in north Queensland would be guaranteed under `an interim compensation package to go to Federal Cabinet next week'? Did he yesterday, in answer to Senator Boswell, state in relation to compensation that it would be `ridiculous to make submissions to Cabinet before we have received results of the consultancies', which reports are not expected, according to the Minister, until some time in January? Given that final decisions on the boundaries have now been made by Cabinet, when will any compensation package be decided by Federal Cabinet? Is it this week, as promised on 3 December, or will it not be until January, as stated yesterday?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday, in answer to Senator Boswell's question, I made it clear that the package of compensation for north Queensland-not just for displaced workers, it can go wider than that because it has to include the industry as well-will not be submitted to Cabinet until I have had an opportunity to assess the final reports that will be presented by the six consultants who are working on the problem now. It is hoped that those consultants will report to us by the end of January or early February, so I can be confident of having a submission ready in February.

ANSWER.PARA: However, Senator Puplick may have misunderstood the import of statements made about an interim measure to protect people between now and then. It is the Government's belief that very few Queenslanders will be put out of work or dislocated in the immediate future because of decisions I shall announce on Friday. Most of the mills-in fact all of the mills bar one, so far as I can discover-have been working overtime in the forests to ensure an extraordinary amount of the resources is taken out to enable them to continue. That being the case, we would anticipate that, if there is to be dislocation, it will occur from April, perhaps even from May. However, because of the possibility that some people may be affected in the interim, I did present to Cabinet a package which was approved on Monday for an interim protection measure. I shall be announcing the results of that on Friday.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Has the Minister read the recently declassified documents released by the United States Department of Defense showing that American forces in the Pacific are prepared to fight limited and prolonged nuclear wars, although what on earth prolonged nuclear wars are by definition is not clear? Do couriers from the United States armed forces courier service go through Australia, and is the Government aware that these couriers carry the computer instructions used to order United States naval ships to use their nuclear weapons? I ask the Minister how the Government can reconcile United States plans for fighting limited and prolonged nuclear wars in the Pacific with the presence in Fremantle Harbour today of the Missouri battle group, which comes under the authority of CINCPAC-Commander in Chief, Pacific? Does the Government not acknowledge the irony of applauding the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement which involves the withdrawal of cruise missiles from western Europe in the same week as it is giving permission for a United States battleship with 32 cruise missiles on board to enter an Australian harbour? Finally, does not the presence of the Missouri battle group in Australia over Christmas does not prove the assertion by retired Lieutenant-Commander Michael Lynch of the Royal Australian Navy that the only purpose of port calls to Australia by US warships is rest and recreation-to put it politely and euphemistically-and nothing to do with any strategic necessity?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Vallentine's revelations are, as usual, breathtaking in their irrelevance. We can only share her amazement at the suggestion that the forces of another country are prepared to engage in combat. What a marvellous revelation that is! Why else would they exist, I wonder?
—Exactly.

—Well, one does have an army to defend oneself. Otherwise, Senator Walsh has a $7.6 billion saving coming up in the next Budget. For some considerable time the United States has adopted policies for deterring war. The American military force, including nuclear forces, has been deployed to support that objective and peace has been maintained in part because, as President Reagan has declared, nuclear wars cannot be won and must never be fought. Until complete disarmament can be achieved, Australia supports the maintenance of peace through deterrence and co-operates militarily with the United States and other countries for that purpose.

ANSWER.PARA: Elements of the United States military do visit Australia periodically for a range of reasons encompassing Australian and US interests. Australian interests include our participation in combined exercises and the familiarisation of our principal ally with the operational environment of our region of direct military interest. Opportunities for refuelling, reprovisioning and crew rest and recreation are also important elements. The Australian Government accepts the United States practice of neither confirming nor denying the presence of nuclear weapons on board its warships. All ship visits take place on this understanding.

The linkage Senator Vallentine attempts to draw between the INF agreement and the visit of the Missouri battle group is too tenuous as to defy national comment. The Government welcomes the INF treaty which, for the first time, will eliminate an entire class of nuclear weapons. Importantly, it does so without putting international security at risk. It is understandable that the INF agreement has forced Senator Vallentine to clutch at straws, as it destroys many of the myths she has sought to promote both in this chamber and outside, and vindicates the arguments that this Government uses in regard to the realities of the way progress can be made on disarmament issues.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. It seems obvious from the Minister's answer that he does not understand the connection between the INF, so I have to ask him whether he is not aware of the fact that the missiles which President Reagan and Secretary General Gorbachev were signing away today in Washington are exactly the same as the kinds of weapons systems which are on board the USS Missouri in Fremantle Harbour today. They are exactly the same kind of cruise missile systems. So while the super-powers are beginning to disarm on land-which we are very pleased about-is it not a supreme irony that our Government invites exactly the same missile systems into Australian harbours on the very same day?
—Order! That is a supplementary question and also a speech.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have already alluded to the fact that it is the policy of the Australian Government to agree with the American Government to neither confirm nor deny what weapons systems of a nuclear nature are on visiting ships. Senator Vallentine obviously misunderstood me on that position. This has been repeated here time and time again, but apparently Senator Vallentine thinks that if someone goes mining, sooner or later that person will come up with a nugget of gold. She will come up absolutely dead broke on this and every other occasion.

ANSWER.PARA: The other point to be made is-and we will no doubt go through this again with some tedious repetition for two hours later this afternoon-nuclear disarmament or any disarmament is a long-winded process. It will not be brought about simply by good intentions by unilateralists or anyone else. It will be brought about by hard work, by agreement and by verification when all the pieces are in place. It will not be brought about by people marching up to Pine Gap and waving a few placards about, or by anything else. It will be brought about by hard work that can then be justified by both countries with absolute certainty that the conditions under which they enter into those agreements will be met.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts. I refer the Minister to remarks made by Mr Peter Beattie, the Queensland State Secretary of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), in regard to the Federal handling of the rainforest World Heritage issue when Mr Beattie accused the Minister of insensitivity towards the lives and livelihoods of people in north and far north Queensland. Mr Beattie said:

QUESTION.PARA: He's offended quite a lot of people locally and I think there will be problems for us in the State area in the future as a result of his clumsy handling of the issue.
He had handled it in a very crude way. This is not a factional brawl in Sydney. We are dealing with people's lives and livelihoods and it should have been handled a lot more sensitively than it was.

Will the Minister heed Mr Beattie's advice and abandon his crude and clumsy approach to this issue, or will he continue to behave, as Mr Beattie described him on the AM program last week, as `a political coward' and, I quote again, `a factional hack from New South Wales'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sometimes one can have a hard week or a difficult day. At times even one's religious faith can begin to ebb. But every now and again something happens to bring it back. There is a sign from God. Something good happens. Today Senator Parer has provided me with an opportunity I have been seeking-indeed, longing for.
—Did you organise a dorothy dixer?

—No, it is not a dorothy dixer. I did not organise it. Occasionally one gets a bit of help from the strangest quarters. I am aware of some comments that a person called Beattie made on radio the other afternoon. I am informed that this person is an official of the Australian Labor Party in Queensland. I am also informed that his views on north Queensland, which he appears to share with a gentleman he visited on a farm recently, are not shared by the Queensland branch of the ALP. In fact, Mr Beattie and others who tried to put up a motion to that effect at the State Council meeting held prior to last Saturday were rolled and a motion supporting my role was carried. That does not surprise me. There is no question that the Labor Party in Queensland is behind the Government on the World Heritage listing. Mr Beattie would not find it surprising to be the odd man out.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the remark made about me that I am a factional hack from New South Wales, I will not run too far away from it. I have been involved in factions in New South Wales for a long time. I find the word `hack' a bit offensive, but I will have to wear it. As to the suggestion that I could be insensitive, I find that appalling. That was the one thing Mr Beattie said that cut me to the quick.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. In view of the Minister's reply and his remarks about Mr Beattie, who, I remind the Minister, is the Secretary of the Queensland Branch of the Australian Labor Party, does he intend to continue to handle the Queensland rainforest issue in the same way as one of his colleagues said that he would handle the problems of the Labor Party in Queensland-by using what he called the `Jonestown solution'?

—I will handle north Queensland with customary dignity and aplomb. I will ensure that great sensitivity is shown to all those who may be affected by the decision. One colleague of mine referred to Mr Beattie's visit to Kingaroy as the worst piece of political judgment since Hess dropped into Scotland. All I can say is that at least he had a parachute on.
—Can the Minister for Justice indicate the result of a meeting of police Ministers held in Hobart recently on the important issue of Aboriginal deaths in custody?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Just under a fortnight ago in Hobart a meeting was held of the Australian Police Ministers Council, which comprises me and the Ministers from the various States and the Northern Territory concerned with police matters, including the very important issue in our community of police-Aboriginal relations. In particular, we were concerned to bring about a situation where, as far as lay within our power, the spate of tragic deaths of Aboriginals in custody might be brought to a halt. At that meeting a very real political will to address this problem was evidenced across all jurisdictions and between all parties, as was the case in the Senate a week ago when it passed a motion in a bipartisan manner in relation to this question. There was evidence of a real willingness on the part of the highest political elected officials of this country to deal with this matter. Whilst we could commend certain practices and procedures to police forces and custodial institutions throughout the Commonwealth, it is one thing for us to pass resolutions, and it is another to have them implemented on the ground in a practical and effective way. The will to implement these practices and processes must be there among the police forces, prison officers and those concerned with dealing with Aboriginals as they come up against the legal and penal systems.

ANSWER.PARA: For that reason, the police Ministers decided not to make a final and definitive statement, but to enter into very urgent but adequate consultations with Aboriginal communities, Aboriginal legal services throughout Australia and other interested parties, including police associations and associations of prison officers, in order to ensure that the final document, which we hope to promulgate next year, is practical and effective. We hope it will bring about a situation in which, first, Aboriginals are diverted away from detention and custody for minor offences-particularly for simple intoxication-and into the care and custody of other Aborigines of standing in their local community; and, secondly, if they are taken into custody, special measures are taken, particularly where there is evidence of some intoxication or some medical condition which might place the person in jeopardy. The question of multi-prisoner cells is something that needs to be looked at and this is something that is not immediately apparent to us as European reformers.

These resolutions need to be implemented in practice and for that reason I was happy yesterday in Sydney to open a conference, a workshop, or a seminar, organised by the Australian Police College which brought together Aboriginal people and police liaison officers from all State jurisdictions and the Northern Territory with a view to having very frank discussions over three or four days in order to come up with practices which can be implemented on the ground in order to ensure the spate of tragic deaths that have occurred does not continue. I said at the time that in the bicentennial year-next year-our practices in this regard will be under intense international scrutiny. Quite apart from that scrutiny, and even if it were not the case, justice requires that we take every step possible to ensure that our fellow Australians do not die in custody if it can be at all averted.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I refer to yesterday's media release from the Minister, Mr Brown, in which he disclosed that Federal Cabinet had agreed in principle to the development of a casino in Canberra and to the Minister's claim in that release that the community would:

QUESTION.PARA: have a full opportunity to examine the proposal and express views on the package . . .

Given the Minister's record to date on community consultation with the people of the Australian Capital Territory (ACT), which has included the abolition of the Joint Standing Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, the abolition of the Australian Capital Territory Schools Authority Council, and the abolition of community health services and hospital boards, among others, what assurance can the Minister give the ACT community that consultations will be genuine and that people will be given an opportunity to respond to the Minister's proposal for a casino? Specifically, what mechanisms will be set up to facilitate community consultation and to see that the views expressed by the Canberra community are acted upon by the Minister?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yesterday the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories, Mr Brown, announced the Government's intentions in this matter and in doing so he stressed that the development would not be rushed through. Indeed, he indicated that there would be a social impact study to identify any particular problems and to take account of them. No doubt Senator Reid and others who have views will be able to put those views to those who are conducting the study.
