Any casino ordinance would include strong control provisions and would be drafted in full consultation with law enforcement authorities.

ANSWER.PARA: The ACT community will have a range of opportunities to express its views on the overall development and on the community facilities which it provides. It should not be forgotten that the casino involves not just a large scale private sector development, but incorporates a hotel complex, restaurants, retail space and other appropriate commercial facilities. It is also designed in such a way as to maximise the value of the site and to ensure that the proceeds that we can get from it will fund a new theatre and a library. They are the sorts of facilities that I would have thought the people of Canberra and the ACT would want. Given the wind-down in construction after the new Parliament House is completed, I think that if the casino can go ahead it will give an excellent fillip to industry in the ACT.

In terms of the abolition of school boards and other boards, it has been explained many times that in the ACT there has been an extraordinary number of boards. One wonders how many citizens were not on at least one or two of them. The spread of the boards and their activities grew over years and years. There came a time-and Minister Brown decided that that time had come-when there was need for some rationalisation. Indeed, those boards were not providing any great extra services. They were providing jobs-often paid jobs, even if they were part time-for too many people. They had long since outlived their usefulness. The reconstruction of ACT boards in a number of areas such as health and education has not created any great community reaction.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it has. You want to have a look at my mail.

—Most of the reactions have been in favour. I recall being told today that somebody had received 200 letters on the casino. That is not what I would call great public reaction. Great public reaction means a lot more than 200 letters, I would tell Senator Reid.
—Like on the monorail and Darling Harbour.

—I have not received any of it, Senator Messner, although a couple of days ago the Australian Democrats called me the Minister for monuments. If I may sum up, there are a number of ways in which the community will express its views. It will have the opportunity to do that and the Government will take those views into account.

—I address my question to the Minister for Finance-although a moment ago I was going to ask for equal time to defend Peter Beattie. Has the Government noted any new signs or any new comments which would indicate the validity of its general thrust of economic policy, and in particular restraint in the fiscal area? If so, what are the comments, signs or indications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Arguably, the most significant signs that the Government is on the right track are to be found in the voices coming from prominent people in the Opposition as to how the Opposition is and was on the wrong track. For example, the honourable member for Boothby, Mr Hall, on 14 July said:

ANSWER.PARA: The architects and strategists of our recent defeat need to transfer responsibility for the result to someone else to survive. That someone else is Premier Petersen.
The facts are that until the opening of the poll at 8 a.m. on Saturday morning our leader had incessantly claimed that the reason we would be elected was our policies.
There is no way that by 10 p.m., on the same day the reason we were not elected, was not the test on those policies.

In the aftermath of electoral defeat last July, some were quick to blame that outcome on Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen . . . Yet I truly believe that such analyses, either at that time or more recently, were as shallow as they were self-serving . . . The more important truth, however, was that, on the basis of the policies which the conservative parties had in place prior to the emergence of that campaign, those parties-including our own-did not deserve to win.
I think we would all endorse that. Then, in the next paragraph, he said:
. . . had the Labor Party lost-the conservative parties would not have been truly ready for government.

Again, I think we would all endorse that. But, if only in a negative way, the fact that prominent members of the Opposition are not only recognising but publicly stating how inadequate were the policies which the Opposition took into the last election-policies to which the Opposition remains committed in that negative way-demonstrates that recognition is growing that the policies being followed by the Government are correct and appropriate.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I remind the Minister of an answer she gave to a question earlier today in which she indicated that completion rates, that is, graduation rates, will be one outcome measure of the performance of universities and colleges of advanced education. I now ask the Minister for an assurance that the Government will not, either explicitly or by implication, be party to any measure which will diminish the pursuit of excellence in institutions of higher education or which might reward institutions in any way for conferring more degrees or diplomas at a lower level of achievement.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Although the paper that I referred to, the Green Paper which has been tabled by Mr Dawkins today, does raise the question of unsatisfactory completion rates, and goes into a discussion mode about some ways that this might be addressed, the Government has not as yet made a determination on any such proposal. The discussion paper, the Green Paper, is just that. It is a paper seeking the views of the education community about how outcomes at the higher education level can be improved. There is no specific proposal.

ANSWER.PARA: Despite that, I am very happy to give an assurance that our Government will institute no policies or new ways of resource allocation to institutions which would result in a lowering of standards. To do so would cut across all the efforts we have made ever since we have been in Government to ensure not only that we have increased participation in higher education but also that the quality of education is improved for all participants in the system. I must say that there is room for improvement. We will be looking at institutions' entrance selection procedures, curriculum content, employment policies and promotional policies and at the whole gamut of things that can affect quality. So, without anticipating in any way the outcome of the discussions which we hope will be very vigorous and lively around the Green Paper, I am happy to assure Senator Baume that we have no interest in any measures which would result in a lowering of standards.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment Services and Youth Affairs. Is the Minister aware of a picket line at the community youth support scheme centres of Elwood and Collingwood in Melbourne, which yesterday were closed without notice? Can the Minister tell the Senate why these projects, and the Gympie project in Queensland, were given no notice of closure? Is it true that the State advisory committee in Victoria which prepared the report on these centres recommended that the Minister not close the centres? Is it true that, although one of the three centres is in the electorate of the Minister responsible, Mr Holding, that Minister has refused repeated requests for a meeting with the centres? Does the Minister agree that the whole matter has been insensitively handled?

—I am in no position to agree with the last part of Senator Powell's question because I have no information about the matter she has raised. I will refer that matter to Mr Holding for a response. I simply say that the whole range of initiatives that our Government has taken and is taking to give unemployed young persons the opportunity to get training, and therefore to secure a place in the labour market, is showing very good results. We certainly can point with pride to increased participation rates at all levels of education, but particularly in years 11 and 12, to disadvantaged areas where the participation rates have increased substantially in the last few years, and to enrolments in technical and further education colleges, which are fairly typical places to which young unemployed persons go to get work force training. So, without being able to comment specifically on the centres referred to in Senator Powell's question-she also referred to one in Queensland-the Senate can have confidence in the measures that the Government is taking to alleviate unemployment by the very constructive method of ensuring that unemployed young people have the opportunity to get work force skills.

—I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to her answer to my question of 21 October regarding the removal of items covering the treatment of certain skin cancers and warts from the medical benefits schedule. The Minister advised the Senate that the treatment of warts, due to technological change, was now much simpler and quicker and performed largely by general practitioners. The Minister advised also that `a separate item to cover the removal of large numbers of difficult warts, anal and genital, is to be considered for inclusion in the schedule'. It is now four months since items covering cervical and anal warts were removed from the schedule. Patients not covered by private health insurance but relying on the oft but wrongly acclaimed Medicare must pay for or join a hospital queue to await treatment for this highly contagious condition which in women has been implicated as a precursor to cervical cancer. Will the Minister advise when a decision is expected regarding the inclusion of papilloma virus in the schedule? The Minister herself has admitted that there is a `large number of difficult warts'. Is there any measure that can be taken in the interim to ensure that patients with this condition-I repeat, a highly contagious condition-can be treated without delay?

—As I think Senator Patterson acknowledged in her question, it is the case that for the treatment and removal of some kinds of warts and skin cancers the technology is now available for general practitioners to carry out those procedures within their surgeries as part of a normal consultation. However, it is the case that medical practitioners have brought to the attention of the Government problems with some of the other conditions mentioned in Senator Patterson's question. I am happy to inform Senator Patterson that officers of the Department of Community Services and Health have, since the deletion of these items from the medical benefits schedule, met with representatives of the medical profession, including surgeons, dermatologists, obstetricians and gynaecologists. The Department is reviewing the special case that has been argued for anal and genital warts to be covered in the benefits schedule, as they usually require hospital admission and removal under anaesthetic. There has been some misunderstanding about the removal from the schedule of procedural items for solar keratoses. The techniques for their removal are similar to those for other keratoses, warts, and so on, and are covered under the appropriate attendance item. Items covering the removal of skin cancer have not been deleted from the schedule. The Government recognises the need for separate procedures to cover these services.

—I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister answer the latter part of my question? Since a number of patients with this highly contagious disease have their names on waiting lists, is there any measure that can be taken in the interim to ensure that patients with this condition can be treated without delay?

—It seems to me that the most appropriate course for those patients is to be treated by their doctors and the question of the level of payment to be resolved later. The implication of Senator Patterson's question is that they cannot get treatment unless the items are included in certain schedules. That is not right. If the doctors are refusing to treat them, Senator Patterson should take up the matter with the colleges concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-In the course of responding to a question during Question Time today, the Minister for Finance made reference to views I expressed last Thursday evening when delivering the Earle Page Memorial Lecture. I am grateful to the Minister for the fact that in the course of doing so he accurately quoted some of the remarks I made during that lecture, thereby providing a lesson to some journalists who did not follow that course. However, notwithstanding the Minister's gracefulness in that regard, in the course of his response he nevertheless misrepresented the passages in question by suggesting that they referred to policies of the coalition parties at the time of the last election when, as the Minister is or should be perfectly well aware since he appears to have read the speech, they referred to the policies of the coalition parties prior to the emergence of the `Joh for Canberra' campaign. I think the Minister will acknowledge that when he refers again to the text of the address.

SPEECH.PARA: However, there is one other matter in respect of which the Minister's remarks misrepresented the position taken in that speech. Again, perhaps this is a misrepresentation that the Minister is not singular in regard to, because indeed it has been common to much of the Press and media comment generally in the past few days. I refer, of course, to the logical non-consequential which the Minister drew in relation to the position or policies of the coalition parties either before the emergence of the `Joh for Canberra' campaign or at the time of the last election in comparison to those of the Australian Labor Party. Of course, there was nothing in my remarks last Thursday night which would in any way suggest that the Opposition parties' policies at that time, on either of those occasions, were in any way inferior to those of the Labor Party. On the contrary, the deficiencies of the Labor Party policies at the time of the last election were of a kind which are, of course, now being clearly brought home to the Australian people.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Senator WALSH

TALK.START.PARA: —On 26 November Senator Chaney asked me a question about people leaving the Commonwealth superannuation scheme and, in particular, the resignation of a specific officer. I have a quite detailed reply to that question, of which he was given a copy a couple of hours ago. I seek leave to have it incorporated in Hansard.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.
The reply read as follows-

On 26 November Senator Chaney asked me a number of questions concerning a change to the interest rate applying to the contributions of persons leaving the Commonwealth Superannuation Scheme. In response, I indicated that I had made a determination that the exit rate would be zero, that I could not be certain what precise period it applied to but that I intended to put out a comprehensive press release the following day.

That press release was in fact issued next day. It is numbered 67/87 and makes it clear that the zero rate applies to contributors leaving the scheme as from 27 November 1987 until the date of the next variation and that it relates only to the period of interest since 1 July 1987. Concurrently with the promulgation of this new exit rate, an ``annual'' rate of 22.676% covering the year ended 30 June 1987 was declared. These two rates replaced the single rate of 22.973% which had applied to those leaving the Scheme as from 21 September, 1987, and which covered the interest period commencing on 1 July, 1986.

Senator Chaney also asked me whether a senior officer of the Commonwealth Superannuation Fund Board (actually the Australian Government Retirement Benefits Office-``AGRBO'') who had just recently retired had received privileged treatment or had gained from inside information. The answer I have obtained from the Commissioner for Superannuation to both aspects is ``no''.
The Commissioner has provided me with the following background information:-

``The officer to whom the questions raised by Senator Chaney and Mr Tuckey on 26 November relate appears to be one of the Section Heads (Class 11 Clerical/Administrative officer) in the Superannuation and DFRDB Administration Branch of AGRBO who retired officially on 25 November at age 59 years after over 40 years service for the Commonwealth and 39 years membership of the Scheme. That officer, who had for some time been planning to retire in March next year on his 60th birthday, informed me orally in late October that he was concerned at the likely effect of the share market crash on his retirement benefits package. He had noted SFIT's acknowledgment in the Press that the Fund had suffered losses in the order of some hundreds of millions of dollars and felt it prudent to plan on the basis that sooner or later the ``exit'' rate would suffer a drastic reduction. He indicated that he would be weighing carefully the financial implications of serving until he could gain the benefit of-
Commonwealth Superannuation Fund
His maximum additional pension entitlement (for 40 years contributory service) accruing in February, 1988;
The higher pension accruing on his 60th birthday in March, 1988; and
The impending second tier pay increase which would also affect his annual rate of pension and the payment in lieu of his considerable furlough credit,
as against the probable large loss of interest on his accumulated superannuation contributions in the Fund.

He later wrote to me on 16 November notifying his likely retirement on 25 November, the end of that fortnightly pay period. He confirmed that advice on 24 November when he formally submitted his retirement decision. He has of course, had the right to set his own retirement date at any time since he reached 55 years of age.

It seems clear to me that this officer certainly had made up his mind to retire earlier than his 60th birthday on the basis of generally available, published information. In fact, at the time he gave me advance notice in writing of his proposed retirement date, it is my belief that the Department of Finance had not yet approached you with proposals for an interest rate change.

Clearly, at least the more senior officers in AGRBO would all possess a more intimate and detailed knowledge of the exit rate arrangement and the influences on it than would many outsiders. This is to be expected given their day to day responsibilities, just as those in other agencies would be more au fait with their systems eg. social security benefits, taxation provisions. However, from reports I have had of telephone calls received by my Office over the weeks since the Share Market crash, many contributors contemplating retirement or resignation were weighing up similar considerations to those exercising the mind of this particular officer, and I would not be surprised if many of them left the Scheme prior to the interest rate change on the basis of their general knowledge of the Scheme and their judgment that the current high interest rate was unlikely to last much longer and would be more beneficial to them than the emerging situation, including the impending pay increase.

In summary, this Officer certainly did not receive any privileged treatment and I am satisfied that his decision to retire earlier than his 60th birthday was prompted by his prudent planning on the basis of publicly available information rather than any ``insider'' knowledge.''

DEBATE.TITLE: ELIMINATION OF INTERMEDIATE RANGE NUCLEAR WEAPONS

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that I have received the following letter, dated 9 December, from Senator Teague:

INTERJECT.PARA: Dear Mr President,
Pursuant to Standing Order 64, I give notice that today I propose to move-
`That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Senate to acknowledge the importance of the agreement being made today between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate their intermediate range nuclear weapons because:
(1) NATO's resolve over the past decade to deter Soviet SS-20 missile deployments in Europe has been the effective foundation for the agreement;

(2) the agreement should be viewed as a first important step towards the early achievement of a 50 per cent cut in strategic weapons, cuts in conventional forces, a complete ban on chemical weapons and a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons;
(3) the agreement demonstrates that the only sound basis for achieving nuclear arms reductions is that disarmament proposals be multilateral and verifiable; and
(4) there is a need to maintain effective deterrence and a strong Western alliance.'
Yours sincerely,
BADEN TEAGUE
Senator for the State of South Australia
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Senate to acknowledge the importance of the agreement being made today between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate their intermediate range nuclear weapons because:
(1) NATO's resolve over the past decade to deter Soviet SS-20 missile deployments in Europe has been the effective foundation for the agreement;

(2) the agreement should be viewed as a first important step towards the early achievement of a 50 per cent cut in strategic weapons, cuts in conventional forces, a complete ban on chemical weapons and a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons;
(3) the agreement demonstrates that the only sound basis for achieving nuclear arms reductions is that disarmament proposals be multilateral and verifiable; and
(4) there is a need to maintain effective deterrence and a strong Western alliance.

I congratulate the United States and the Soviet Union on the Intermediate-range Nuclear Forces Treaty signed in Washington today by President Reagan and the Soviet leader, Mr Gorbachev. I am confident that all senators from all parties in this chamber welcome the Treaty, as it heralds the fact that the super-powers' nuclear arsenals will be reduced for the first time since World War II. This is the first real disarmament decision by the United States and the Soviet Union. Other very important preceding treaties, including the Strategic Arms Limitation Talks, SALT I and SALT II, the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty of 1972, and even the earlier Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, were only about arms control. This Treaty is about actual reductions; it is about disarmament. Today's Treaty in Washington is a real disarmament agreement. It will eliminate 4 per cent-a small but important start-of the US and Union of Soviet Socialist Republics (USSR) arsenals of nuclear weapons. This 4 per cent involves the elimination of all US and Soviet intermediate nuclear weapons, that is, missiles with a range of from 500 kilometres to 5,000 kilometres. The intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty announced today is an important first step in the disarmament agenda.

I am not confident that all senators understand the essential foundation on which this agreement has been based. The Opposition parties and the Government understand, but I despair that the Australian Democrats and the Nuclear Disarmament Party senators-a small minority in this chamber-do not. The Opposition parties and the Government recognise that today's agreement is based on a policy of peace through strength, that the deployment by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) of a deterrent to the Soviet SS20s, which were deployed a little more than 10 years ago, has been an essential foundation for the now mutual withdrawal that the INF treaty will achieve; that is, mutual withdrawal both by the Soviet Union and Warsaw Pact forces on the one hand and by NATO on the other. I believe Opposition members and the Government recognise that any effective nuclear arms reduction requires that disarmament proposals be multilateral, not unilateral, and that they be verifiable. The world's continuing security requires the maintenance of an effective deterrent and a strong Western alliance. Accordingly, on behalf of the Opposition parties I have wanted to highlight these four points that we in this chamber need to recognise today as the foundation for this important treaty, so I have couched my motion in these terms:
The need for the Senate to acknowledge the importance of the agreement being made today between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate their intermediate range nuclear weapons because:
(1) NATO's resolve over the past decade to deter Soviet SS-20 missile deployments in Europe has been the effective foundation for the agreement;

(2) the agreement should be viewed as a first important step towards the early achievement of a 50 per cent cut in strategic weapons, cuts in conventional forces, a complete ban on chemical weapons and a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons;
(3) the agreement demonstrates that the only sound basis for achieving nuclear arms reductions is that disarmament proposals be multilateral and verifiable, and
(4) there is a need to maintain effective deterrence and a strong Western alliance.

Honourable senators will recall that this week's meeting in Washington is the third summit meeting. In November 1985 President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev met in Geneva. I am sure honourable senators will still recall the fireside chat they had. One of the important consequences of that meeting was their agreement:

A nuclear war cannot be won and must never be fought . . . We undertake to work for a 50 per cent reduction in our offensive nuclear weapons systems as a step towards the objective of a complete elimination of nuclear weapons.

The Geneva summit meeting not only set that as the most substantial of the objectives yet to be achieved-and I look forward to that being achieved on the same basis, with the same realism and with the same strength as the foundation for today's agreement-but also there was reference in Geneva to a chemical weapons ban and, most importantly, to the actual achievement of intermediate forces being withdrawn, especially from Europe but ideally throughout the world. It is that part of the Geneva goal that we have seen completed in this treaty at the third summit meeting.

The second summit was held in Reykjavik, Iceland, in October 1986. A more precise set of proposals for disarmament was discussed, but a major stumbling block of disagreement about strategic defence led that summit to be fruitless. However, in the 12 months since that time, notably by 19 September this year, foreign secretaries George Shultz and Eduard Shevardnadze agreed that an INF treaty in principle could be achieved and would be prepared for signing by the summit meeting today.

This agreement is great news for Europe and great news for that part of the world which, for the last 15 years, has been threatened most directly by massive SS20 missiles deployed in the Soviet Union west of the Urals. These massive SS20 nuclear missiles, now amounting to 441 on the Soviet side, are aimed at all of the major capitals of Western Europe. They directly threaten the peoples of Scandinavia, the United Kingdom, the Low Countries, France, West Germany, Italy, Portugal and Spain, and, indeed, they threaten neighbouring countries in the Mediterranean, and, through other deployments in Asia, China, Japan and other Asian countries.

When the Soviet Union deployed these weapons it was riding a large wave of aspiration to show the world that it could be the strongest defending nation. During the 1970s, at the same time as the 1972 SALT I agreement and the 1979 SALT II agreement, which was so disappointing because of the duplicity of the Soviet Union at that time, were being negotiated, there was a massive increase not only in the number of weapons and warheads but also in the megatonnage available to the Soviet Union. It was at that time, during the 1970s, that these new powerful weapons were deployed and aimed at Europe. The response by the NATO forces in western Europe was decided in 1979. They believed that the only response available to Europe was to deploy similar weapons which would act as a deterrent against the SS20s ever being used, which would, of course, have meant Europe's destruction. With an enormous amount of publicity, because of the minority peace dissenters and protesters at Greenham Common in the United Kingdom and the greens generally throughout Europe, cruise missiles and Pershing II missiles were deployed by the United States, with the full approval of NATO and with the agreement of the United Kingdom, West Germany, Belgium, the Netherlands and Italy, all of which were receiving these missiles.

NATO and the European nations made a dual track decision. They also put forward to the Soviet Union that the deployment of the deterrent would not proceed if the Soviet Union withdrew the SS20s, which was the initial offence. However, despite careful negotiations through to 1983, when the first of the Pershing and cruise missiles were deployed, there was no ground given by the Soviet Union in its overly strong deployment stance. As a result, cruise and Pershing missiles were deployed in 1983, 1984, 1985, 1986 and 1987. Indeed, they have still not been completely deployed. All the time the United States and NATO held forth an olive branch to the Soviet Union and engaged in active talks in respect of the INF treaty that would see intermediate range weapons withdrawn not only from Europe but from all other areas. Most thankfully, the agreement that has been signed by President Reagan and leader Gorbachev today ban both super-powers from maintaining arsenals of intermediate range weapons in all parts of the world.

Let me concentrate for one minute more on the question of NATO's response to the SS20 deployment. In the last month the Australian Democrats have put to the Senate the claim that today's agreement is the result of the peaceniks, the dissenting demonstrators, putting forth their views in Europe. They claim that today's agreement is the result of the peace movement, so called. I totally reject that. I believe that it is only on the basis of strength that we have seen this mutual withdrawal of these weapons. There would not have been this agreement if there had not been the NATO response that I described. The surest way to achieve disarmament around the world and to save the world from a nuclear conflict is to ensure that there is a deterrent. We must ensure that there is strength in the Western response and, of course, that involves Australia in a close alliance with the United States. It is because of the strength of that response on the part of NATO and the Western alliance that the agreement was signed today.

It should be noted that the SS20 is a solid fuel mobile missile with a range of almost 5,000 kilometres. It has three multiple re-entry vehicles, each with a 150-kiloton warhead. These offensive weapons are 10 times as powerful as the bomb that was dropped on Hiroshima more than 40 years ago. More than 1,000 warheads can independently be targeted all over Europe. These are the weapons that are now to be withdrawn and that is why we applaud the agreement that has been negotiated today.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are not trying to get in on President Reagan's popularity, are you?

—I believe that we should in the Senate congratulate both President Reagan of the United States and General Secretary Gorbachev of the Soviet Union on the agreement that was reached today. There was good faith on both sides. I should say, as the convenor in this Parliament House of a disarmament forum in September last year which was attended by representatives of the five nuclear nations and many parliamentarians, and which Senator Button has also been gracious enough to recognise as a useful activity during the International Year of Peace, that all of the nations displayed good faith in respect of the objectives of the agreement that has been achieved today.

SPEECH.PARA: It was proposed only a year ago at the Reykjavik meeting that 100 intermediate warheads be retained by the Soviet Union in Asia and that 100 warheads be retained by the United States, presumably in Alaska. I think all Australians greatly opposed this proposal because, whilst it would have seen the elimination, happily, of these weapons in Europe, they would have been retained in Asia to the extent that I outlined. We should recognise that the agreement that was signed today reflects the position that was put by the Australians, the Chinese, the Japanese and the people of the other countries of Asia who were threatened by that 100-100 retention. What we have achieved is a zero-zero outcome for all intermediate range weapons.

One of the most important new achievements that have made this possible is the verification procedure. As the Senate knows, verification means checking on cheating. It is the ability of one super-power to make sure that the other one does not try to break arms agreements secretly. Verification means satisfying oneself that the other side sticks to its word and complies with its solemn treaty obligations.

The verification requirements in the treaty signed today are not only the major part in the 100-page treaty and in the 100 pages of appendices attached, but also recognise that there is a new ability to verify the terms of the treaty. This is a very real breakthrough. Had there not been a desire by both sides to achieve verification, this treaty would not have been signed today. The Russian's chief INF negotiator has been General Vladimir Medvedev. He has said:

As a technical specialist I am first and foremost concerned with the technical problems involved in verification, but of course it does have a political aspect. Verification ensures the maintaining and fulfilment of important political agreements.

He has clearly acknowledged verification requirements to be substantial and practical. For the first time we have seen common ground as to verification procedures between the two super-powers. One of the reasons for this breakthrough is the recent development of a satellite, as big as the double-decker so-called `peace bus' that was parked at the front of Parliament House last Monday, with the potential to take the super-powers into a new age of trust. Four of these satellites will be put into space very soon and there will be no hiding place left. The KH12 will be able to achieve remarkable verification standards. It will be able to see through clouds using what is called synthetic aperture radar. It will be able to see at night using special night sight imaging devices. It will have a picture resolution to within three inches when in low orbit. Once the four KH12s are in orbit, as planned, earthbound intelligence analysts will be able to receive an instantaneous close-up picture of any spot on the planet within 20 minutes of asking for it. Perhaps most significantly, the KH12 will have an unlimited lifespan and will be serviced and maintained by engineers travelling on the space shuttle to keep its eyes and ears unblocked and its brain constantly alert.

The pragmatic negotiators in Geneva have a saying: `Verification cannot make a bad treaty good, but it can make a good treaty enforceable'. This is what we are observing for the first time. I draw to the attention of the Senate the fact that I, as one signatory last year to the parliamentary report on disarmament and arms control, drew particular attention, on pages 704 and 705, to the importance of verification. In the United States, public opinion polls this week show that 63 per cent of the public wholeheartedly endorse the INF treaty signed today. Why then do the other 37 per cent dissent? Why are they not convinced? The overwhelming reason given by that 37 per cent is that they are not sure that the verification procedures will be adequate. It is an important matter. A real breakthrough has made this treaty possible.

The real goals for disarmament, for making the world safer, are to maintain deterrence; to maintain a stable counter-balance between the nuclear powers, in which Australia plays an important part; and, with that deterrence in place, to go on to achieve a 50 per cent reduction in strategic nuclear weapons-that is, intercontinental nuclear weapons and not just in the small percentage of intermediate weapons-and a reduction in conventional forces in Europe, in chemical weapons and in nuclear testing. We have a long agenda to achieve. This is a very important first step.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator ROBERT RAY
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Home Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been outlined by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) during Question Time earlier today, the Government and the Australian Labor Party wholeheartedly welcome the decision of the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate entirely their intermediate range and shorter range nuclear forces. In most people's minds, this agreement will rightly be seen as the most significant step forward in nuclear disarmament achieved so far. Accordingly, I have no difficulty in associating with the general sentiment of Senator Teague's motion, although the Government might not emphasise some of the points highlighted in the motion. I suppose the salutary point from an Australian perspective of this treaty between the United States of America and the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics is that we, Australia, have been, more or less, bystanders-vocal in putting our views forward, certainly, but really just observers from the sideline. I hope that the success and promise offered by this treaty provide some food for thought for those in Australia who proclaim their devotion to the cause of nuclear disarmament, and for those who claim to wear their principles on their sleeve.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government believes that the treaty signed today will provide a model for future negotiations between the super-powers. It demonstrates a new and welcome maturity amongst the political leaders of the United States and the Soviet Union, a preparedness to strive for a worthy legacy to history rather than accept the preconceptions of their respective political constituencies. More fundamentally, it shows that the way to concrete progress in disarmament is for the United States and Soviets to be willing to talk to each other.

Emotional rhetoric for the benefit of political constituencies here in Australia is not, and can never be, a substitute for the long, slow need for super-power negotiations. The Intermediate Range Nuclear Forces (INF) treaty is not something whipped up over a weekend, at a rally or a consciousness-raising group. It is 170 pages of closely-argued provisions, and it has taken some six years to achieve. I cannot recall any Palm Sunday or Hiroshima Day marches over that period which contributed to this painful process of negotiation. I wonder whether the senators for nuclear disarmament will be organising rallies of concerned citizens to celebrate and congratulate the architects of the INF Treaty--

TALK.START.PARA: —We did today, outside.

—Senator Wood has very graciously indicated that they have. I congratulate them for doing so. In particular, although we may regard President Reagan as not being successful in every policy aspect, the role of the President of the United States in this case deserves great credit. The INF Treaty is a better version of the `zero option' President Reagan first put forward in 1981 for the withdrawal of INF weapons from continental Europe. What has been achieved in not just a withdrawal, rather, the elimination of an entire class of weapon: about 850 United States missiles and 1,900 Soviet missiles-all the land-based Pershing and cruise missiles installed by the United States for the security of western Europe, and all the land-based SS4s, 12s, 20s, 22s, and 23s deployed by the Soviet Union in Europe and Asia.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Teague emphasises the role played by the resolve of North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) forces in encouraging the Soviet Union to talk. There may be some truth in that assertion, but at the same time we should recognise that there has been a great deal of uncertainty and negotiations. The elimination of intermediate and shorter range weapons from Europe places far greater emphasis on the need for NATO to maintain conventional deterrence. As we know here, national defence budgets are always subject to active debate, and the next few years of adjustment may be painful for some western European NATO members. France is determined to maintain its own nuclear capabilities, with controversial implications for our own region.

The Government has no disagreement with the United States encouraging its allies to build up their own conventional capacity. This same attitude is pursued in our own defence arrangements under the provisions of the ANZUS alliance and other treaties. This goal of self-reliance, which has been supported by successive United States administrations, has, however, provoked wild criticism from `loony league' conservatives in western Europe, in the United States and here in Australia. The entirely natural and sensible view of the United States that allies should shoulder their fair share of responsibility is seen by some critics as `betrayal' or `treachery'. Perhaps the most significant comment of President Reagan in the lead-up to the treaty was his response to his conservative critics. He said:
Some of the people who are objecting the most, basically, down in their deepest thoughts, have accepted that war is inevitable.

That is a sad reflection on the current mental state of some conservative thinkers in the West. It indicates an attitude of moral cowardice which I hope would never find voice in this chamber. The entire motivation of the Australian Labor Party and the Government, affirmed by our national conference, is based on the conviction that war can and must be prevented. No matter what difficulties or obstacles are encountered, such a commitment is essential.

In negotiating the INF treaty the Soviet Union has proved to be a hard bargainer. On many occasions progress stalled over the Soviets insistence on linking strategic defence initiative (SDI) research to discussions about existing weapon deployments. To the credit of the General Secretary of the Communist Party of the Soviet Union, that preoccupation has now been dropped. Both nations acknowledge their work on SDI and hopefully that frankness will provide a basis for specific discussions in that area. That is how it should be. The motion looks forward to progress in other areas such as possible cuts in strategic nuclear weapons and nuclear testing. All are vitally important areas and the Government is confident that achievements will come on these issues. But progress will take time. Each issue in disarmament is intricate and complex-the defence and foreign policy arrangements of the US and the Soviet Union and their myriad of allies cannot and should not be changed overnight. We do not want the illusion of peace at the price of instability.

Although there has been much tragic conflict over the past 40 years, during which our region of South East Asia has suffered more than most, we are still lucky to live in an era free of world war. This is not an occasion for banal praise of the United States or banal criticism of the Soviet Union. The United States knows that Australia is a reliable ally bounded by cultural, social and philosophical sympathies. The Soviet Union knows that Australia is, as was epitomised by the Prime Minister's recent visit there, a constructive but reasonable critic of many aspects of its society. In particular the Australian Labor Party, as part of the international democratic socialist community, has good reason to be hostile about elements of past Soviet behaviour.

Because the Government is aware of this history of international relations, it remains firmly convinced that Australia has a role to play in strengthening what is known as the Western alliance. But our awareness of past sins has not hindered our contribution to realising future potential for disarmament. The Hawke Government, with Bill Hayden as Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, has done more, and has been recognised overseas as having done more, on this central issue of world stability than any Australian Government since that of Ben Chifley and Dr Evatt at the time of the founding of the United Nations 40 years ago. I do not intend to list the initiatives of this Government in the area of disarmament. Those who are genuinely concerned will already be aware that the Hawke Government places meaningful action ahead of empty rhetoric.

To sum up, the Government congratulates the United States and the Soviets on today's agreement and commits itself to doing everything in its capacity to encourage further concrete negotiations between the super-powers, both globally and specifically in our own region. The signing of the INF treaty is vivid justification of our policies aimed at identifying specific proposals for hard negotiation. Hard work over many years will always be the answer, not emotional clap-trap. I do not often quote Sir Winston Churchill but at least he was right when he said, `More jaw-jaw means less war-war'.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats do, of course, support the motion as stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Senate to acknowledge the importance of the agreement being made today between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate their intermediate range nuclear weapons . . .
We do not agree with the rest of the motion and I shall tell honourable senators why. The motion goes on to list reasons for the importance of the agreement and the first of these is:
NATO's resolve over the past decade to deter Soviet SS-20 missile deployments in Europe has been the effective foundation for the agreement;

What rubbish! War is not peace. The foundation for this agreement is the fact that people around the world are saying to their politicians: `Enough is enough; we are sick and tired of your threatening us with nuclear war'. The people are taking the matter out of the hands of politicians. They have taken to the streets again and again over a number of years. They have campaigned at Greenham Common, at Pine Gap, in the United States and in Europe. The people are finally being heard. They are sick and tired of being exposed to the posturing and sabre rattling of the politicians who would say that war is peace. These people have taken matters into their own hands and have made their leaders, in the Soviet Union and in the United States, listen to reason, and that reason is demonstrated by the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement-the reduction of nuclear weapons. This is a first step and in some ways it is not even a very big step, as I shall point out later. Nevertheless it is an important first step. The second reason listed in the motion is:

the agreement should be viewed as a first important step towards the early achievement of a 50 per cent cut in strategic weapons, cuts in conventional forces, a complete ban on chemical weapons and a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons;
We can and do agree with that. The third reason is:
the agreement demonstrates that the only sound basis for achieving nuclear arms reductions is that disarmament proposals be multilateral and verifiable,

Again, we cannot agree with that. We cannot agree with this idea that multilateral disarmament is the only possible way. We do not agree with it because history shows that when one side in any conflict starts to de-escalate, the other side follows. John F. Kennedy showed this in the early 1960s. He unilaterally stopped nuclear testing in the atmosphere and this led to a partial test ban treaty. Unilateral cuts do work. The unilateral concession has been made by the Soviet Union-500 SS20 warheads will be removed from Asia and the US is not removing any warheads from that area, even though it has many on ships in the area. At this point the US is not removing those weapons, but perhaps it will. The Soviets are willing to take a punt, to take a chance to preserve peace.

Let us talk about the Soviets. I do not think it is very hard to understand why the Soviets want peace. I have been to the Soviet Union and I have seen the monuments to the fallen. I have seen what has happened as a result of World War II when 20 million Soviet citizens lost their lives. We have been so fortunate in Australia and I, too, was fortunate in America because my home was never bombed. I was never exposed to such things. Certainly during the wars we sent people off to fight, but our homes were never bombed and our children were never killed in their beds. This happened to the Soviet people so they know and understand it. They want peace; they want it sincerely-as much, if not more than the American people.

TALK.START.PARA: —Stick to the environment!

—Senator Richardson tells me to stick to the environment. Does he not believe in peace? Does he not believe the Soviet citizens suffered in World War II? I do not believe for a minute that he does not recognise that. The point is that unilateral disarmament works. Part of the rhetoric that we get from the far Right, the ultra conservatives, is that we must continue to arm ourselves in order to obtain peace. That is absolutely wrong thinking. The fourth reason listed in the motion is:

SPEECH.PARA: there is a need to maintain effective deterrence and a strong Western alliance.

This flies in the face of the second item listed in the motion, which mentions cuts in conventional forces. I wonder if Senator Teague, who proposed this motion, realises this. I see that he is now in the chair and thus finds himself somewhat constrained by his position. Nevertheless, I wonder whether he really thought this through. I am certainly in favour of a reduction in conventional arms.

Incidentally, there seems to be a fallacy amongst the right wing members of the world community that somehow the Soviets have a massive conventional force advantage in Europe. This is simply not the case. It is a matter of arithmetic. The parliamentary delegation to the European institutions had contact with the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) headquarters in Brussels and we discussed this very issue. It turns out that if one includes, as one must, the forces of France and Spain in NATO-because they would come to the aid of NATO if the Soviets attacked, though I do not believe for one second that they ever would-there would not be parity between the two sides; NATO would have a slight advantage. We found in NATO headquarters a great abhorrence of the INF treaty. We got this from two people. We had briefings from Merrill Walters, the NATO Director of Nuclear Planning, and from Colonel G. R. Akam, who is in the US Army. Both said, `Nuclear deterrence is essential to keeping the peace in Europe. We believe that it allows a flexible response to take place, and that includes limited and winnable nuclear war'. That is what the people in NATO headquarters think. That is not what the people of Europe or anywhere else in the world think. We have to look closely at what the military planners are saying. They are living in a never never, fantasy land of winnable nuclear wars. That is one of the main reasons that people have taken peace out of the hands of the military and those who say that peace comes from rearmament or massive armament.

Let us come to the subject of verification. Senator Teague brought up the subject of the KH12 satellite. Certainly, it is a very sophisticated satellite, but it is not essential to the role of INF treaty verification. The breakthrough in the INF treaty is on-site verification. This is what is so exciting about the treaty. For the first time, both super-powers are saying, `Okay, we will get over our paranoia. We will allow people to come on site and not only see that we are complying with the treaty but oversee the destruction of the warheads'. Senator Teague nods his head in affirmation. This is a remarkable achievement. It is a milestone. I hope that we have turned the corner on disarmament. Unfortunately, our Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) does not seem to understand this point.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not surprising.
—`That is not surprising', says Senator Puplick.
—You have an ally there.
—Yes, I have an ally occasionally in Senator Puplick. He is an astute man, but sometimes his politics gets in the way of his intelligence.
—So does his Party.

—And his Party. Earlier today Mr Hawke claimed that the United States bases in Australia will play a key role in verifying the INF treaty. Once again, he displays the fact that he does not know what the bases in Australia do. The KH12 and other polar-orbiting satellites simply have no role in Australia. The United States bases in Australia do not monitor those satellites. They are polar-orbiting; they pass over the United States; they can be keyed to disgorge their information over the United States or its own territories; and they are not tracked by Pine Gap, Nurrungar and certainly not by North West Cape, which is not a satellite-tracking facility anyway, or any of the other facilities in Australia. As I said earlier, the verification will be on site. In fact, the verification role of the bases has often been used as an excuse for having them here. Now it turns out that under the INF treaty the verification will be on site: human eyes on the ground, human feet walking into areas to see exactly what is going on. If the Government keeps maintaining that the main value of the bases is for verification and the verification is now being done on site, I am afraid that it has just put the last nail in the coffin of the justification for the bases on Australian soil.

SPEECH.PARA: We have heard a number of things about the peace movement. The peace movement is active in Australia, as it is everywhere else. It does not really mind how this treaty came about. It is unfortunate, however, that members of this chamber refuse to give the movement any credit. The supporting mechanism for nuclear war is the availability of uranium. I hope that this Government will take a look at its policies on shipments of uranium to France. France is outside the INF treaty. France is building nuclear weapons apace, and the French nuclear weapons are being built in some cases using Australian uranium. I advise Senator Richardson, who I know is a stalwart in his Party, if he is indeed a man of peace as he would claim, to take a hard look at the shipment of uranium to France.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who is going to pay for World Heritage if you stop uranium?

—We have a paper on Kakadu coming up, and I shall explain that point a little later. One point that worries me about the INF treaty is that it is for land based missiles. I am sure that Senator Vallentine will go into this matter in more detail because she is very concerned about the Missouri battle group, which is in Western Australia at this very moment, equipped with Tomahawk missiles. The United States maritime strategy involves a number of nuclear strike capabilities, including guided missiles and human guided aircraft; and there is a strategy for sending missiles and aircraft from United States units into Central Europe in time of war. Now that the INF agreement has been signed, it is imperative that we look at the problems of the maritime weapons, many of which are in the north-west Pacific. We have a huge build-up in the north-west Pacific, and if Australia really wants to contribute to world peace, since this is our ocean-we inhabit the borders of it-Australia should get involved perhaps in calling a conference on disarmament of maritime weapons in the Pacific. Perhaps we could actually contribute. Everybody has been ignoring this factor. Because of population pressures, I suppose, the super-powers look at Europe. Perhaps we could play a role in the Pacific by calling for nuclear disarmament in this area.

SPEECH.PARA: Once again, I welcome the INF treaty. It is a first step in the elimination of nuclear weapons and of nuclear war. We still have a very long way to go. There are still thousands and thousands of nuclear weapons in the arsenals of the world. We still have to involve France and Britain in these discussions. Certainly, the two super-powers are talking to each other. I think that it is a very good sign, and I think that this is the best Christmas present the world could have-a reduction in nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crichton-Browne Sen N.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in favour of the urgency motion moved by my colleague Senator Teague, which I shall take a moment to repeat to the Senate:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:
The need for the Senate to acknowledge the importance of the agreement being made today between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate their intermediate range nuclear weapons because:
(1) NATO's resolve over the past decade to deter Soviet SS-20 missile deployments in Europe has been the effective foundation for the agreement;

(2) the agreement should be viewed as a first important step towards the early achievement of a 50 per cent cut in strategic weapons, cuts in conventional forces, a complete ban on chemical weapons and a comprehensive ban on the testing of nuclear weapons;
(3) the agreement demonstrates that the only sound basis for achieving nuclear arms reductions is that disarmament proposals be multilateral and verifiable, and
(4) there is a need to maintain effective deterrence and a strong Western alliance.

I commend the wording of the motion. One obvious and indisputable fact which has been demonstrated by this agreement, and which we can only hope will not be lost sight of by the unilateralist and the anti-United States of America peace groups, is that agreements such as this must be multilateral and verifiable if they are to be effective. The strength and virtues of this agreement are exactly that.

Let it also be understood by these groups that agreements such as the intermediate-range nuclear force agreement can and will take place only through deterrence and equality of threat. Disarmament will take place only by bilateral or multilateral and equal disarmament-certainly not, and never, by unilateral action as called for by some groups within the community and by some senators in this chamber. I remind the Senate of the words of the Soviets themselves:
We strictly abide by the principle of equal security, because some or other military advantages can only provoke the other side into additional arming and sharper military rivalry.

The great lesson to be learned from negotiating processes such as this agreement is that, if it were not for the nuclear capacity and the strength of the bargaining position of the United States of America, the terms of this agreement would not be as they are; this agreement would not be consummated; and it would not be a reality. It is what can be described as peace through strength-or, as the Liberal Party of Australia likes to phrase it, peace through security. This agreement once and for all demonstrates the absurdity and the danger of calls for unilateral disarmament and the destabilising of the United States' capacity and Australia's role in ensuring that strength and that security by its commitments and the agreements it enters into.

When reflecting upon events which have led to this agreement, it is perhaps worth recalling how America's strength has contributed to the terms of the agreement and to the fact that we now have such an agreement. Of course, we recall that in early 1977 the Soviets began the deployment of SS20 intermediate range nuclear missiles in the European part of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics. That, of course, exposed countries of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) to the vulnerability of a surprise nuclear attack. These powerful SS20s replaced older weapons. It is not without significance that two-thirds of the total number of SS20s were located west of the Ural mountains and at most were within 20 minutes flying time of West Germany and were capable of targeting any European city.

At that time no US intermediate range missiles were deployed. Then, of course, NATO introduced a dual track strategy to counter such deployment, the first part of that tracking being to seek to negotiate with the Soviets for the removal of those weapons. The Soviets continued to engage those weapons and, because of the very significant advantage it gave them over the NATO countries, the United States, together with the NATO forces, deployed the Pershing II and cruise missiles in 1979.

During 1981 and until 1983 the United States continued to seek from the Soviet Union negotiations on the intermediate range missiles. However, the Soviets, with the very significant advantage they had by virtue of their SS20s, refused to co-operate under any circumstances. It was only after the introduction and installation of the Pershings and the cruises that the Soviets walked away from the negotiating table because they knew that they could no longer prevent the Pershings from being installed. Of course, the Pershings created very great concern for the Soviets. The Pershing II particularly is a highly accurate missile with a 5-50 kiloton warhead and the Soviets claim that it has an ability to strike any target in the west of the Soviet Union with only four minutes warning. Of course, the deployment of the Pershings caused enormous difficulties for Moscow because it required them to take one of two courses. It required them to involve themselves in political negotiations, which they had so far refused to do, or to involve themselves in strategic defence, causing them to spend a great deal of money because the Pershing was capable of knocking out their command centres. That made the Soviets very nervous and very vulnerable.

TALK.START.PARA: —They were already involved in SDI.

—That is right. The Soviets were already involved in the strategic defence initiative (SDI). It ought not to be forgotten what great opposition there was at that time from the various peace groups within the NATO countries to the introduction of the Pershings and the cruises. The protests and the demonstrations are legendary. Who can forget the peace groups at Greenham Common, half of them funded with Soviet money, demonstrations to prevent the installation of the Pershings and the cruises?

SPEECH.PARA: However, let us ask ourselves now: What has been the effect of the installation of these weapons by NATO and by the United States? In 1985, shortly after his election-or selection-General Secretary Gorbachev was forced to return to the negotiating table with one vital item on the agenda-the removal of the Pershings and the cruises. The results of those negotiations, caused by the installation of the Pershings, can be seen today. They provided the allies with a powerful bargaining chip and allowed the allies to bargain from a position of strength. The installation of the Pershings has been responsible for the removal of all short and intermediate range land-based weapons from this planet. Had they not been deployed, the Soviets would not have bargained and there would be no agreement from Moscow today. We would still be in the situation where the Soviets, with their SS20s, would have a significant advantage over western Europe, and world stability would be at risk.

Let us not forget the other benefits that President Reagan was able to bring to this agreement through the strength of his bargaining chip. He was able to insist on and achieve the zero-zero option in his agreement. He was able to demand the uncoupling of the SDI negotiations from the intermediate nuclear forces (INF) agreement. He was able to persuade the Soviets to exclude the British and the French nuclear deterrence capability from consideration within the agreement. He was able, for the very first time, to insist on the Soviets allowing ground verification. I ask honourable senators: What more tangible examples do we need to demonstrate peace through strength and action?

The significance of the verification procedures should not be underestimated. They were referred to by you, Mr Acting Deputy President. They usher in a major breakthrough in arms agreements. The significance of the verification terms of the agreement is not that they guarantee there will be no future violations-no doubt there will be-but that they at least demonstrate that it is possible to have a verifiable agreement in the first place. Perhaps equally importantly, the agreement represents a dramatic change in the Soviets' attitude towards verification. It provides for the first time for on-site inspections. In fact, the Soviets had originally agreed to a level of on-site verification greater than that which the United States is presently requesting. I guess that in many respects it can properly be argued that those levels of demand for verification became redundant upon the terms of the agreement being reduced to zero-zero as distinct from maintaining 100 warheads each at the time. It is my view that the verification proposals contained within the agreement do not include unlimited on-site inspections and therefore are not adequate to guarantee certainty of compliance, because the United States does not know the number of SS20s that the Soviets have in storage. In fact, as I recall, Gorbachev recently owned up to having a greater number of SS20s than that which the Americans suggested they had.

However, the central point is that the Soviets have now committed themselves to future verifiable agreements. This must create a belief that we can expect in the future arms control agreements which will be not only of political significance, as I suspect this agreement will ultimately prove to be, but, hopefully, of very real military significance. Without verifiable agreements, there can never be deep and meaningful cuts in nuclear weapons because the deeper the cuts, the greater the vulnerability of each side. Neither nation will expose itself to vulnerability or anything less than mutually assured destruction unless it is able to verify the mutuality of the vulnerability. Such verification is impossible without on-site inspections, something which until this agreement the Soviets had not been prepared to countenance.

The military significance of this agreement, as distinct from its political significance, should not be overstated. It is the first sign that the two major nuclear powers are prepared by multilateral action to begin to dismantle the awesome nuclear stockpiles which they both possess. The relevance of this agreement is not only that it is a first step in building down-the number of nuclear weapons in the world will for the first time be reduced-but also that the tensions between the super-powers have been considerably reduced. As one might say, the temperature in relationships has been reduced and the threshold of conflict has been raised.

The greatest threat to the world today is not the number of nuclear weapons possessed by either side. That became almost irrelevant the moment that the number of weapons required to destroy this planet was available. That number has been well passed. The greatest threat, in my view, is the nuclear threshold-the coming together of events which will cause a nuclear war. This INF agreement has demonstrated the first tentative signs that both sides are committed to a denial, to taking tangible and positive steps to ensure that such a war does not take place.

The significance of this treaty is that it breaks the logjam. It creates a momentum. It eliminates, for the first time, a complete class of nuclear weapons. It demonstrates, whatever the motive, the desire of both sides to move towards significantly reducing the risk of nuclear war. It demonstrates a sense of good will and genuine desire which encourages both sides to move forward with a greater sense of assurance and trust.

It needs to be clearly understood, and it should not be forgotten in the hype and excitement of the current treaty negotiations, that neither this agreement nor any other agreement will change the dichotomy between East and West. It will not inhibit or retard the expansionist ambitions of the Soviet Union. The fundamental differences between the East and the West, between the super-powers, are not changed or influenced by arms control agreements. The very reason that East and West are in conflict and are natural enemies has not been changed in any way by this agreement.

The Soviets' closed, authoritarian community, governed by a hierarchy or echelon of unelected dictators ruling over a subjugated and oppressed society is as true today as it has always been. Arms controls do not have the capacity to forge a real and lasting peace; they simply provide the mechanism for reducing the risk of total destruction of the globe. In my view, the best prospects for a lasting peace will come from the establishment of a free and open democratic society within the Soviet Union. We ought not forget that there has not been a war between democracies since World War I. It is fair to say that we can look forward with optimism and confidence to this agreement setting the ground rules. It will create an environment in which the two major nuclear parties will be able to come together in further pursuit of a reduction in nuclear weapons.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —In the short time I have been a member of the Senate I have already spoken on a similar issue to that dealt with in this urgency motion, namely, nuclear disarmament. Like everybody else in Australia and the world today, including all political parties, I am pleased about the momentous decisions reached between the Soviet Union and the United States of America in the signing of the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement. As has been said by all other senators who have participated in the debate, this is the first time since nuclear weapons came as a plague upon the earth that there will actually be a reduction in the number of nuclear weapons through their destruction. Admittedly, that will affect only about 4 per cent of those already held, but at least it is a very good beginning.

SPEECH.PARA: Most people would find agreeable the motion moved by Senator Teague. As Senator Ray said, certainly honourable senators on the Government side agree with it. However, we disagree with some of its emphasis. Perhaps paragraph (1) and paragraph (4) are in a way a little self-serving. I suggest that much of the motion could have been drafted by a Deputy Secretary of the Politburo in the Kremlin. With some suitable changes in the wording, it would be carried with alacrity and acclamation by the comrades of the Central Committee. For example, I think they would change paragraph (1) to read:
The Warsaw Pact's resolve over the past decade to deter NATO's deployment of Pershing and Cruise missiles has been the effective foundation for the agreement;
I suggest also that the comrades in the Kremlin would delete paragraph (4) and replace it with a paragraph in these terms:
There is a need to maintain effective deterrence and a strong Warsaw Pact alliance.

In a sense at present those on both sides of this debate in the world-those from the West and those from the communist bloc-are congratulating themselves that it was their determination not to give in before the other side that has led to the breakthrough and so on. As far as I have been able to ascertain over the years, when one side says that the other side has escalated in one area, that side asserts that the other side did it the year before, and so on. One can never quite find out accurately where the escalation started, except in respect of when nuclear weapons were first being produced in the late 1940s. Ever since then both sides have accused the other of escalation. The great achievement of the INF agreement is that that cycle of criticism of the other side has been broken. Both sides should take credit for finally, for whatever reason, agreeing to stop the madness of accusing the other of always being the evil side, the side not to be trusted.

In supporting this motion on behalf of the Government, I point out that the Government's role in nuclear disarmament over the past 4 1/2 years has been excellent. In some ways I do not like to be critical of the Opposition. After all, it brought forward this motion. But it must admit that when it was in government in Australia for something like 30 of the past 40 years it did nothing that is equivalent to that which the present Federal Labor Government has been doing in support of nuclear disarmament. I am not trying to be gratuitous in making that criticism, but the Liberal-National parties in government always relied overwhelmingly on what the Americans were doing to form the basis for their position. The Federal Labor Government is to be congratulated on its independent role, which often was in conflict with that of the Americans in a number of areas, in raising the issue of nuclear disarmament not just in this country but in the world.

The use of the word `deterrence' in the motion is very important. Though there may be moral quibbles about the use of deterrence as a way of keeping peace, in the absence of anything else over the past 40 years there can be no doubt that the policy called MAD-mutually assured destruction to both sides-kept some equilibrium and kept the fingers off the world self-destruction button. Though many people in a moral sense can be critical of deterrence as a policy for keeping peace, in effect it was the only practical thing that worked. The difference between the Government and the Opposition is that we do not see deterrence as the ultimate end in itself. Deterrence is the practical thing that is working now, but it must be replaced by the abolition of all nuclear weapons and, after that occurs, by appropriate treaties, co-operation and understanding between the various countries of the world so that the adoption of what I think everyone would agree is the immoral position of using deterrence and fear to create peace is replaced by a positive attitude of co-operation and openness to achieve peace in the world.

Australia has played a very important part in both deterrence and verification by its role with respect to the joint facilities. I do not deny that in my Party there has been a consistent and ongoing debate about whether the joint facilities should be eliminated from Australia, whether we should adopt a unilateralist position and a neutralist position. I point out that every time that matter has been debated in the top forums of the Party it has always been defeated by an overwhelming margin. The Australian Labor Party has always been in favour of its involvement in the so-called Western alliance. As I have said previously in debates, we are naturally aligned with those countries that have a democratic tradition and the cultural traditions that go with democracy, openness and pluralism. That is the position of the Australian Labor Party, and it always has been since the Party was founded in 1891. We are part of the Western alliance. We accept that role and that responsibility.

We accept also that we must play a role in deterrence and verification. The joint facilities help in the deterrent and verification process. I hope that with the abolition of all nuclear weapons-both super-power leaders have said that that is their bottom line, that that is what they hope to achieve by the end of the century or by the mid-1990s-although obviously there will no longer be a role for deterrence, there will still be a role for verification. I think the Australian people will be willing to continue to provide facilities, such as the joint facilities, to help in the verification process. There can be no ongoing peace or stability between the super-powers if one side believes that the other side is trying to get away with something that is hidden or if they are not open about what is going on in each country. I think the verification process is very important.

Also, whereas I may be critical of the Opposition parties' uncritical reliance on the American position, I am also very critical of the Australian Democrats and the nuclear disarmament senators for adopting a neutralist and unilateralist position. That just will not work in terms of reducing nuclear weapons. The agreement reached between the two super-powers today indicates that multilateral talks are the way to go, not unilateral developments. Unilateralism would mean effectively that there would be no reduction in nuclear weapons in the world.

I want to mention three areas where the Australian Government in the last 4 1/2 years has played a major role in the world as a middle power. First of all, I cite our efforts to achieve a comprehensive test ban treaty. People should be aware that the last time this matter was voted on in the United Nations, in the form of a resolution from Australia and New Zealand, something like 140 countries supported it. Great credit has been brought to our country through the initiatives we have made in the United Nations to support a comprehensive test ban treaty. Unfortunately, at times we have made these efforts against opposition from both the Soviet Union, in its own way, and from the United States.

The second area where the Australian Government has been very active concerns the need for the abolition of the use of chemical weapons. It is quite clear that, with the abolition of the major arsenals of nuclear weapons, we also have to get rid of and ban the possibility of chemical warfare, because if chemical warfare were allowed to be used in any conflict in the world the result would be almost as horrendous as the result of the use of nuclear weapons. We have already seen dreadful scenes of chemical warfare being used in the Iraq-Iran conflict. This is activity of a very minor scale compared with what is possible with the arsenal of chemical weapons held in the world today. Again, I think the Australian Government is to be congratulated on its fine role in encouraging a treaty to abolish chemical weapons.

The third and final area I want to mention concerning the role of the Australian Government is the appointment of our Ambassador for Peace. I know that many cynics agreed amongst them selves that the Australian Government's establishment in 1983-84 of the position of Ambassador for Peace based in Geneva was a cynical public relations gesture. I believe much of that criticism is now muted. People see that Richard Butler has been directly involved in support for the comprehensive test ban treaty.
