But, more importantly in some ways, he has been back in this country speaking to community groups on the need for disarmament and the need for peace. I believe that is a very important Government initiative.

In all these discussions about the reduction of nuclear weapons, one matter cannot be ignored; that is: What will the minor nuclear powers do with their nuclear weapons? The treaty that has been agreed between the Soviet Union and the United States is excellent, but one cannot ignore the fact that countries such as China, Britain, France, India, Pakistan, Israel and South Africa either have nuclear weapons or have the potential to make them. In the coming years each of those countries will have to accept the responsibility of being involved in multilateral discussions for nuclear disarmament. We cannot allow those countries to be outside those discussions for nuclear disarmament. Of course, we are also particularly keen to see the French stop nuclear testing in our own region.

In conclusion, I would like to place on record my belief that congratulations should go to the Government. I have great pride in the fact that I am a member of a Labor government that has used Australia's position as a middle sized power in the world to make a significant contribution to raising the debate on nuclear disarmament in this country and to contribute in the forums of the world we have been recognised as significant by many countries in the United Nations in the debates about nuclear disarmament. I believe that that is an excellent achievement of the Hawke Labor Government which will stand on the record for all time. Again, as I mentioned earlier, I do not believe that the other political parties-the Opposition parties, the Australian Democrats and the Nuclear Disarmament Party-have contributed as much as the Australian Labor Party has contributed in government to nuclear disarmament.

I look forward to seeing further developments over the next 12 months on the nuclear disarmament front, and I hope that by the middle of next year the super-powers realise their next hoped-for achievement of a 50 per cent reduction in the strategic nuclear weapons that they both hold. Overall, I think the motion is to be commended. Although I have differences of opinion and emphasis, I think it very appropriate that today the Senate carry this sort of resolution.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Boswell Sen R.L.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the urgency motion put before the Senate by my colleague Senator Teague. Today is indeed a significant day. The two super-powers of this world have come together for the first time actually to move to get rid of or destroy 800 intermediate range nuclear weapons. I believe congratulations are in order, and I extend them on behalf of this Parliament to both the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics and the United States of America. Hopefully, this will be the first step to defuse the arms race between the super-powers. Let us hope that the lesser nuclear powers of China, France and the United Kingdom will ultimately become part of a unilateral move towards disarmament throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: I am a member of the all-party parliamentary disarmament group, and I welcome these moves which will de-escalate the arms race. My Party, the National Party of Australia, along with all the parties represented in the Senate, acknowledges that the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty that removes nuclear missiles from Asia and the Continent will go a long way to achieving that de-escalation. We congratulate the people who are signing that treaty today.

It is appropriate today to examine how and why this treaty between the two super-powers has come about because, if we want to achieve further successes in this area, we must study the success of the past. Let me say that I do not believe that it was achieved by the posturing of the Australian Democrats with their oversimplification of the situation-their view that all nations should ban nuclear weapons, ergo it will happen; that is, that it will happen because they said it would. Neither was it achieved by Senator Vallentine standing up every broadcast day and frightening Australians who listen to Parliament by stating that sailors in the United States Navy will afflict Australian men and women with all sorts of sexually transmitted diseases, such as syphilis, acquired immune deficiency syndrome (AIDS) and others. I think that is just an oversimplification of the argument.

Senator Vallentine argues selectively. She insists that the Navy personnel must be kept out of Australia and by that subterfuge she would deny American ships berthing facilities in the Indian Ocean. I really believe that this reduces the disarmament debate to a really infantile level. It causes the disarmament argument great harm. Whilst Senator Vallentine and Senator Wood spend most of their time in Canberra concentrating on nuclear issues-that is, the time they have between being gaoled, getting fined and paddling under the front of nuclear armed vessels that are coming into Australia-they are very rarely in the chamber when the Senate is debating major issues of importance to this nation. They do come into the Senate on occasions such as this and make some contributions, but I do not believe they have ever understood or come to grips with the realities of how and why these two super-powers have today removed 800 missiles from their joint arsenals.

I believe a statement accusing Americans of spreading sexually transmitted diseases is a terrible insult to our allies. Senator Vallentine should take the opportunity today to apologise on behalf of the Australian people. Today of all days, Senator Vallentine could not resist another crack at the Americans at Question Time when she asked a loaded question of a Government Minister. I would have thought today, in the spirit of goodwill and co-operation this Senate is extending to the two super-powers, would be one day when Senator Vallentine could have congratulated both the super-powers.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wonder where she has been during the debate up to now?
—I will leave that to speculation. I do not believe Senator Vallentine will apologise to our allies, so I will take the opportunity to put the record straight.
—Apologise on her behalf.

—I do not feel I should apologise on her behalf. She would be woman enough to do it herself. Let us examine some of the facts. The US Department of Defense requires all applicants for military service, as well as all individuals who are already in the military, to be tested for AIDS. Personnel deployed overseas in US Navy ships, and other military personnel en route to permanent overseas duty, are tested prior to deployment. If any are found to be AIDS positive they remain in America. If any already serving abroad test positive they are returned to the US immediately. I believe Senator Vallentine has picked up some Soviet propaganda that initially came out when an American ship visited Mauritius last October. The Soviet Embassy in Mauritius released a statement implying that the US military was responsible for the spread of AIDS. That was also broadcast on radio.
—Senator Vallentine went to America.

—I cannot be diverted to speak about Senator Vallentine. Today I want to put my Party's position on the signing of this treaty. Australia's contribution towards this momentous achievement should be applauded. Without the support of Australia and other Western allies this treaty could never have been signed. In terms of military capability we are only a very small power but I believe our co-operation and support was necessary for the implementation of this treaty between the two super-powers. If Australia had withdrawn its support and weakened the united front put up the Western alliance, that might have put the Soviets in a far stronger bargaining position over a divided and vulnerable alliance. The co-operation has also worked to our advantage. I believe initially the Soviets wanted to retain 100 of their 127 INF missiles in Asia, which would have seriously threatened Japan and other nations of the South Pacific region, including, I suppose, even Papua New Guinea. I believe our mutual interests were served, and the missiles were removed from Asia. That is very good from our point of view.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not believe this treaty could have been signed without our joint United States-Australian facilities. From time to time they have come under a lot of attack and abuse. It is important to realise that these facilities played an integral role in the signing of this landmark treaty which eliminates a whole range of nuclear weapons. It is trendy to be in the peace groups and to be arrested for picketing places such as Pine Gap and Nurrungar, but it is a tragic irony that the antics of these people only end up delaying the nuclear disarmament process. Nurrungar and Pine Gap have made a direct contribution towards the negotiating of this treaty. We have the facilities to ensure that the verification regime of the treaty, which is the strictest and most detailed in history is complied with. After all, if the Western alliance does not know how many missiles are being deployed by the Soviets, how will it be able to determine how many will be dismantled and destroyed? How could we, in that situation, ever begin to negotiate these types of treaties? The stringent and clearly defined obligations of this verification regime are the best means of ensuring that the treaty provisions are not violated. They foster greater confidence in the agreement, which will mean greater stability and security in Europe and Asia.

The other function of these centres is to contribute to the deterrence effort by providing early warning assistance. Therefore, Australia's contribution today-this memorable day-should be highlighted as part of a united Western effort to provide joint facilities for verification and deterrence. Without those facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar I do not believe we would have seen these two men sitting down today in Washington signing this treaty.

I believe, too, it is important to acknowledge the role of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) in the signing of this treaty. If it was not for NATO's vigorous and united response to the destabilising Soviet deployment of SS20s in Europe, today's achievement would have been impossible. Since World War II NATO countries have courageously rejected the fairy-tale world of the peace groups and the Democrats, to face the reality of the super-power struggle. At this stage I welcome Senator Vallentine to the Senate.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate is almost over.

—The debate is nearly over but Senator Vallentine has come in in the past three minutes. Since 1977 the SS20 missile force has grown, with no countervailing US missiles being deployed in Europe. The NATO strategy of nuclear deterrence and flexible response that has kept peace in Europe for the past 40 years was seriously threatened.

SPEECH.PARA: Unfortunately time is limited but in the short time I have left to close my contribution, I point out that it must be clearly understood that the two men representing the two super-powers would not have been sitting down in Washington and signing this treaty to reduce intermediate-range nuclear forces had there been no verification and deterrence. There are no fairies in the bottom of the garden. It is unfortunate but the fear of one nation by the other has kept the world at peace for 40 years. Without the two components of verification and deterrence the disarmament treaty could never have been initiated and signed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beahan Sen M.E. .

TALK.START.PARA: —Of course, along with other speakers, I agree with the general thrust of Senator Teague's motion concerning the intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) treaty. It is appropriate that the Senate should acknowledge the importance of this historic agreement. It is appropriate and correct to note that the treaty is a reflection of the success of the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) and of broader Western alliance approaches to arms control. It is correct and appropriate to say that this should be seen as a first step in many more such arms control agreements. It is appropriate and correct to suggest that the basis for such agreements should always be a multilateral approach and should also be based on the principle of verifiability.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth noting, and it has not been noted by other speakers so far, that Australia, along with Japan, was particularly prominent in calling for the agreement not to be limited to Europe but also to cover missiles in Asia. With all of this, and with all of those points that I concede in Senator Teague's motion, it should also be conceded-and it has not been so far by anyone in the Opposition-that the success of the treaty is at least equally the result of changes in the Soviet Union. Only three years ago, I remind honourable senators opposite, the Soviets refused to talk about intermediate-range nuclear forces. Changes in the Soviet's position, particularly on questions of verification, reductions to zero and non-linkage with other areas of arms control, have made this agreement possible. This is consistent with the Soviet Union's proclaimed policy of trusting its security to a sufficiency of weapons rather than to a preponderance of weapons. That is an important shift in emphasis which I, along with other members of my Party, welcome.

While NATO and the Western approach-in particular, the approach that has been adopted since the deployment of the SS20s, the dual track approach that has been used by Western nations-are vindicated in the signing of this agreement, the changing attitude of the Soviet Union should also be recognised, and it is preposterous nonsense not to look at both sides of this very complex international equation. I believe that this highlights the quaintly outmoded attitudes of the Opposition in international affairs. It seems to be caught in a sort of cold war time warp. It is still in the 1960s. It is not quite up to date and it has found it very hard to pull itself out of a mind set which was perhaps appropriate in the 1950s but which certainly has nothing to do with the realities of the 1980s. The comments made by Senator Hill and Senator Hamer in this chamber, and by John Howard, Ian Sinclair and Mr Downer in the other chamber, seem to indicate, as I have said, that the Opposition has not moved at all since the 1960s.

While we support the motion itself, we do not support the rhetoric that accompanies the motion or the rhetoric that has accompanied the support of the agreement. The Opposition seems to prefer the simplistic approach of black and white, of goodies and baddies. The world was much simpler when we could operate that way. It is much more complex now that we have to deal with nuances of change which are hard to understand and which we have to work hard to understand. Opposition members do not want to tackle that sort of thing. They are still following the old cowboys and Indians approach to international relations. They might be described as international cowboys. They take the unrealistic view that unless all Western demands of the Soviet Union are totally met, we should not accept that any changes are occurring at all. This is, of course, utter nonsense. Agreements do not occur that way. This one would not have occurred that way, and it would not have occurred if other conservative nations such as the United Kingdom and the United States of America, and their conservative leaderships, had not taken a much different stand from the stand that has consistently been taken by the Opposition in this place. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) I think summed it up very well in the address that he gave to the House just yesterday, when he said:
Australians have paid a very high price indeed for the predilection of the conservative parties in this country to project their domestic political preoccupations on to the screen of foreign policy.

One need only recall the tragedy of the Australian involvement in the Vietnam War to recall both the myopia with which the then Liberal-Country Party Government viewed our region, and its determination to derive and advance domestic political gains from the region, which it failed, or refused, to comprehend.

My point is that the Opposition simply has not changed since those times. It is still in that 1960s time warp. But there is no doubt about the changes. The changes are occurring. Apart from the specific changes that I have referred to already in the Soviet Union's attitudes towards specific aspects of arms control, other changes and reforms are occurring within the Soviet Union which have a fundamental importance in setting the scene for more specific changes in the international sphere. Changes represented in the twin themes of glasnost and perestroika, for example, have created an atmosphere of greater trust and confidence.

I was fortunate enough to be in the Soviet Union early in November as a representative of the Australian Labor Party. As its National Vice-President I was invited, and our Party accepted the invitation for the first time, to participate in the jubilee celebrations for the seventieth anniversary of the Revolution. At that gathering I attended a two-day meeting of the Supreme Soviet and heard Mikhail Gorbachev give his long but very substantial speech. I met him very briefly afterwards. I did not get quite as much time as either Mrs Thatcher or Bob Hawke, but I did set the scene, of course, and make it easier for Bob Hawke's visit later on! But I was given the opportunity of addressing a round table discussion of guest parties which included communist and social democratic parties from around the world. This round table discussion was chaired by Mikhail Gorbachev for the whole of the two-day session, and I was privileged to speak at it. I would like to quote a brief passage from the speech. Although it was not a totally uncritical speech, I was making what I believe to be an important point about the question of trust and confidence and about the importance of the sorts of reforms that are occurring. I said:

We see the development of greater confidence and trust between the countries of East and West as a precondition for further gains in the most important matter for us all, the question of arms control. There is a need to overcome tensions arising from perceived threats both military and non-military, to each other's security and social political systems. Trust, of course, depends largely upon how we view each other and what we believe to be each other's motives and goals.

We therefore welcome moves to facilitate a less encumbered flow of information between the peoples of the East and the West. Glasnost and perestroika are domestically important for the Soviet Union, but they are internationally important as contributors to increased thrust and a consequent reduction in tensions.

There is no doubt, as I have said, that changes are occurring. I was able to speak to a wide range of people. Whilst there are impediments to that change, and whilst the Yeltsin affair is, I suppose, a symbol of some of the difficulties in the process of change, there was no doubt to me at the time; there was no doubt in my discussions with academics, with the media and with ordinary people in the street-we had interpreters with us the whole time-that there is a momentum for change which is simply not going to be easily diverted. As I have said, that is important in setting the scene for the more specific change that has been occurring in this INF agreement.

This is not to say that we accept uncritically everything that is happening in the Soviet Union and everything that the Soviet Union does now or has stood for in the past. As I have said, our acceptance of the invitation to attend the seventieth anniversary jubilee celebrations was our first acceptance of such an invitation. We had been invited many times before but we had not accepted. Unlike the Opposition, we take the view that changes such as those that are currently occurring in the Soviet Union must be encouraged.

TALK.START.PARA: —Why do you say contrary to us?

—We should not put impediments in the way and we should not use the rhetoric of the 1960s when talking about the 1980s, as Senator Crichton-Browne has just proved he is so good at doing. As I said, this is not to say that we accept uncritically everything that the Soviets do. In my speech I made two fundamental criticisms of their system. In other speeches that I gave in other situations I drew attention to others. I indicated, for example, that it would be an appropriate symbolic gesture if the Soviets withdrew their troops from Afghanistan. I indicated that compliance with the Helsinki Final Act on human rights was also a fundamental pre-condition, as seen from the Western perspective, to any further changes that we might expect in international arms control fora. The difference between us and the Opposition, the difference between that sort of line-a critical line that accepts and welcomes the fundamental changes that are occurring within the Soviet Union-is that we are concerned to encourage the development of reform in the Soviet Union. It is true that we are prepared to criticise the Soviets, but we are wanting to draw them out and to say, `What you are doing is fine. We know that you cannot do it all in one hit and we are not going to make it impossible for you to make contact with us while you are making these reforms'. On the other hand, the Opposition seems intent on creating divisions, on building barriers to any of the genuine changes that are being attempted currently within the Soviet Union.

SPEECH.PARA: I, along with other speakers on the Government side, support the motion, which is a fundamentally sound one, even though we would not support at all some of the rhetoric which has accompanied it. I agree with Senator Schacht that the wording of the motion also is to some extent self-serving. Nevertheless, we cannot fundamentally disagree with the general positions that are taken by it, and will therefore support it. I simply make the plea to the Opposition that in this, of all areas, there is a need for a bipartisan approach. We are not talking simply about relations between the Soviet Union and Australia or the Soviet Union and the West; we are talking about the future of the world.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vallentine Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —While this week is an historic occasion as we celebrate the first agreement between the nuclear super-powers that involves the actual destruction of nuclear weapons, I regret this urgency motion which is a blatant attempt to artificially--(Quorum formed) As I was saying, I think it is a shame that this debate has had to be brought on because I believe that the urgency motion is a blatant attempt to polarise artificially the disarmament debate by scoring political points, instead of using the occasion to discuss how we can extend the European intermediate-range nuclear forces (INF) agreement to the Pacific. In fact I am curious to know why this motion was necessary at all because if it was self-evident that peace through strength had triumphed there would really be no need for it. I suspect that it was because of the Opposition's insecurity that the peace through strength proponents, who feed off each other's mutual hostility in the Cold War capitals, felt it necessary to introduce this urgency motion today while the peace movement simply indicated its approval of the INF agreement with picnics and celebrations like the one outside Parliament House at lunchtime today.

SPEECH.PARA: I also regret the decision of the Government to allow 32 or more sea launched cruise missiles into Fremantle this week at the very time that the United States of America will be starting to dismantle them in Europe. At least three of the ships coming in with the Missouri battle group are known to be carrying Tomahawk sea launched cruise missiles-the Missouri, the Bunker Hill and the Leftwich. There is a great danger that in the joy over the agreement in Europe we shall ignore the increasing escalation of the nuclear arms race at sea, particularly in the Pacific Ocean. I should also remind honourable senators that as far as the United States and Soviet navies are concerned their Pacific command covers the Indian Ocean as well as the Pacific.

Considering Senator Teague's motion, I would ask him whether he has ever read Tom Gervasi's book, The Myth of Soviet Military Supremacy, which is available here in the Parliamentary Library. If not, I commend it to him and other senators. Tom Gervasi is a man who believes in a strong defence for the United States and, like Senator Teague, he is no pacifist. In his book he points out that the deployment of cruise and Pershing 2 after the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) decision in December 1979, was nothing to do with the deployment of Soviet SS20s in the Soviet Union. When the West German Chancellor Helmut Schmidt made his celebrated speech in 1977, he did not mention the SS20s. He simply expressed his concern that SALT 2 negotiations then in progress would neglect the components of NATO's deterrence strategy because they dealt only with the nuclear strategic weapons of the super-powers and did not take into account the disparities between East and West in nuclear tactical and conventional weapons.

At no point in his address had Chancellor Schmidt defined the nature of the disparity in arms between East and West, nor did he suggest that the SS20 was its cause, nor did he even mentioned the SS20 at all. If he thought that the SS20 posed a new kind of threat, he did not say so. If he thought that this threat required a new response, he did not prescribe one, nor did he imply that it ought to be an American one. In fact he told Newsweek that he would find it difficult, given the German psyche, to tell the Germans that they need to add missiles to the 6,000 American nuclear warheads stationed in West Germany already. In fact, NATO had indicated no concern when the Soviets began deployment of the SS20 in 1977, accepting it as force modernisation and replacing the SS4s and SS5s which were already 20 years old. The decision to deploy the Pershing 2 in Europe was made in 1971, six years before Chancellor Schmidt's speech in London. As for the cruise missiles, they were a superb example of what Sir Solly Zuckermann, the British Government's chief scientific adviser for over 20 years, referred to as the technological imperative. They were weapons already made and looking for a home. It is also interesting to note that the Reagan Administration had to set up a special cabinet-level interagency group to find a justification for deploying these weapons in Europe. Authorised by National Security Memorandum 77, its special planning team was established to develop a public relations strategy to sell the deployment of Pershing 2 and cruise missiles in Europe. United States Defense Secretary Caspar Weinberger privately offered officials the advice that:
We've got to make them think that what we're doing is good for them. Not just that, but we've got to make them think that they're going to like it, and that it's what they've been asking us to do.

What Senator Teague has got to realise is that the deployment of cruise and Pershing 2 was nothing to do with the deployment of the Soviet SS20 missiles and that if there is any credit for the decision to withdraw them, it should go primarily to the independent and non-aligned peace groups in east and west Europe which have, since 1980, demanded `No cruise, no SS20s'. They have been very even-handed in their criticism. While I agree with much of what Senator Teague suggests in the second paragraph of his motion, I would add the need to work for disarming the seas in order to stop the escalation of the nuclear arms race in the Pacific. In the last few years we have seen the Soviet deployment of new delta class submarines in the Sea of Okhotsk, testing of the SS-NX-21 and SS-N-24 sea launched cruise missiles, further construction of typhoon submarines, although none have as yet been deployed in the Pacific, development of the former United States naval facility at Cam Ranh Bay since 1979, and construction of their first proper aircraft carrier in the Black Sea. The United States has now deployed eight Trident submarines in the Pacific and in a few years after they are armed with the D5 sea launched ballistic missiles, they will have a first strike capability. As the Pentagon has proudly boasted, the Trident submarine is the most destructive weapon in history. Each one has 24 missiles with eight warheads, a total of 192,200 kiloton of warheads, which, I remind honourable senators, is 16 times larger than the bomb dropped on Hiroshima in 1945. This is a measure of how far the arms race has advanced in 42 years.

Besides the deployment of Tridents since 1982, the Reagan Administration has started deployment of 4,000 Tomahawk sea launched cruise missiles since 1984, of which 758 are nuclear armed. The cruise missile is a dangerously destabilising weapon because it is impossible to include in any verification agreement and the Soviets cannot know the difference between a conventionally armed Tomahawk and a nuclear armed one. The increase in the size of the United States Navy, pushed through under former Naval Secretary John Lehman, includes new nuclear powered aircraft carriers and battleships like the Missouri, which arrives in Fremantle today and which will be visiting Sydney over Christmas with its 32 Tomahawk sea launched cruise missiles on board. It seems an inappropriate way for us to celebrate the birthday of the prince of peace-I am talking about Jesus Christ-on Christmas Day by having the Missouri battle fleet in Sydney, the nuclear powered Long Reach in Hobart and other nuclear armed ships in Brisbane. Last year we had the Carl Vinson in Fremantle. All of this goes to prove what former Lieutenant-Commander Michael Lynch of the Royal Australian Navy has said, which is that the visits of these warships have nothing to do with the strategic needs of the United States Navy, but merely serve its rest and recreation needs so-called, a polite euphemism to describe the activities of several thousand young American sailors and their physical appetites after they have been at sea for a long time.

I would also like Senator Teague to explain how he can reconcile his call for a comprehensive test ban treaty with his adherence to the Western alliance, given that the only reason the world cannot have a comprehensive test ban is that our major ally, and the head of the alliance, simply does not want one. I hope that on some future occasion he will explain to the Senate the reasons for this intransigence on the part of the United States. If this agreement proves anything, it is that continued pressure by the people of the world for disarmament, instead of a continued arms race, has now paid off and that the new leadership in the Soviet Union and an apparent change of heart by Ronald Reagan have now meant a return to dialogue after the deadlock of the early part of this decade during the days of Brezhnev and Ronald Reagan mark 1. It is this change of heart, rather than Senator Teague's obsession-peace through strength-that has made the INF agreement this week possible.

Obviously, I agree that disarmament measures must be multilateral and verifiable. I have never advocated anything else. Members of the Opposition, and today I heard a member of the Government, talk about unilateralism. They seem to misunderstand the difference between unilateral initiatives towards peace, that is, one side making a first gesture, and a call for unilateral disarmament. The two are very different indeed. I support multilateral disarmament.

I would also like to stress the dangers of talking about deterrence for 42 years as if somehow the nuclear arms race has never changed. The most alarming developments in recent years have been possible because of technology leading to both the United States and the Soviet Union accusing each other of developing a first strike capability. It is nonsense to talk about deterrence having kept the peace for 40 years. Deterrence is the only so-called defence system known to humanity which has to fail only once to be rendered totally useless.

For peace through the strength of nuclear deterrence to be effective for even 99.9 per cent of the time is not good enough. Lord Louis Mountbatten said very clearly in his famous Strasbourg speech in 1979 that nuclear weapons serve no military purpose whatsoever. They cannot be used. They do not constitute a defence system. The statement that nuclear weapons have kept the peace since 1945 ignores the 130 small wars which have taken place since then and in which 20 million people have died, including the 40 or so wars raging right now. So we are told that there has been no world war since nuclear weapons were first used in a war situation. In itself that is true, but it does not prove that we would have had a major war in the absence of nuclear weapons. The point is that no other way of peacekeeping has been seriously attempted. We have succumbed to the temptation to find a false security in these deadly weapons, instigating in the process a reign of terror which has affected our young people in a very negative way.

Also, there is no guarantee that, because people argue that nuclear weapons have prevented a major war, they will continue to do so indefinitely into the future. To say that shows an abysmal lack of knowledge of the increasing sophistication of nuclear weapons systems, which allows less and less time for errors to be corrected. So let us hope that this agreement signed today will give some hope to our young people, that they will see that the peoples' voice does count. It is important that we acknowledge the efforts of peace groups, east and west, and that we continue to put peaceful pressure on the super-powers to continue this process of real disarmament at sea as well as on land.

For the benefit of Senator Boswell, I must inform the Senate that today I sent telegrams to both the Soviet and United States ambassadors congratulating them on this historic statement. However, I cannot support this urgency motion as it stands because of Senator Teague's wording of sections (1) and (4). I hope that my position is not misunderstood. I welcome the signing of the disarmament treaty today as a very historic first step in the process towards real disarmament.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I join this debate because I am surprised and disappointed that members of the Government and Senator Vallentine have decided that it is an opportunity to win cheap political points rather than to commend Senator Teague on the terms of his motion and the importance of the debate he has brought to the chamber today. Senator Teague's motion states that the following is a matter of urgency:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Senate to acknowledge the importance of the agreement being made today between the United States and the Soviet Union to eliminate their intermediate range nuclear weapons . . .

He goes on to set out the reasons why we should do so. I would have thought that that was beyond dispute and that both Government senators and Senator Vallentine would have welcomed the opportunity to get up and say that they support and commend Senator Teague for bringing this matter to the attention of the Senate. Instead, regrettably, Senator Schacht saw the debate as an opportunity to claim all credit for his political party, in other words, taking a purely political party line, to try to gain some benefit from what is a benefit for the whole of mankind. Senator Beahan then took a shot at me, Senator Hamer and others, accusing us of having indulged in Cold War rhetoric in the past, which is quite unfair. I can suggest only that he go back and read Hansard. He will find the invalidity of the statements he made. Then we had Senator Vallentine, in such a disappointing way, indicating that she would not vote for this motion.

In the few minutes I have in this debate-I may expand my remarks later in the adjournment debate-I wish to remind the Senate that my Party and the National Party of Australia, the Opposition parties, were very active in seeking mutual and verifiable reductions when we were last in government. I remind the Senate that there were times, particularly in the work the Fraser Government was doing towards a comprehensive test ban treaty, when we incurred the wrath of our ally and friend the United States, which was concerned with the leadership role that we, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party, were taking in the international fora on that subject. Yet if one believed what one heard in this debate today from Government senators, one would think we were not playing any such role at all. What we were not doing, and what this Government has been doing, in the domestic political situation of Australia, was making a loud noise about what we were seeking to do.

When I went to the Second United Nations Special Session on Disarmament in 1982 I was the only member of this Parliament to go to that special session. We expected an Australian Labor Party member to be there, but apparently he did not turn up. Many an American expressed concern about the independent position that the Liberal Party was taking in this particularly important area. I bring that to the attention of this Government. I remind the Government that in that forum and others it was Australians who were out there leading the committees, who were contributing in Geneva at the Committee on Disarmament, who were providing seismic experts to try to develop a system of verification-as we have been doing in all the intervening years-and who were sending chemical experts, chemists, to Geneva to work on the proposed chemical weapons treaty. They were doing so in those days under the authority and on the instructions of the then coalition Government. To come into this chamber, as both Senator Schacht and Senator Beahan have today, and almost suggest that this Labor Government invented the subjects of disarmament and peace when it came to office is totally misleading.

I remind honourable senators that for years we on this side of the chamber have been advocating restraints of both vertical and horizontal proliferation. I remind honourable senators of the work that the Fraser Government did on the Treaty on the Non-Proliferation of Nuclear Weapons, the conferences that were held in Vienna and the work done and the speeches given since on ways in which that treaty could be further strengthened and improved. We have also suggested ways in which the work of the Committee on Disarmament could be further improved. I also remind the Senate of the way in which we, in recent years, have taken this debate to the community through our `peace through security' campaign. We on this side do believe in deterrents and we believe that they have worked. The proof has been in the fact that-thank God-we have not had a nuclear war because of the positive attitude of the Western alliance. We have taken our campaign to the community, on to the streets and into the schools. We have had people such as my colleague and friend Senator Teague developing videos to educate school children about our contribution and role in this area. These have been first-class videos based on fact, not rhetoric, and I commend them. We have also contributed in the public fora, in peace marches and on the streets.

In more recent times we have continued this process. I continued it in the First Committee of the United Nations last year; we continued it in the work done by the Opposition's foreign affairs committee which I led in the last Parliament. We received people such as Max Kampleman and went in great detail through the fine work that he was doing in Geneva in putting treaties such as this one into place. I and others have visited the US Arms Control Agency, arguing there that both sides should try to become better informed. We contributed the Opposition's point of view which we believe to be in the best interests of the total community. We worked-and this included Senator Teague and Senator Crichton-Browne, who have both contributed to this debate today-on the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence report on disarmament last year. That is perhaps the best piece of work-the most studied, thoughtful and academic piece of work-on that subject that has been produced in this country for a long time.

Our contribution has been constructive and as a result of it I believe this Government can make wise decisions and can take good counsel to the United Nations and other international fora. That is the sort of constructive role that we have attempted to play, so I regret that the Government and Senator Vallentine have attempted to make cheap political points out of a day that should be one of celebration for all of us. We on this side of the Senate believe that because of the agreement the world has become a slightly safer place in which to live. We congratulate the two super-powers on their agreement. To enable a vote to be taken on the matter of urgency, I now move:
That the question be now put.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the papers.

This debate relates to the Seventy-second Session of the International Labour Conference held in Geneva and the report of the Australian delegation. It contains instruments, as required under article 19 of the International Labour Organisation (ILO) constitution relating to convention 162 and recommendation 172 concerning safety in the use of asbestos. Associated with the paper is a tabling statement by the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis). Annually, we in this chamber deal with reports of the ILO, sessions of which are held typically in June. The International Labour Organisation is a subdivision of the United Nations and is a unique body. Its uniqueness once again should be commended to the chamber.

The ILO consists in equal proportions of a government sector, a workers' sector containing union representation, and an employers' sector containing representation from business organisations and employer groups around the globe. Each year it convenes in Geneva for the purposes of debating and arriving at agreement on conventions which are then recommended to member countries. If those member countries adopt those conventions, they stand as a benchmark in those countries as minimum behaviour or minimum standards for industrial relations. The ILO has been doing this for many years. It has proved its value in all sorts of ways. In Australia in the recent past it has proved the value of its conventions-conventions which have been adopted by all the State governments and the Federal Government. Most notably, recently the value of those conventions was proved in Queensland, where the Queensland Government, under the former Premier, Sir Joh Bjelke-Petersen, attempted to enact State laws which contravened conventions which had been adopted by the ILO and in Australia and which required some changes.

The ILO as a living example of tripartitism is a body on which the Hawke Government has modelled many of its industrial relations conventions. We have set up extensively throughout industry in Australia and at peak level tripartite consultative mechanisms to enable the Government and the social partners, in the form of unions and employers, to try to address the middle and longer term problems in industrial relations which, if not addressed, would exhibit themselves in industrial disputes over specific issues in industry. By addressing the macro issues one tries to resolve in advance, and thus remove from the arena of industrial relations, matters that would blow out in industrial disputes.

This Government's industrial record illustrates better than any speech that can be made the success of that strategy. It stands in stark contrast to the approach of Opposition members, who when in government adopted an approach to industrial relations which was simply a matter of putting on the statute book as many pains and penalties as possible to breed compliance irrespective of the grievance. Thus, Australia had high figures for industrial disputes. Under our Government those figures have dropped markedly. In no place is this better illustrated than in the iron ore industry in Western Australia, which now, during the tenure of office of this Government, is regarded as a reliable supplier to its Japanese markets. It was acknowledged as such in the recent Australia-Japan iron ore conference held at Observation City, Scarborough, Western Australia. The productivity level of workers in the iron ore industry under the tripartite approach of this Government has increased dramatically. In 1983, the first year of our office, gross tonnes of iron ore exported per employee ranked at 20,243; last year they shot up to 27,220, a dramatic increase. Industrial disputes have fallen dramatically too.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to talk on the International Labour Conference paper and safety in the use of asbestos. During the Conference the use of asbestos was discussed and a committee was set up to examine its use in industry. A number of amendments were made which, if followed through, would make conditions safer for workers in the asbestos industry. However, I feel that we need to take this matter a lot further. I believe that labour conferences in this country should also look to asbestos as it affects ordinary people in their own houses. Recently, on 6 October, a report went out that Professor David Ferguson from Worksafe Australia told conference delegates at a national symposium on cancer in the workplace:

SPEECH.PARA: After that the most exposure occurs in the use of asbestos for insulation, mainly of pipes or boilers and in the insulation of houses and the spraying of asbestos in ceilings or between linings.

Professor David Ferguson also stated that the evidence is sufficient to warrant the elimination of asbestos in any form. He said that, although mesothelioma was previously considered to be a rare cancer, Australia now appears to have a higher incidence of it than any other country, which, of course, is a very serious matter.

It was also drawn to the attention of the Senate today during Question Time that in the offices of the Department of Primary Industries and Energy in the Edmund Barton Building in Canberra the ceilings made of asbestos recently fell down and, as a result, the staff in the office had to leave the office for a couple of days or so, which meant that a very important question was not able to be answered in the Senate today.

The thing that is most depressing for everybody is that experts warned of the dangers of asbestos more than 19 years ago. The Australian Capital Territory health authorities were warned of the dangers of insulation, but these warnings were ignored. In fact, a report by a Mr G. Major was put out at the request of the Australian Capital Territory Health Services Branch of the then Department of Health. He described how he watched South African asbestos fluff being piped between ceilings for insulation purposes in Canberra homes. Having read articles in the Press recently, we all know that it will cost citizens between $12,000 and $15,000 to have the asbestos removed, which most people cannot afford.

I would also like to draw the Senate's attention to newspaper reports in Western Australia this year of workers in the asbestos industry claiming recompense for the cancers that the asbestos has caused. Mr Wally Simpson is the first worker to have survived long enough to put in his claim for compensation. Unfortunately, the court found that the company concerned was not negligent and therefore this man, who is dying of cancer, will receive no recompense. The warnings came out 19 years ago. Successive governments have taken absolutely no notice. Although the International Labour Conference is to be commended for the steps it is taking now, these steps have come too late. It is a case of too little too late. Many people are dead, others are dying, and nothing whatsoever is happening to recompense those involved.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crowley Sen R.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to place a slightly different emphasis in my comments about the report of the Australian delegation to the Seventy-second Session of the International Labour Conference, held in 1986. The report of the Director-General of the International Labour Organisation (ILO), given at that conference and entitled The Changing World of Work: Major Issues Ahead, highlighted three broad issues which are mentioned in the report before us. They are: new dimensions in labour relations, including the protection of workers in the informal sector; trends and issues related to the future of social protection in both developed and developing countries; and the twin problems of unemployment and poverty. Those very significant points are matters with which the Government has certainly been grappling.

SPEECH.PARA: Associated with this report is a copy of the speech given at the conference by the Minister for Industrial Relations, Ralph Willis, addressing those points in a way that is most thoughtful and constructive, and which would make edifying reading, particularly for the Opposition. It is also interesting that the principal issues highlighted have been of major concern to this Government both during 1986 and since its re-election this year.

The importance of increasing employment through growth in the economy is something that this Government has been addressing. We can quite clearly see the evidence of the success of the Hawke Government since it came to office in 1983, with the creation of over 800,000 jobs to this point, and an estimated one million jobs by the end of 1988. Clearly, that has been an aim of the Government; clearly, it has been a success for the Government; and, clearly, it fits very well with some of the headline issues that I have just outlined.

Mr Willis's speech also highlighted the importance of looking at the problems of developed countries as compared with those of the poorly developed or developing countries and the problems of the guidelines or industrial practices applying in both. He says that we should take up the issues addressed by the Director-General and the conference. Clearly, those issues need more and considered thought. Australia gives a lot of thought to them both through its involvement in the ILO and also through the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Bill Hayden, has addressed these sorts of issues and is very concerned that they continue to be addressed.

The other point that I want to speak briefly about is the recommendation regarding the safe use of asbestos. In particular, I wish to comment on the way recommendation 172 associated with this document was arrived at. It involved a very extensive series of discussions; it is not as though this recommendation has just come off the top of people's heads. In fact, the ILO Committee on Safety in the Use of Asbestos has been meeting for many years and the report documents that the Committee now has a very exceptional scientific database on asbestos, in particular, its mineralogical characteristics as well as its physical and chemical properties and its biological effects. The report also states that that study over 10 years has been of great benefit in the formulation of this recommendation. As so often in tripartite agreements of this sort, a total ban is not placed on the use of asbestos, but a very thoughtful requirement that, if it is to be used, it has to be used under strict workable standards of handling in the workplace and of use in the community. I urge people to look at this recommendation because there has been very much activity and discussion about asbestos in all States, from the Wittenoom discussions in Western Australia, which go back much more than 19 years, to some activities by colleagues of mine in South Australia who are very concerned about the safety issues of asbestos.

The National Occupational Health and Safety Commission established by the Government, now called Worksafe Australia, clearly will be one of the organisations of government to adopt this recommendation, develop it and look at further ways of having it incorporated into Australian law or regulations. I commend this report to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to add my praise for this report of the Australian delegation to the International Labour Conference, which is the major body of the International Labour Organisation. That organisation grew up as a result of the First World War. Trade union organisations on both sides of the conflict, and, indeed, trade unions from neutral countries, said after the war that there ought to be an organisation which devoted its time and attention to the conditions of the working man and woman. In October 1919 the conference met in Washington and appointed a governing body which since then has met usually once or twice a year, except during the Second World War. This report is of the seventy-second session of the conference.

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting to note that at the conference held in Philadelphia in May 1944 a declaration was made which makes interesting reading. That declaration reaffirmed that labour is not a commodity, that freedom of expression and association are essential to sustain progress, that poverty everywhere constitutes a danger to prosperity everywhere and that the war against want is required to be carried on with unrelenting vigour within each nation. In other words, it set forth aspirations which still hold good. It is important to note that that declaration re-affirmed in particular that labour is not a commodity. There is a danger in the sorts of debates that take place today, including those in this chamber, to treat labour as a commodity. Often times it is said that wages should be reduced in the interests of economic imperatives, that workers should accept lesser conditions than they are used to; and other words to those effects are used. When that is done an impression is given, if it is not intended, that labour is considered simply as another commodity, such as coal, wheat or cars. If the community comes to adopt that view, a disaster will follow; the very strong recommendations made by this organisation will be overlooked.

International Labour Organisation conferences are attended by representatives of workers and employers. The delegation to the conference with which we are dealing included the Hon. Ralph Willis, to whom Senator Crowley referred as being in attendance; the Opposition spokesman on industrial relations at that time, Mr Neil Brown; Mr Bryan Noakes, the employers' delegate from the Confederation of Australian Industry; and Bill Mansfield, the Assistant Secretary of the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The input into this organisation is wide ranging. The organisation represents countries throughout the world and the various economic interests within those countries. So when it speaks-particularly when it speaks about the conditions under which workers should be employed-its words have considerable force. It is well to remember in that context that when the organisation gives an admonition that we should consider workers not simply as pieces of machinery but living human beings who are entitled to dignity and respect and proper wages and conditions, such admonition carries great weight.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Unfortunately, the annual report of the Automotive Industry Authority does not really deal with the state of the automotive industry. No doubt we will have to wait until about May before the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce (Senator Button) provides us with those details. One needs to be desperately concerned about another industry plan of this Government going wrong. It has been demonstrated beyond any shadow of doubt that the Government's steel plan is now a total failure, and the automotive industry plan is well on the same road as the steel plan; in other words, it is headed for disaster.

The Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce has been gaining great kudos by going around this country in effect pretending that he is not responsible for the decisions of the Government in these matters. The truth of the matter is that the automotive industry plan is aimed at reducing by 1992 the number of motor vehicle manufacturers and motor vehicle models. It has been demonstrated within the motor vehicle industry that that plan will be a failure because, frankly, people will not buy one of four simple models of cars. Companies such as Mazda are demonstrating clearly around the world that there are niche opportunities for car manufacturers to produce a run as small as, say, 40,000 vehicles and sell such a run world wide.

I hope that the car dealers are never put in the situation where they have available to them only the routine franchised vehicles from one of the major manufacturers. If they are put in that situation, their dealerships will fall in value greatly as they are destroyed by those competitors who are able to offer buyers some alternative motor vehicle. The great problem with the automotive industry plan is that it limits the number of cars and the number of models available. That will result in the removal of any incentive for innovation and advantages of product differentiation. The export facilitation scheme effectively means that exports are being subsidised.

The components sector of the car manufacturing industry is very much the Achilles heel of the plan. I refer first to the industrial relations aspect. The component manufacturers have been holding to ransom the major car manufacturers. I mention the strikes at the plants of Cooldrive Consolidated Industries and Flexidrive. As with the steel plan, once again the Achilles heel of this plan is the failure of the union movement to deliver to the manufacturing sector what the Government has in effect promised. The situation is that the companies are doing what they have to do, the taxpayers are contributing their fair share, but the union movement is taking advantage of the situation by blackmailing the manufacturing companies.

I am not being critical of the union movement. It should be understood that this is not an attack on unionists. I am merely pointing out that this Government and the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator Button, knew that those circumstances would arise when these plans were implemented. At the time we criticised the Minister for introducing these plans. We pointed out to him that he was going down the wrong path, but he refused to listen to us. Now the union movement is taking him to task and demonstrating to the people of Australia that this Government's industry plans have been a failure in the past and will continue to be a failure. The Opposition suggests that the Government should adopt its policies in this area. The Government could well adopt the Opposition's policies in this area to the advantage of the Australian taxpayers.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Maguire Sen G.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I also wish to make some remarks on the latest annual report of the Automotive Industry Authority for the recent financial year 1986-87. The Authority was established in October 1984 by the Hawke Government to oversee the post-1984 passenger motor vehicle plan in Australia. As such the Authority is part of the Government's economic planning mechanism. It is one of the several authorities involved with the various industry plans in Australia which have been initiated and developed by the Hawke Government since its election in 1983 in an effort to help restructure and redevelop and to lay the foundations for growth in a number of important secondary industries in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: I was particularly interested to note the claims made just a moment ago by Senator Lewis, who I gather is the Opposition spokesman on such matters. He claimed that this plan has gone wrong, that it is yet another example of industry plans that have gone wrong. That assertion is totally confounded by the evidence that was put before me recently when I had the opportunity to inspect the very large facility of Holden's Motor Co. in Elizabeth, one of the northern suburbs of Adelaide. What is happening at that plant will totally dispel the claims made by Senator Lewis this evening. On that site at Elizabeth, Holden's Motor Co. is spending many hundreds of millions of dollars-not just many millions or many tens of millions of dollars-in an effort to boost its motor vehicle production activities. A number of factors have enabled it to do that, not the least of which has been the confidence engendered in the new motor vehicle industry by this Government's motor vehicle plans and the plans administered by the Automotive Industry Authority.

Together with Senator Foreman, I was recently able to inspect the new plastics facility at Holden's Motor Co. at Elizabeth and the new assembly line along which more than 50 robots have been installed for the purpose of that company producing even larger numbers of new motor vehicles. It was a real pleasure and delight to inspect that plant, which after January will be the only place in Australia at which Commodore motor vehicles will be built. Since the 1970s that plant has been plagued by industrial relations problems. There were even suggestions at some stages that the Elizabeth facility would be closed down. It is very pleasing to note that it will now be the central place in Australia for the production of Commodore vehicles. It is now the largest employment site of the Holden Motor Co. in Australia. There are now more people employed at Elizabeth than at Fishermans Bend in Victoria or at Dandenong in Victoria. It is really impressive to note that under this plan Holden's are about to introduce a second shift of production, from January, to produce Commodore cars. Yet just a moment ago we heard the nonsense from Senator Lewis that the car industry plan was another plan that had gone wrong. The confidence shown in the industry, particularly in South Australia, by Holden's gives the lie to that claim by Senator Lewis.

I am also pleased to note that Mitsubishi Motors Australia Ltd, which is located in the southern suburbs of Adelaide and which has both assembly facilities and an engine plant, is now exporting Australian made motor vehicle engines to Japan. I think that is really something. It shows what is happening in Australian industry. Certainly this move has been assisted by the downward movement in the Australian dollar, but it shows what this industry is capable of producing if rationalisation occurs and if there is a planned basis for production in the car industry. I am also delighted to note that South Australian manufacturers of components such as ROH Industries Pty Ltd and Castalloy Ltd have recently secured very large export orders indeed. Australian made car components are now being exported from this country as a result of the new-found confidence in and more stable basis of the Australian motor vehicle industry.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remind the Senate that we are debating the Automotive Industry Authority's third annual report. I also remind the Senate that in a ministerial statement of 29 May 1984 the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, Senator John Button, announced the Commonwealth Government's policy objectives for the development, as he put it, `of a more competitive and export orientated automotive industry'. This report should contain a statement of the Automotive Industry Authority's success-which the Authority should monitor-in achieving those objectives. We are now three years down the track and there is no statement in this report about how successful the plan has been. We would prefer to have specific performance targets. But there is nothing in this report to indicate how successful the Authority has been in meeting those objectives, so there is no use in having objectives.

SPEECH.PARA: This is not surprising, because since September 1985 company fleet passenger car sales had plummeted by almost 46 per cent. In fact, sales in 1986 generally were at their lowest for 18 years. Sales of imported cars at the beginning of this year were 30.1 per cent lower than in the previous year. One of the big reasons for the big slump, of course, is this Government's fringe benefits tax. But this has occurred not only because of the fringe benefits tax, but also because of government interference. I refer to increased fuel tax levied by both State and Federal governments. I mention the increased sales tax imposed by the Federal Government and also, of course, the massive devaluation of the Australian dollar. This Labor Government must take direct responsibility for the sad state of the industry at present.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Colston Sen M.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I table the report of the Australian delegation to the Seventy-seventh Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union held in Managua in April and May 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: Ordered that the report be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —I seek leave to make a brief statement in relation to the report.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to be able to present the report of the Seventy-seventh Conference of the Inter-Parliamentary Union. During this conference, members of the Australian delegation were particularly active, both formally and informally, in bringing to the attention of other delegates Australia's views concerning the subsidisation of agricultural production and exports, and related issues. The delegation had sought to bring the matter before the Seventy-sixth Conference in Argentina as a supplementary agenda item. But when that strategy was unsuccessful the delegation managed to have the matter unanimously accepted as a main topic for debate at the 1987 Conference in Managua. The Australian delegation performed creditably in the plenary debate and in the drafting committee for this particular item.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to acknowledge the assistance the delegation received through the then Ministers for Trade and for Primary Industry and from the Parliamentary Library. I must record the delegation's thanks to the head of the Australian Embassy in Mexico who made two of his staff available for the delegation's support throughout the conference. This was the second time I, as leader, had such excellent assistance from the Australian Embassy in Mexico. Miss Beverley Morrisby, from the embassy, provided the same excellent assistance as she had in Mexico in 1986. On behalf of the delegation, I must offer sincere thanks to Mr Glen Waller, also from the Australian Embassy in Mexico, for his invaluable assistance.

For the smooth running of the delegation, I thank the other members of the delegation-the Hon. Ian Wilson, MP, the deputy leader, Senator Alston, Senator Black, Mr Jull, Mr Kent, MP and Senator Vallentine. As leader, my thanks are extended to Mr Peter Murdoch, the secretary to the delegation, and Mr Geoff Crawford, the Department of the Foreign Affairs adviser. TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Committee is considering clause 21, and the Australian Democrats' amendment No. 8, moved by Senator Powell. I put the question:

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (9) Page 18, after clause 22 add the following clause:
``22a. Section 44 of the Principal Act is amended by adding the words ``under the age of 18 years and receiving full-time education at school'' after the words ``16 years'' in subsection (3)''.

This amendment will change the new provisions regarding widows pensions and sole parent benefits which were introduced in the May mini-Budget. The Committee will recall that suddenly, following the May mini-Budget, people who had been previously entitled to or were expecting to be entitled to widows pensions or sole parent benefits while they had children up to the age of 24 in full time education were faced with a cutback in benefits when their children reached the age of 16. At that time it was anticipated quite quickly that this was going to cause immense distress to a great many sole parent families, the vast majority of them headed by women. A large number of these women were of an age whereby they did not have the opportunity to move back into the full time work force.

As I said in my speech at the second reading stage, this was designated by the Government as a labour market program. There are a tremendous number of difficulties involved, not the least of which is the inappropriateness of this measure in the context of a government which protests that it is attempting to help families and that it wants to keep children at school for the longest possible time and to have a focus on education and training for young people. The age currently set down in the legislation as a result of that change-that is, 16 years-is not generally the age at which even secondary schooling is completed. It runs quite counter to the claims of the Government that it is after an increase in retention rates.

The amendment I have moved attempts to lift this age to 18 years, which is far more realistic, at least when it comes to secondary education. As far as the Australian Democrats are concerned, there should have been no change from the age of 24 which, of course, covered tertiary or post-secondary education and training quite adequately and was of great benefit to many families, particularly, I repeat, sole parent families. Here is another instance where the Government, in making its economies out of welfare sector for redistribution within that sector, not having the courage to raise funds in the large corporate sector, is making savings at the expense of women and young people in particular. This has been a continuing pattern. In this amendment the Democrats are supporting the Government's initiative towards higher school retention rates.

There has certainly been a spate of correspondence to my office and to the offices of other Australian Democrat senators and, I trust, to the offices of Government senators and members, and Ministers in particular, detailing instances of the difficulties being experienced by women. The Government has told us that the women concerned will now be able to get into the paid work force-although I think it probably just said the `work force'. We often forget that women do work, even if they are only in the home. We should all remember to differentiate quite clearly by using the term `paid work force'. It is as if there were discredit in women's honourable task of being full time parents, instead of which the Government has said that they can now seek employment. What that means in 1987, as it meant in 1986 and it will mean in 1988 at least, is that those women can join the ranks of the unemployed. They will be able to queue at the Commonwealth Employment Service offices, in too many cases along with their adolescent and young adult children, who are also amongst the ranks of the unemployed in very high numbers. Alternatively, the Government has said, they can get involved in training and retraining programs.

A lady from Colac wrote to me on behalf of her daughter, who lives deep in western Victoria, some 80 or 90 miles from the nearest tertiary or technical and further education institution, wanting to know which training program her daughter, a widow, was going to get involved in when she became ineligible for the pension. I have had any number of such questions from people in rural areas. Of course, people in urban areas also often face this kind of difficulty. We have to bear in mind that this a group of people in large measure who have not had this expectation and who have now had it lumped on them with very little notice. Their expectations will certainly change over time. At the time of the May legislation the Democrats attempted to impose a longer transition period, because that allowed by the Government was only a short one. Of course, those people who are currently eligible for assistance will remain eligible, but there is a large group in the transition stage who have been thrust on to the unemployment queues and who are finding it difficult even now to get into training programs, because those programs were not set up in advance. There is an enormous amount of disillusionment in the community on this issue. I commend this amendment to the chamber.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be very brief. It is simply not true to say that this Government has lacked the courage to tax the corporate sector. If we look at the range of taxes, from the capital gains tax to the fringe benefits tax, we see that this Government has gone into waters into which no other government has been prepared to go. We have shown our courage and put our runs on the board. Obviously, this is a decision taken by the Government which recognises the increased maturity of 16-year-olds, who do not need the same level of care as younger children. I therefore do not believe that the Australian Democrats' amendment is in any way a recognition of reality.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I would also like to speak to this amendment because of the personal experience that I have had in Western Australia from a group of women who have approached me on this matter in particular. This group of women is called Women in Transit. These are women who have all been affected by the new regulation in the May mini-Budget. Now that their youngest child in each case has turned 16, these women are all in a very difficult situation. The group is gathering information on the effects of the changes, and the picture which is emerging is a particularly ugly one. The women point out that the change is making it impossible for their children to continue with their education. These women particularly want their youngest child to continue with education and, because they are no longer eligible for the single parent benefit, they can no longer afford to keep their child in education. When they look for jobs they find that there are none for untrained middle aged women. They find it very difficult, if not impossible, to get into training courses.

SPEECH.PARA: It is particularly interesting that the House of Representatives, from which this Government governs-in other words, over which it has total control-has just requested the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Employment, Education and Training to conduct an inquiry into the work force entry or re-entry of social security pensioners. The scope of the inquiry will include supporting parent beneficiaries, so basically the initiation of this inquiry constitutes a de facto admission that the Government has goofed. The Government has attempted to force supporting parent beneficiaries into the work force, in a context of its admitting the need for an inquiry to ascertain whether education, training and support measures are adequate. Such a move would not be made if there was not compelling evidence to suggest that they are in fact inadequate. I very strongly support the Australian Democrats' amendment and hope that the Government will pay some attention to this matter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is a matter which I would like to put to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson). It is a disturbing matter. It is apparent that the Government is not going to support this amendment, nor is the Opposition, and therefore these women will still be appearing at the Commonwealth Employment Service offices. I have had reported to me instances of officers in the Commonwealth Employment Service discriminating against these women and actually saying to them that they cannot help them because of the age group they are in and because they do not have any training. We know that the training programs which are promised have not been set up, although they may very well be in the process of being set up, and that these women do not fit readily into existing training programs. It is a case of putting the cart before the horse. This measure was implemented before provisions for these people were put in place.

SPEECH.PARA: I have had these disturbing reports from both the Sydney and the Melbourne areas. It may simply be a matter of practicality for the people in the Employment Service. They know that they do not have jobs for these women. Perhaps they are giving them the facts. However, it is bad enough for women who consider that they were involved in an honourable profession, that of home making and mothering, to find themselves on the dole queues, but it is even worse to be told that that is where they will have to stay and that there is no work for them. Can I please have an assurance from the Minister that he-we are dealing here with social security-will do what I asked the responsible Minister during the May mini-Budget on this matter, and take this up with the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins). I do not believe that the Department of Social Security should just wash its hands of these people. We still have a responsibility to them as human beings. I am very disturbed by these reports.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly I will take the matter up with both Ministers-the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) and the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe). I would hope that, in a service as large as that administered by the Department of Social Security, Senator Powell would be referring to some isolated incidents rather than to a pattern. If there are any specific instances-and I hope she can give me some examples-I will be very happy to take them up with the appropriate Minister. In any event, I certainly will take up the general question.
