SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (11) Page 21, clause 28, proposed paragraph 73 (a) (ii), line 15, after ``a compensation payment'' insert a comma.

This amendment seeks to insert a comma after certain words in clause 28. I am advised that if this is not done, the family allowance supplement might very well be available to people who are already receiving other benefits from the Commonwealth, in particular Commonwealth employees workers compensation payments which have a child related additional benefit. In this case we are supporting the Government's policy which is, of course, that welfare benefits should go to those who are in most need. We believe that the way the clause is drafted it would be possible for people to receive the family allowance supplement on top of certainly Commonwealth employees workers compensation payments and possibly State workers compensation payments which have a child related benefit. We do not believe that this would be in the best interests of the Government and its policy, which we advocate, of supporting the needy. I commend that amendment to the Committee.
Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Clause 28, proposed new section 76 (1), payment of allowance, seems to me to be an appropriate place at which to bring my concerns to the Committee. During the second reading debate on the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 I pointed out that the Government had created a poverty trap in this legislation. I will explain to the Committee what I am talking about. A single income earner who earns $330 a week and who has a dependent spouse pays $40.39 in tax. Under the family allowance supplement, if he owns his own home or is renting public housing, the Government gives him back $35. If he is renting privately, under the family allowance supplement he gets back $50.

SPEECH.PARA: I put to the Government that, instead of creating a hand-out mentality in this group, instead of just going for vote catching, it would be more sensible to work the family allowance supplement in such a way as to give such families an additional $35 by not taking that amount of tax from them. If the Government said to that group of families, `You pay $40.39. We are prepared to reduce that amount so that you pay'-if the Minister wants to stick to that amount-`only $5.39 instead of the $40-odd', this would put a stop to the disincentive to that income earner to earn more money.

If that person, earning $330 a week, worked an additional 7 1/2 hours on a Saturday he would earn $90 extra, but by doing so would lose his family allowance supplement-if renting privately-and out of the $90 extra he earned that week he would get only $8.59. No one in Australia would work a whole Saturday, a whole 7 1/2-hour day, for an extra $90 and of that, as take home pay, get only $8.59. I brought this to the attention of the Minister and he assured me that he agreed with me. He said that, if my figures were correct, he thought that the situation was wrong and that the Government should be able to handle it in a different fashion. I ask the Minister what the Government is going to do about it. I understand that he has checked my figures and that the Department has found them to be completely correct.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —The figures that Senator Walters has given are indeed correct, although her example is nothing new. I think it was used during the election campaign. It is an example which has been used before. I will go through what the family package is about before addressing the question of where we go from here. It is based on a targeted approach, if you like, assisting low income families in need. The sum of $500m is directed to those families in need. It is not possible to direct $500m to families in need without having a means test. There is no other way to do it. The Opposition's approach has been to support that. If that is the case one must admit that there is no doubt that overall the family package improves the incentive for unemployed people to get jobs. Families who are on benefits and who take up work will keep their family allowance payment or will have it phased out gradually. One presumes that eligible families will always be better off when working than when on benefits-that is certainly their view-and families who receive the family allowance supplement will stay on that rate of payment for six months. That is changed only if their income goes up by more than 25 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: The example that Senator Walters gave about overtime does not bear that out. The reality is that very few people will be affected by an income change of more than 25 per cent. I concede that Senator Walters's figures are accurate, and I asked the Department of Social Security to look at that during the dinner break. Given that it would appear that there are many fewer people affected than Senator Walters has suggested, I am not sure that at this point there is that much that can be done. It is a mistaken view that the Government's family package perpetuates poverty traps. Surely, it does a lot to ameliorate the problems of poor people. There is confusion about poverty traps and effective marginal tax rates. That having been said, it is pretty obvious that if one has a means tested approach, inevitably somewhere along the line between the social security and taxation systems-and that is a rather complex relationship-it will not be possible to avoid some of these conflicts. The Government is aware of this problem and it is addressing it. Hopefully it will be possible to make announcements about it. It will not be tonight, but the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) is aware of the problem and he is looking at it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) has indicated by his shrug of the shoulders, he is not at all happy with that answer. He has succumbed to the `Yes, Minister' approach of the Department of Social Security. I make it perfectly clear that the Government is taking from a person whom it has designated a low income earner-that is, a single income family man with a dependent spouse and two children under 13 years of age, on $330 a week-more than $40 a week in tax. It then turns around and says that because that person is a low income earner and it believes his children could be in poverty, it will give him back $35 of that amount. That is ludicrous. The Government is paying the Australian Taxation Office to make that assessment and take the $40.39, and it is paying the Department of Social Security additional money to hand back $35.

SPEECH.PARA: That could be done for only one reason-the Government wants to be seen as giving a big handout, as the `big fella', the white knight. It wants to get some votes on this because it thinks it is being good and giving $35 to those whom it considers to be low income earners who need help. What absolute rubbish! The Government is ripping off more than $40 in tax from those people. Why does it not just tell that group of single income earners-and I do not care how many or how few there are-that they need not pay that tax? That would stop the disincentive for such people to earn more money. If they were offered an additional 7 1/2 hours work in a week, they would gladly accept it because although their tax would go up they would not lose the $35 that the Government is so generously handing them as a family allowance supplement. Indeed, as the position is now a family would lose $50 because it would also be getting a rental allowance if renting privately. As it is, if a family man is asked to work another 7 1/2 hours, he will say, `Not on your life! The employer will pay me $90, but I will lose all my handouts from the Government and I will be only $8.59 better off. I am not going to work 7 1/2 hours for $8.59'. Would the Minister? Would he work 7 1/2 hours for $8.59? I bet he would not. He would say, `No I will not work for that, I would rather put my hand out. The Government has said that if I do not work that extra 7 1/2 hours it will give me $35; if I do work it the Government will not give me a penny'.

The disincentive in that proposition underscores the problem that the Government has created. If the Government is not prepared to tell that group of people that it will not take over $40 from them in tax, that it will allow them to keep that money that they earn and that it will tax them only $5, it will create the biggest poverty trap imaginable because it will be saying to them, `Do not try to earn more money to try to support your own family; do not try to escape the mess you are in, because if you try the Government will not help you. The Government will make sure that you do not do that extra work because if you do you will receive only an extra $8.59'.

The Government really must consider the long term effects of this sort of legislation on the Australian community. It must consider the fact that it is creating such disincentives for this group. It is no use the Minister telling me that there are only a few families affected. So long as the Government creates such large disincentives and long term problems for this group of parents trying to help their own families-and I do not know how many people are involved, I have just picked out that one income group as an example; there must be other people in that area who will be worse off if they do not stick to the handout mentality-it is doing a great disservice to the Australian community.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Walters began her contribution by saying that we are taking from the low income earner. The reality is that the family allowance supplement that we have discussed tonight is about giving to the low income earner. Surely that is the overriding, overwhelming effect of it. The package gives; it does not take. Senator Walters was referring to a very narrow range; I am referring to the broad range. She said that the Government should take into consideration the long term effects of its decision. I have already acknowledged that that is what the Government is doing in looking at the problem at the moment.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Walters also made two remarks about me. In the first she asked whether I would work an extra 7 1/2 hours for $8.59. Given my working hours in the past year, I consider that I have worked a lot more than that for nothing.

TALK.START.PARA: —You might be doing that tonight.
—That is correct. The other remark was about my gestures. I like moving my arms about.
—And shrugging your shoulders.

—I am expressive; but Senator Walters should never read too much into my expressions because, after all, I am also light-hearted. I would not want her to read too much into a shrug or a wave of the arms.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to make a contribution on this clause. I acknowledge the point made by Senator Walters about the effective marginal tax rates that will be applied in the case of persons with incomes in the $17,000 to $23,000 range. That is a problem which the Minister has acknowledged and which has been spoken about quite frequently. I am concerned about it and I believe that it will have to be rectified. Over the past 10 years I have stood in this place and elsewhere and waged a consistent campaign for a fair deal, a fair go, for families. I have pointed out the serious injustices suffered by families in Australia because of the failure of successive governments to index the family allowance.

SPEECH.PARA: The history of this whole family allowance scheme goes back to 1976 when the then Fraser Government abolished the tax rebates which had been payable for children and, with the money saved, established a family allowance scheme by which family allowance was paid to the mothers. At that time I said in this chamber that that was a good idea if the payments were to be indexed and to keep pace with the increases in costs. I repeated that year after year. Then, in about late 1980, the Fraser Government again adjusted the scheme, but not sufficiently to keep up with the loss in the real value of the family allowance. By last year that loss had resulted in $10 billion being pinched by successive governments from the purses of Australian mothers because of the failure of those governments to ensure that the family allowance kept pace with increases in the cost of living. Of course, that affected lower income families more dramatically than others. It affected all families, but lower income families more than others.

The Government has now proposed a band-aid treatment, as it were, to try to cover up the wounds that it and its predecessors inflicted on lower income families. I accept that this family assistance scheme is not an inconsiderable scheme. It is a good start. However, I think it is based on a false premise when one goes into the problem, which Senator Walters and others have mentioned, of effective marginal tax rates. The family allowance supplement (FAS) package will also cause a number of administrative problems. But at least it is providing to low income families with children an amount on which to get by.

TALK.START.PARA: —They wouldn't need to if they didn't have to pay so much tax.

—I will come to the tax matter in a moment; it is a very important matter. It is interesting to note that, in its FAS, the Government has recognised that it is more costly to feed, clothe and educate teenagers than younger children. That is a common sense approach and the Government should be praised for that.

SPEECH.PARA: Since we are in committee, I would like to raise another point by way of a question to the Minister. When the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) made his statement and promise on this issue, he promised that in Labor's third term, the total assistance per child would increase from 11 per cent to at least 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension. He added that payments for older children would reach a benchmark of 20 per cent of this rate. While on the issue of indexation I would like confirmation from the Minister that this is still the Government's policy. I do not want to see, five years down the track, the amount being proposed now dwindle to such an extent that it will not reflect costs at that stage.

Also on the question of indexation, I notice that the upper limit for the income test is to be indexed. But, unless I have read it wrongly, I cannot see any mention of indexing the amount mentioned in clause 28, proposed new section 72, relating to allowable income. Perhaps I have overlooked it, but I would be obliged if the Minister could point out where that is mentioned. I assume that the amount is indexed, as with the amount contained in the later clause relating to the family allowance income test. Those are a couple of the questions I want to raise with the Minister.

Another question relates to the general matter of taxation which has been mentioned. I do not think that we should let this clause go by without refreshing our minds about the purpose of the family allowance in the first place. The family allowance was really a taxation measure which recognised that families with children, at whatever level of income, have higher costs, including taxation costs, than families who do not have children. That was the simple reason for the introduction of the family allowance scheme. As I mentioned, the taxation rebate was abolished in 1976 and the money saved was used to fund the family allowance scheme. But now the taxation system does not recognise children.

The Government has said that it will abolish poverty by the year 1990. What does that mean? As far as I am concerned, kids are supposed to be poor. I do not think they should have money hanging out of their pockets and all the rest of it, unless they scratch up that money from somewhere else. None of my kids has much. The Government proposes to abolish child poverty. It is not a question of abolishing child poverty. The Government should be talking about the family. It is the mums and dads who are poor, not the kids. I do not really like what is behind the idea of abolishing child poverty. It might result in someone in the year 2000 saying to some parents, `Your kids are poor; we will have to take them from you'. I do not want to labour this point or get carried away with it; I just raise it. I know what is meant. It is a valid, laudable and well sounding phrase, but let us analyse it.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's an election ploy.

—The Government's measure will help a considerable number of people and, frankly, I acknowledge that. I know that a good deal of influence was exerted by a couple of unions with which I was associated to ensure that something was done in this area. I do not want to go through the history of it.
—Oh! Go on.
—As all honourable senators would appreciate, most of all Senator Haines, not every measure that goes through this place is necessarily debated on its merits. That is unfortunate.
—Only by us. We're the only ones who do it. You are quite right; generally it is not the case.

—The honourable senator is diverting me. It is important to understand that, because the taxation system does not recognise the number of people in a particular family dependant on a particular income, a whole range of families, at whatever level of income, are being discriminated against by the taxation system. As I said, it does not recognise and does not take account of the number of children that must rely on that one income. That is a tragedy. I do not know of any other country in the world that does not take account of that aspect. It is all very well for Mr Elliott to say that family allowances should be abolished.
—What about the Government?
—The Government as well. Mr Elliott and all such big businessmen can write off--
—Everything.

—Yes, they can write off very large numbers of things; but the most important business in this country cannot do that. Of course, that affects mostly those families that rely on one income. I urge the Government to do something to rectify the situation whereby families on one income are being severely discriminated against under the Government's taxation policies.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall be brief, as consideration of this measure has been going on for some time. In response to the remarks of Senator Harradine, I shall quote that part of the document entitled Social Security Budget Information 1987-88 which deals with the family package. It reads:

SPEECH.PARA: And now, with the family package, the Government will index payments and recognise the higher cost of older children . . . Once achieved, these benchmarks will be retained-ensuring that the relative value of payments will not be eroded over time.

While I do not think the indexation commitment is in clause 28, I do not think Senator Harradine has misread it. I think that matter will continue to be looked at in the Budget context next year. Thus far, certainly, the Government's promise has been kept. I have no doubt that that process will continue. In response to the interjection made by Senator McGauran on one of his rare visits to the chamber, I can only say that the family package proposal was not an election ploy, as we are at present debating its being put into practice. It is not much of a ploy if it is actually being implemented.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walters Sen M.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) for at least listening to the figures I quoted in my speech yesterday and for acknowledging that the Government has a problem in this area. I thank him for at least acknowledging that the family package will indeed be a poverty trap or a disincentive to people taking on additional work and that the Government will look at the problem and attempt to correct it. It is a pity that other Government members do not listen a little more to the speeches of Opposition members, as Senator Richardson did yesterday. Senator Crowley, who followed me in the second reading debate, made very derogatory remarks about the figures I brought to the attention of the Government. I shall quote some of her remarks, as they underline the fact that some members on the Government side just speak off the top of their heads without having listened to the speeches of those who preceded them in the debate. Senator Crowley said:

SPEECH.PARA: There is nothing we can say to argue against a person who has a blind conviction-sometimes known as a prejudice-about these matters. Senator Walters hears no argument of logic about it.
She went on to say:
I am amazed, if not shocked, that Senator Walters could come in here and say what she did, I think missing the point of the legislation and the proposed changes.
She continued:
I listened to the extraordinary nonsense by Senator Walters who suggested that such a package was an insult. This betrays her lack of understanding of what this legislation is about . . .

That is totally opposed to the attitude that Senator Richardson has taken in recognising that there was considerable sense in the matters that I brought to his attention and that my figures were accurate. Indeed, he indicated that the Government intends to look at the situation and take some action to attempt to correct it. I thank the Minister for doing so.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Lest this new and close relationship between Senator Walters and me should at some point in time be misrepresented, might I say that, so far as Senator Crowley's remarks are concerned, I think she was referring to Senator Walters's general comments about the family package. I believe the family package is one of the great steps of this Government in social reform, and I want to defend it strongly. I would not like any of the remarks I have made to be taken in any other way.

—I have been trying to determine what the Minister meant when he read out the statements from the Department of Social Security budget information document. That did not square with the comments that I quoted of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in regard to the total assistance per child. In those comments it was stated that the total assistance per child would increase from 11 per cent to at least 15 per cent of the combined married rate of pension in Labor's third term. He added that payment for older children would reach a benchmark of 20 per cent of this rate.
—That is correct.
—It does equal that, does it?

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I will just read out the rest for the record. This is from the document that I quoted earlier:

SPEECH.PARA: Achievement of benchmarks by 1990 will involve raising the total payments for children (Family Allowance plus FAS) to: 15 per cent of the married rate of pension for children under the age of 13, and 20 per cent of the married pension rate for 13, 14 and 15 year olds, in recognition of the higher cost of teenagers.
They are the paragraphs that come between the two that I read out before.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —On that particular point, are we now saying that in fact this is somehow related not only to the family allowance supplement (FAS) but also the family allowance scheme itself? Honourable senators should be aware-no doubt they are-of what is taking place. It looks as though the base rate of family allowances is being unjustifiably frozen. We must bear in mind that we are talking about justice now. Family allowance appears to be frozen at a totally unsatisfactory level. The present amount, by the way, will now buy only something like two-thirds of what it could buy when the allowance was first introduced. So the level of family allowance has dropped by one-third. In other words, families' taxation levels have increased on the basis of that factor alone by one-third, given the fact that the taxation rebates were abolished in 1976 to pay for this amount.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1976 operation entailed pulling money out of the hip pocket of the taxpayer and putting it into the purse. That was fine. I did not mind that. But the trouble is that a third of that money has now been taken out of the purse. What worries me is that, unless the Government in some other way-such as through the taxation system if it will not do it with these measures-recognises that it is more costly, in terms of taxation, education, clothing and food, to support a family with children than it is to support a family without children, that injustice will continue. What I am really asking is how those figures mentioned will apply. Will they apply to the FAS or to the family allowance basic rate itself?

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —As I said, we are looking at the family allowance plus the family allowance supplement. It seems to me that, provided the Government honours its commitment to the two percentages, the 15 per cent and the 20 per cent-and I have no doubt that it will-it does not matter what the components that get us to the figure are, provided we get to the figure; and we certainly will do that as far as low income families are concerned. So while I acknowledge that the family allowance itself has not risen spectacularly since 1976, I think, by definition, the family allowance supplement is the component of the package upon which we should be concentrating at the moment. Given that, I am sure that we can allay Senator Harradine's concerns.

—I wish to make some remarks on that matter. Given that the Minister has stressed the importance of the family allowance supplement in this whole process, I raise a concern which I have not raised today; that is, the take-up rates of the family allowance supplement. With previous supplementary benefits take-up rates have been a problem. It is acknowledged that many of the poorest families, particularly those without a great grasp of English-people in the migrant community who have not yet been able to overcome language problems, but others as well-have not had a very high take-up rate of supplements of this sort. I know that there have been advertising programs and so on, but there always have been such programs for supplementary benefits. I wonder whether the Government can give us some assurance that additional specific steps are being taken in those areas of particular need-areas where there has been a demonstrably low take-up of supplements previously.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Certainly it would be acknowledged that the take-up rates for the family income supplement were not all that we hoped they might be. I acknowledge that there have been particular problems in the ethnic community with them. The signs for the new test are indeed encouraging. The Government is concentrating the advertising to which the honourable senator referred on the ethnic Press to make sure that those people who lacked sufficient information to take up such programs in the past can be fully informed. We are hopeful that this problem will be rectified. I am informed that new applications in the last two months have more than doubled compared with the number for all of last year. That being the case, I think the signs are there that that situation, if not fully redressed, has been substantially redressed.

SPEECH.PARA: Clause agreed to.
Clauses 29 and 30-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 31 (Income test for family allowances).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (12) Page 25, Clause 31, paragraph (d), at the end of the paragraph add ``, and by inserting the words ``or for the current year of income'' after the words ``last year of income'' when first occurring in subsection 85 (7), and by omitting the words ``the following year of'' and substituting ``the year of lower'' in subsection 85 (7)''.

This amendment is proposed because section 85 (7) of the Act is, I believe, deficient in that, in combination with section 85 (1), it discriminates unfairly between families whose incomes drop substantially and permanently at some time during the first six months of a financial year and those whose income drops some time during the second six months. If the income drops during the first six months, the income taken into account is the income of the previous financial year. Therefore, the anticipated fall in income for the current financial year will not be taken into account until the latter half of that year. Many instances have been drawn to my attention where this is a concern. Incomes can fluctuate dramatically at any time. By locking decisions on eligibility into the previous financial year there is potential for a great deal of hardship. Hence this amendment is proposed.
Amendment negatived.
Clause agreed to.
Clauses 32 to 35-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 36 (Repeal of Part XII and substitution of new Part).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (13) Page 27, clause 36, proposed section 101, proposed definition of ``disabled children'', paragraph (a), line 6, leave out the proposed paragraph, insert the following paragraph:
``(a) has a physical, intellectual or psychiatric disability''.
(14) page 27, clause 36, proposed section 101, definition of ``disabled children'', paragraph (b), line 8, after the word ``daily'' insert the words ``or very frequent''.
(15) Page 28, clause 36, proposed subsection 103 (3), lines 1 to 8, leave out the proposed subsection.

These amendments relate to provisions concerning the child disability allowance. The first of them, which is an amendment to proposed section 101 (a), relates to the definition of `disability'. In the Bill, disability is defined in terms of physical and intellectual disability. Psychiatric disability is omitted. The Australian Democrats, as well as the people involved in the disability support area, are grateful for the support of the Opposition with the earlier amendment on this issue. I remind the Committee that earlier disability services legislation included psychiatric disability as a result of that same combination of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. It is important that the three types of disability are clearly recognised and that it is acknowledged that there is a difference between intellectual and psychiatric disability. That has been clearly canvassed during this debate. I simply add that the Australian Council for Rehabilitation of Disabled has weighed into this debate and has pointed out to us-and I think pointed out today directly to the Minister-that intellectual disabilities arise from an inability to learn and understand while psychiatric disabilities arise from difficulties with emotions, feelings and perceptions of reality. We need to recognise that and not to cut out one significant sector in this definition.
The proposed amendments to paragraph (b) of proposed section 101 relate to further aspects of the definition. Paragraphs (b) and (c) of the proposed section state:

(b) because of that disability, needs care and attention provided by another person on a daily basis that is substantially more than the care and attention needed by a child of the same age who does not have such a disability; and
(c) is likely to need that care and attention permanently or for an extended period;

The amendment I am proposing addresses the concern with the limitation of the word `daily'. We are proposing to add `or very frequent' in recognition of forms of disability which may not need regular and complete care on a daily basis, different from that which a child without such a disability would need but frequently enough so that the additional allowance is necessary for the care of that child.

The third amendment I am moving in this group addresses the restriction in clause 36 which might mean that the mere fact that a child attends school during the day would preclude the parent or the carer from being paid the child disability allowance. There are a considerable number of instances when attendance at a school might be part of the daily life of a child with a disability. We believe the Bill imposes an undue restriction and we propose this amendment to reduce that restriction. I commend those amendments to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Senator Powell has spoken to amendments (13), (14) and (15), but I shall put them separately.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —On mature consideration during the dinner suspension-
—You are joking!

—I occasionally have mature consideration. Given that that is the case, the Government will not oppose amendment No. (13) concerning the term `intellectual disability'. The first of the other two amendments concerns the words `on a daily basis.' I think it is really a matter of using better language, and `on a daily basis' is certainly much clearer. The new criteria allow for additional care being able to fluctuate, given that on some days it is more necessary than on others, provided at least some care is given on a daily basis. Obviously the condition of a child can be unpredictable. We think the definition more than covers any problem. Certainly it is not meant to be restrictive.

SPEECH.PARA: So far as schooling is concerned, to which amendment No. (15) is directed, certainly there is no new restriction at all. The best example of that is the case of children in boarding school. Where a child is at boarding school, and is therefore absent from the home for 24 hours, the disability allowance will be payable only at weekends when the child is at home. The payment is not affected where the child attends school for part of the day and is home for the rest. So I do not believe that the new clause is in any way restrictive or will affect those recipients presently getting it.

TALK.START.PARA: —I must express my absolute delight at the Minister's unqualified support for the first of these amendments. I think this constitutes a breakthrough with this Government. I am sure that the psychiatrically disabled, and those who care for and work with them, will be delighted. I also welcome the assurances of the Minister that the further definitions in regard to the child disability allowance are not intended to be restrictive. Should that prove to be the case, the Government can confidently expect further proposed amendments next time we have another social security amendment Bill-and they are introduced on a nauseatingly regular basis in this place. But the assurances are there, and we welcome those assurances and welcome the Government's support for the first of these amendments.

These amendments relate to the under-18-year-old unemployed who are now no longer able to receive the unemployment benefit and who also, by way of this legislation, would not be able to receive the sickness benefit. My amendment is designed to restore that access to the sickness benefit to under-18-year-olds. It is a concern that because the sickness benefit is not available, and because of the requirements which now exist for job search allowance recipients, that there is a distinct disadvantage to them. Job search allowance recipients have to attend the Commonwealth Employment Service office or a training course, or possibly both, with a penalty of automatic loss of income for non-compliance without any sufficient reason. We are concerned at how the Department of Social Security will be able to identify when a job search allowance recipient is ill. The practical result of this would be that those under-18-year-olds who are ill could lose their income unjustly and may not even know that they have the right to retain the job search allowance.

It is also unclear how long any such termination, which might result from the lack of awareness of this situation, will last and whether in fact a fresh application would have to be made and whether reinstatement would take place only after a 13-week waiting period. We believe that the sickness benefit should continue to be available to under-18-year-old beneficiaries in spite of the fact that they are now no longer unemployment beneficiaries and go on to in many cases a reduced job search allowance. I commend these amendments to the chamber. The amendment to clause 38 is consequent upon the amendment to clause 37.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (18) Page 32, clause 39, subclause 39 (b), leave out the proposed subclause.

This amendment relates to a point which I made in my speech at the second reading stage; that is, the Government's promise of indexation. We see the Government making economies within particular areas of the welfare sector in order to be able to claim that it is increasing support for other parts of the welfare sector. We have seen this before. We saw pension increases delayed in the 1986 Budget, and this is a rerun of that exercise. There is no justification for the Government reneging on prior commitments in relation to rates for sickness and unemployment beneficiaries. We are presently in a climate where we have a Budget which is touted as a great achievement, being a relatively balanced Budget, and we have a Treasurer claiming that there is going to be a surplus Budget next time. We are also seeing a great increase in wealth, regardless of the stock market crash. I would have to object to this point being used as an excuse for inaction, as it was earlier by the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), when of course all that has happened as a result of the stock market crash is that we have been taken back to the stock market levels of about October 1986. I fail to see, if a millionaire drops back from having $10m to $6.5m or whatever, how that means that there is not as much wealth sloshing around at the top while pensioners and beneficiaries are once again asked to pull in their belts and to bear the brunt. This seems to the Australian Democrats to be the sort of exercise that cannot be supported.

With this amendment we are seeking to have the Government come clean and live up to promises which it has made with regard to the indexation of unemployment and sickness benefits. As I say, it is the sort of exercise which is very difficult to tolerate, particularly in the current economic climate, when there is a great deal of heartache felt by people who simply cannot find employment. This kind of exercise does not recognise that they are being punished for circumstances that are beyond their control.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (19) Page 36, clause 41, proposed subsection 121a (1), proposed definition of ``person to whom this section applies'', (a) subparagraph (i), leave out ``6 months'', insert ``6 weeks''; (b) leave out subparagraph (ii).
(20) Page 37, clause 41, proposed paragraph 121a (5) (c), lines 17 to 20, leave out the proposed subparagraph, insert the following subparagraph:

``(c) for the year of income following the last year of income or for the current year of income is, or is likely to be, at least 25% less than the taxable income of the person's parents for the last year of income:''.
(21) Page 37, clause 41, proposed subsection 121a (5), line 21, leave out ``that following year of'' insert ``the year of lower''.

These amendments relate to the parental income test as it applies to young people living away from home. Under the Bill, a person does not qualify for a benefit if the child lives away from home for a continuous period of at least six months. We are talking about a group of young people in the under-18 age group whose potential income has been reduced by virtue of the job search allowance being $25. One of the ways in which they can reach the $50 maximum-I might add that because of the failure of the previous amendment, that is a pegged maximum-is by not being supported in any way and, therefore, not being subject to the parental income test.

It seems to the Australian Democrats that it is particularly draconian to require a person to live away from home for six months in order to qualify for the extra $25. I cannot imagine for one minute why it cannot be shown that a child has left home if that child has been away from home for less than six months. When my children have lived away from home, I have known whether they have left home or not. I know that it is a feature of children of this age group, and even older age groups, who have left home to move back again. But I do not think that the problems faced by young people living away from home have been taken into account. The first of these amendments is designed to reduce the time in which a person must have been away from home in order to qualify for the full amount to six weeks, which I think is far more reasonable. Even that is of some concern. The reasons young people leave home are stated in the October newsletter of the Institute of Family Studies. It referred to a report by Frank Maas which points out that research shows that family conflict is one of the main reasons youth leave home and that low income groups are more prone to such outcomes. In those circumstances, it seems that a six-week period for qualification is not too much to ask for. This amendment also attempts to delete the requirement for a person to have been in full time employment at some point during that period. Item (ii) of proposed new section 121A requires a person to be employed on a full time basis for a period of, or for periods that in the aggregate constitute, at least 13 weeks. In the circumstances that family conflict is a major reason for youth leaving home and that low income groups are more prone to leaving home, and given that these are the sorts of groups, the disadvantaged young people, who are least likely to get employment, it seems that the combination that is in this legislation will make it an enormously high hurdle for young people to clear in order to qualify for additional benefits and not to come under the parental income test.

This raises the whole question of what the Government is on about when it talks about young people. Again, these issues are raised in the same article in the Australian Institute of Family Studies newsletter. The question is who should bear the responsibility for the upkeep of young people. The report points out that it used to be that the status of student presented the most problems, that it was difficult to reconcile the way student benefits were structured with an answer to the question of who has the responsibility. Since the May statement, it has been difficult to find clarity in the status of unemployed youth. Previously, unemployed youth faced no family income test for their benefit payments. The assumption was that a young person should be treated in his or her own right once that person entered the work force. That was, one would suggest, a reasonable assumption because surely workers, or potential workers, should be regarded as fully fledged members of society. Unemployed workers surely should be regarded no differently. Those over 21 years of age are treated accordingly. There seems to be now a tacit assumption that families will carry the extra burden.

Inherent in many of the various measures which have been taken and which are being taken there are many problems because at the same time support within the family has been withdrawn for older children. Family allowances were first withdrawn from the 18- to 24-year-old dependants and for 16- to 17-year-olds once the income reached $39,000 per annum. Eligibility for Austudy depends on family income. While I would not suggest for a minute that low income families should not receive assistance for supporting teenage children, it is a fact that it is only families on very low incomes who receive support for dependent teenage children. We have referred often in this debate to the removal of the supporting parent's benefit once the youngest child reaches the age of 16. This is a conflict because that removal is consistent with the view that young people should be accorded more independent status at that age. The Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson), who was at the table when I raised this matter earlier in this debate, said just that-that the idea is that 16-year-olds are independent. Yet the Government is making it as difficult as it possibly can with this provision for young people to avoid being disqualified from family support under the parental income test. So that is the reason for that amendment.

Amendments Nos (20) and (21) address an issue which was raised earlier in an amendment, the issue of whether the income of the previous financial year should be the only income which is taken into account. I have raised the point that there can be great fluctuations in income at any time. If that happens in the first six months of any financial year it can be greatly detrimental. I give the example of a young person who had applied for Austudy and whose parents separated in July 1987. The mother's only source of income then was a small amount of maintenance. Under the current rule, the mother's income was taken as being the amount it was for the financial year 1986-87, that is, the father's salary. The drop in income will not be taken into account while the current legislation stands until 1 January 1988. That is the sort of circumstance that can occur and it is the reason for amendments Nos (20) and (21).

In this whole exercise there are some problems with Government policy in relation to young people, whether they are or are not considered independent. I stress that, while low income families receive some support-it is acknowledged that there is additional support for those families-there are problems in regard to family stability which have been outlined, particularly in regard to the removal of the sole parent benefit. In the whole exercise and, in particular, in the case of the job search allowance and the removal of the unemployment benefit, it can be young people from low income families who suffer most. It is very often those young people for whom the school curriculum does not cater. I instance the recent removal by the Government of special programs which have catered for those young people-the participation and equity program and the disadvantaged schools program-and the demise of the Commonwealth Schools Commission, not to mention the Government's lack of commitment to the community youth support scheme, which suits those for whom more structured programs are not appropriate.

I remind the Senate that today three of those programs were closed down without any warning or explanation other than that they had been under review. Two programs were in my own State of Victoria, in Elwood and Collingwood, and the other program was in Queensland. I do not know what the young people in those areas are going to do. They have not been told. In speaking to these amendments, I raise those significant issues with relation to Government policy for this particular group of young people-low income, unemployed people, particularly those under 18 years of age.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (22) Page 37, clause 42, proposed subsection 122 (1), lines 29 to 37, leave out the proposed subsection, insert the following subsection:

`` `(1) subject to subsection (2), where an unemployment benefit is payable to a person whose income exceeds $60 per fortnight, who has attained the age of 25 years and has received such a benefit for at least 6 months during the preceding 12 month period, the rate per week of that benefit shall be reduced in accordance with the assets test applying to pensioners.''.

This amendment relates to the assets test provisions as they are to apply to beneficiaries under this legislation. The legislation introduces the assets test provision for beneficiaries and, while there is no fundamental objection to the principle, the concern being addressed by this amendment is that which is raised by the different application of the assets test provisions to beneficiaries as opposed to pensioners. The assets test, as it applies to beneficiaries, brings with it a `sudden death', in a sense, in that there is no sliding scale for the benefit once the threshold is reached as there is in the case of pensions.

It was interesting to look at the response when this matter was raised by Opposition members in the House of Representatives. In response to those concerns, the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) made the point that benefits tended to be essentially short term and that a person with substantial assets but without income for a short period was not comparatively badly off. He went on to point out that the situation was different for pensioners who were often on a pension for a longer period. The Minister went on to say:
Administrative reasons played a part in the decision to go for the `sudden death' assets test. Administratively, it is a much simpler test.

That was the Minister's response. I think we should look at the claim that benefits tend to be short term. Certainly, the age pension is a payment which can go on for a great many years. Let us look at the situation with benefits. In 1975, the average duration of the payment of unemployment benefit to a person was 12.7 weeks. In October this year the average duration of unemployment was 46.8 weeks. The number of Australians unemployed for six months or more has risen from 32,800 in 1975 to 283,500 this year-a nine-fold increase. Quite clearly, it is difficult to claim that the unemployment benefit is a short term benefit, and should this trend continue it will be even more difficult to claim that. What we are saying in this amendment is that while there is no fundamental objection to a fair asset test system for qualifying for benefits, if it is to apply it should apply in the same way to beneficiaries as it applies to pensioners. I commend the amendment to the Committee.

The last one related in particular to young people. Despite the fact that there is a box full of advisers next to the Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services (Senator Ryan), she has not bothered to respond to any of the concerns that Senator Powell has raised. It is bad enough that in the period of its government it has turned its back on pensioners, homeless young people and people on the unemployment benefit; it is far worse when somebody on this side of the chamber moves an amendment aimed at restoring some of the lost benefits and reducing some of the hardship and the Minister does not even bother responding to the criticisms.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before we proceed to deal with this clause, I must point out that Senator Powell's amendment No. (23) appears to be misplaced. I think that it should come after amendment No. (26), which is to clause 55. Do you agree, Senator Powell?

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, there is no doubt about it. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (24) Page 38, after clause 42 add the following new clause:
``42a. (1) Section 125 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection (3) `5' and substituting `13' ''.
(2) Section 125 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting from subsection 125 (3) ``paragraph (b) does'' and substituting ``paragraphs (b) and (c) do''.
(3) Section 125 of the Principal Act is amended by inserting after paragraph (3) (a) the following paragraph:
``(b) in the case where the claim is lodged more than 5 weeks prior to the day on which he became incapacitated-from and including the day 5 weeks before the day on which he became incapacitated.''.

This amendment addresses a problem which has arisen under the new rules introduced earlier this year, again in the May mini-Budget, whereby a person who claims sickness benefit for more than five-weeks after becoming qualified for that benefit cannot receive any back payment. The five week limit was imposed in the May mini-Budget. If the person applies within five weeks of being qualified, back payment will be made to the date on which the person became qualified. Previously, as I am sure honourable senators will remember, back payment was possible for up to 13 weeks. In our view, those who apply for sickness benefit more than five weeks but less than 13 weeks after being qualified should be entitled to back payment for five weeks prior to the date of application.

What is happening as a result of this is that genuine doctors certificates going back past the five-week period are being changed on the request of the recipients because they are not able to have that back payment. We are not asking that we go back to the pre-mini-Budget provision, but simply that between five and 13 weeks back payment should be possible for those people who do not get to making that application. Obviously, when it is an application for sickness benefit there can be a number of reasons why there is delay in the application being made. I commend the new clause to the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State)

TALK.START.PARA: —Paragraph 168 (4) (d) is primarily concerned with increases in the rate of pension. It allows this to be done up to three months retrospectively in certain circumstances. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (23) Page 42, clause 55, after paragraph (b) add the following new paragraph:

``(bb) by omitting from subsection (2) ``unless the person complies with the reasonable requirements of the Secretary, with respect to any such matter'' and substituting ``unless the person complies with the reasonable requirements of the Secretary, which shall be provided in writing, with respect to any such matter.''

This amendment is brought forward because of concerns which surround the activity test as it applies to job search allowance recipients and new measures introduced in this legislation and, in particular, in this clause. The imposition of requirements for unemployment benefit recipients has been extended, in particular the requirement which may be made for those recipients to undertake courses of training of one kind or another. This amendment simply seeks to make it necessary for that requirement to be in writing.

We believe that this is necessary because it is a matter which will not be consistent; it will occur from time to time. The requirement will not be something which is necessarily regular for all recipients on all occasions. Therefore, if it is a requirement which is not in writing, it is considered by us to be open to substantial abuse. Therefore, I have moved this amendment to ensure that when there is a requirement for the attendance at any course on referral by the Commonwealth Employment Service, then it should be in writing, because if that requirement is not met, then the allowance is withdrawn. We believe that it needs to be in writing for the protection of the recipient so that there is no misunderstanding in the circumstance where that requirement is not met. I commend this amendment to the Committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) has not yet responded on this amendment. I think it is important, particularly from the point of view of people being able to go to the relevant tribunal with regard to the denial of their rights on any particular occasion. One can well imagine in these types of circumstances that, unless a person is able to show in writing that a direction has been given, it would be very difficult for the bureaucrats to be able to prove in a tribunal that such a direction had been given. I think it is for the protection of both sides that a written direction should be made available in preference to an oral direction, which can always be disputed and will often be disputed in those circumstances where a denial of pensions or benefits is likely.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State)
