SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (27) Page 44, clause 63, proposed section 12, definition of ``application day'', lines 19 to 26, leave out the definition, insert the following definition:

`` `review period' in relation to a veteran who has made a claim for a pension or an application for an increase in the rate of a pension or a veteran on whose behalf such a claim or application has been made means that period up to and including the date of determination by the Repatriation Commission or the Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal as the case may be.''.
(28) Page 44, clause 64, proposed subsection 19 (2a), line 37, leave out ``on the application day'', insert ``during the review period''.
(29) Page 44, clause 64, after proposed subsection 19 (2a) add the following new subsection:

``(2ab) Subject to section 24a, a veteran shall be entitled to the rate of pension provided for by section 23 or 24, if the veteran is a veteran to whom that section has applied at any time up to and including the date of the decision of the Repatriation Commission, Veterans' Review Board or the Administrative Appeals Tribunal, as the case may be.''.
(30) Page 45, clause 65, proposed paragraph 24a (c), lines 19 to 21, leave out the paragraph, insert the following paragraph:

``(c) in the case of a veteran to whom section 24 applies-the veteran's age or length of time out of employment shall not be taken into account in determining what prevents the veteran from continuing in employment, if the veteran ceased employment as a result of the veteran's war-caused injury or war-caused disease alone.''.

Honourable senators will be aware that it was the stated intention of the Government in proposing these clauses that they overcome a difficulty which flowed from some legal judgment which threatened the continuity of totally and permanently incapacitated pensions for recipients beyond the age of 65. It is argued by the Government that these clauses resolve those difficulties and ensure continuity. I have received counter argument from legal counsel to the effect that these clauses do not achieve what they are intended to achieve. It is argued by legal counsel of veterans' groups that the provisions of clauses 63, 64 and 65, which introduce the concept of the application day, fail to preserve continuity and, even worse, as I said in my speech at the second reading stage, they make it extremely difficult to seek a special rate pension successfully in the future.

The departmental legal opinion differs from this. It appears that the two bodies of opinion-both learned, informed and well intentioned-arrive at different interpretations of the legal effects of these clauses. I have been asked to represent the views of those whose interpretation says that the legal effect of the clauses is not to ensure continuity and in fact is potentially to deprive applicants who might otherwise be worthy. It is argued that we are facing a veritable minefield of litigation if this ambiguity is not resolved. I am advised that these amendments resolve the ambiguity. I am also advised that the ambiguity flows out of the ambiguity of a legal judgment in relation to the matter of Banovich. I am told that on the one hand this judgment can be interpreted in a sense that is favoured by the Department of Veterans' Affairs and on the other hand in another legal sense that is favoured by veteran litigants. Therefore we have a serious legal ambiguity on our hands.

It is argued that the introduction of an application day imposes an absolute time limit, which is unjust in that it imposes in a legal sense a limitation of action which is inappropriate in this type of legislation. In fact, I am assured that honourable senators are aware that such a limit to action is very uncommon in this type of legislation and is judged to be quite inappropriate. In almost all other areas there is provision for discretion. Such provision is excluded by these clauses. The Veterans Advocates Advisory Group briefly summarises its legal objections to clauses 63, 64 and 65 in a letter which it sent to most, if not all, senators. Its first observation is:
All the criteria of the TPI must be considered on only one day...
That is, should this concept of an application day be affirmed. Its second observation is:
Most veterans are unaware of when is the most appropriate time to lodge their application and may inadvertently disentitle themselves...
That is, as a result of this focusing on a specific application day. The third observation is:
Even a single day difference might disentitle a veteran; there is no discretion.
It is observed that this was probably not intended, but it is argued that that is the legal effect. The fourth observation is:
There are Sections in the Act which, by their nature, presuppose views up to the date of hearing review. These clauses are inconsistent with those Sections.
In other words, this body of legal opinion is citing internal contradiction within the Act as it will be amended should these clauses proceed. Its fifth observation is:
Like suffering and loss due to war service should merit like compensation. That is not achieved when compensation can depend simply on when the Department receives a piece of paper.

In short, the observation of those who put forward this learned legal opinion is that there will be a veritable minefield of litigation. It must be resolved by the amendments which they have advocated that I move on their behalf. They are not contending that any ill will is intended, but rather that there is genuine legal ambiguity that must be resolved in the interests of the veterans.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State)

TALK.START.PARA: —Apparently, the amendments being proposed by the Australian Democrats are seen as advantaging veterans. However, they are unclear in their effect and could have the result of depriving particular veterans of a pension at a higher rate. For example, is it intended that veterans must comply with the totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) eligibility criteria over the whole of the review period? What would the result be if a veteran meets the TPI criteria for part of the period and then fails to meet the criteria for the rest of the period? These amendments would go well beyond the broadest view of what is the current law by enabling TPI eligibility to be tested at any date before an application for an increase in pension has been lodged.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has asked the Department of Veterans' Affairs monitoring committee to address the issue of up to date assessment in its report on the operation of the Veterans' Entitlements Act. This course is much preferable to supporting the amendments put forward by the Democrats. Amendment (30), which would remove the new paragraph 24a (c) from the Bill, would have the effect of enabling a TPI pensioner to keep his TPI pension even though he was working more than eight hours a week. It would make a mockery of the existing TPI eligibility criteria.

Amendment (30) would also seek to insert a new paragraph 24a (c). The proposed amendment is a nonsense; it would have no effect. Paragraph 24a (c) currently specifies one of the exceptions to the continuation of payment of the TPI pension for the life of the veteran. That exception is where the veteran becomes capable of working more than eight hours a week. That is one of the basic eligibility criteria for the TPI pension. The proposed amendment would say that it is an exception to the rule that a TPI pension is payable for life where the veteran's age or health shall not be taken into account in determining a claim. This is a nonsense. It does not make any sense.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I have said, there are simply two bodies of legal thought on this matter. The body of legal interpretation which I am representing in these amendments simply rejects those observations. It does so sincerely and accepts the alternative interpretation, but it simply does not acknowledge it. If I may cite an anomaly, under the proposed legislation if there are two veterans retiring early, one lodging an application on the last day of employment and the other one month after that time but otherwise equal, the first will be disentitled whilst the other will not.

SPEECH.PARA: The two additional amendments which extend beyond the application day controversy simply cite that there are injustices which flow out of the circumstances of needing to fulfil three criteria on one day. I am told that on many occasions it would simply be impossible for all three criteria to be filled on one day-namely, the application day. So, quite clearly, we are dealing with two learned bodies of legal opinion which simply differ over the interpretation of this and say that we will be in trouble if we proceed with the amendments in their present form.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I remember when we debated the original legislation some time ago. In fact, the original legislation took well over a year to come to completion. At the time I had the carriage of veterans for my Party. There was a division on this matter and my Party opposed the insertion of the clauses which eventually were the subject of a court case and caused such enormous trouble. I think it is interesting that, at that time, we got much the same type of answer from the Minister as we are currently getting from the Minister; that is, an airy wave of the arm and the suggestion that it is absurd. It so happens that the court case was resolved in our favour, not in the Government's favour, so the Minister should be relatively careful about that.

SPEECH.PARA: By inserting the types of conditions that were inserted after the age of 65, which is where the problems came from in the previous exercise, we ended up with a judgment from the court with regard to the continuing test. Really, this is where we are hung up at the moment in terms of this legislation. I do not think that these clauses will meet the problem that the court has posed. Essentially, the problem that we were faced with was an interpretation by the court which, in many ways and certainly in a number of its aspects, I consider to be basically absurd. Here I think I would agree with at least one comment of the Special Minister of State-that the court made a judgment that somehow or other it was the intention of this Parliament to create a test in respect of totally and permanently incapacitated (TPI) ex-servicemen. I think when one goes back and reads the Hansard one will see that this was not the intention of the Government, the Opposition, the Australian Democrats or anyone who contributed to that debate. So, in essence, I think the court judgment was obviously an absurd one in terms of the legislation which was passed. Nevertheless, the court made that judgment, we are stuck with it and we have to try to get back out of it. Unfortunately I think that the legislation before us will not clarify the position.

I accept the point raised by the Minister that in trying to move to correct the basic position one might end up disadvantaging a different group of veterans. I think that could probably happen in respect of our amendments. It is a case of deciding which group of veterans would be least disadvantaged. We believe that our amendments would disadvantage the smallest group of veterans in terms of the amount of pension they may lose. The only way to make sure that nobody is disadvantaged is to return to the previous position in which TPI pensioners were placed, which is, of course, what we advocated in the first place. The Government does not intend to do that. Instead, it intends to rely on the monitoring committee, which, I also remind honourable senators, was set up at the instigation of my Party. I think we will find that, after this legislation is enacted, the monitoring committee will come back with evidence of an identical set of problems for a different group of veterans. I believe it would be far better if we adopted the Australian Democrats' amendments and then moved on to try to come to some constructive resolution of the problem.
Question put:
That the amendments (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 10.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Chairman do now leave the chair and report to the Senate.
Question resolved in the negative.
Clauses 63 to 65 agreed to.
Clauses 66 to 75-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clauses 77 to 81-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Remainder of Bill and clause 76, as amended-by leave-taken together.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (31) That the House of Representatives be requested to make the following amendment: Page 56, clause 82, proposed paragraph 85 (4) (aa) lines 24 and 25, leave out all words after `during', insert `the periods referred to as `periods of hostilities' as defined in subsection 35 (1);'.
Page 56, after clause 83, insert the following clause:
`83a. Section 90 of the Principal Act is repealed and the following section substituted:
`Treatment principles

`90. (1) The regulations may prescribe treatment principles, setting out circumstances in which, and conditions subject to which, treatment of a particular kind, or included in a particular class of treatment, may be provided under this Part for, or in respect of, eligible persons-
(a) by the Commission at a hospital or other institution operated by the Commission;
(b) at a hospital or other institution in respect of which the Commission has entered into arrangements under paragraph 89 (1) (b) or (c); or
(c) otherwise under this Part.

(2) Without limiting the generality of subsection (1), the regulations may specify kinds of classes of treatment that will not be provided for, or in respect of, eligible persons under this Part, or will not be so provided at places, or in circumstances, specified or described in the regulations.
(3) The provisions of the regulations made under subsection (1) are binding on the Commission in the exercise by it of its powers and discretions under this Part.
(4) In this section `eligible person' means a person eligible under section 85, 86, 87 or 88 to be provided with treatment.'.'.

Presumably it has been noted by those who have been listening this evening that for all divisions on the amendments that have been moved to the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Bill this evening, we have witnessed the extraordinary sight of the Australian Democrats and Independents voting on one side, and the Government, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia voting together to defeat all the amendments, some of the most important and constructive amendments that have come before this chamber since I have been here.
Opposition senators-Oh!

TALK.START.PARA: —Honourable senators may not believe it but I speak for myself. I really believe it. I now address myself to the two remaining amendments, the first of which seems innocuous. It simply asks that we grant the same veterans' entitlements to women as we grant to male servicemen. I would be surprised if the amendment were opposed by either the Government or the Opposition. It is a fairly simple proposition that servicewomen be acknowledged to the same degree as servicemen. That is my proposed amendment to clause 82.

SPEECH.PARA: My amendment to clause 83 I believe to be a much more emotional proposition. I think most people would have registered by now that it is the proposal of the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys), exercising his privilege, to impose, as from 1 January 1988, a penalty or a fee of $111 per week on all totally and permanently incapacitated pensioners in nursing homes. It is a tragic coincidence that, on 1 January 1988 when we begin the celebration of the nation this will be the happy new year present which will be extended by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs to totally and permanently incapacitated Australians, many of whom have been totally and permanently incapacitated for most of their lives.

TALK.START.PARA: —Shame!

—It is a shameful decision carried out at the discretion of the Minister. The amendment proposes to remove the privilege of the Minister of introducing this variation to the circumstances of totally and permanently incapacitated veterans in nursing homes and to demand or insist that it be done under regulation, which gives the right of denial to the Parliament. In moving this amendment I register the absolute disgust of the Australian Democrats that this amendment is necessary.
—I call Senator Richardson.
—Now you are going to tell us what you have got against ex-servicewomen.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —I have nothing against ex-servicewomen. They are indeed great Australians, Senator Haines, and I, along with the Government, want to do all we can to help them. In accordance with the Government's election commitment, clause 82 currently extends such rights to ex-servicewomen of World War II only. The previous Minister, Senator Gietzelt, in response to a request from the Returned Services League (RSL) commissioned a study into the particular circumstances of these women. The study identified discrimination against them and disadvantages, so that the Government's extension of treatment rights was directly an acknowledgment of the results of the study. However, the circumstances that applied to those women did not apply to women who gave service in later conflicts. Indeed, the RSL gave assurances that the extension would not be seen as a precedent for other claims in the future. No case has been made out, and accordingly the Government opposes the requested amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: As far as the amendment to replace section 90 is concerned, I do not think there is sufficient understanding on the part of the Democrats as to the complexities--

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not think there is sufficient concern on your part.

—Senator Haines, remain calm. I do not think there is sufficient understanding on the part of the Democrats as to the complexities of the treatment principles. The treatment principles existing under section 90 are set out in detail and veterans are able to obtain copies of them. They can therefore understand what is to be or what is not. The document is, of course, readily available to them, but the important thing is that it is readily adaptable to changes and circumstances, given of course the safeguard that the Minister would have to approve any change. That document is easily understood by veterans and its flexibility would be lost if we were to agree to this amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: I am not sure whether Senator McLean is aware of the time that it would take to put all of those treatment principles into regulations. If the Government were to agree to his amendment the inevitable result would be a time lag. That would mean that there would be uncertainty and no guide whatsoever to veterans and their dependants for an intolerable amount of time. Obviously that is not what veterans want, it is not what the Government wants and it is why the amendment should be rejected.

TALK.START.PARA: —What an extraordinary reply from the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson). First he tells us that a study has been made into the circumstances of ex-servicewomen who served in Korea, Malaya and Vietnam and that their circumstances differ from those of the servicewomen who served in the two previous world wars. What a profound observation that was. Of course their circumstances vary, and they are likely to change from today. Many of those women are, we hope, likely to live many years, and their circumstances will change profoundly. The observation I made about the legislation and the introduction of the concept of an application day applies exactly the same rigidity of thought as the Minister has attempted to impose on us in that ridiculous observation he has just made. As for saying that totally and permanently incapacitated veterans in nursing homes, many of whom are in their nineties, should be in the slightest bit concerned about the fact that it might take some time to produce some regulations which will impose upon them, or not impose upon them, a fee of $111, that is just a whole lot of verbal gobbledegook. The Minister has tried to confuse us with words and tried to pretend that he has responded to an observation that, as from 1 January 1988, he has the right to inform the veterans in writing that they will get a bill of $111 a week for the rest of their lives. They are non-responses. If the Minister cares to try again, please do.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator McLean is new in this place, so I will accept that he does not understand. But just in case there is some mistake about the words-although, having checked, I see there is certainly no mistake-I did not say that a study had been commissioned into the circumstances of women involved in conflicts later than World War II. I said-and I repeat it so that the honourable senator will understand-that a study was done of the circumstances of women who had been involved in World War II. The Returned Services League of Australia (RSL) had requested such a study. The Government responded to the request. The RSL made it clear at the time that it did not believe that that was setting a precedent for women involved in later conflicts.

SPEECH.PARA: I do not think I have made any extraordinary statements. They are quite normal and they are in accordance with the wishes of the RSL. The Government has therefore acted properly. As far as I am concerned, the only extraordinary statement that has been made tonight on this question is that the veterans we are talking about are in their nineties. The average age is the late sixties. Those in their late sixties would definitely be concerned about the undue delay in certainty as to what their entitlements were likely to be if the Government were to agree to the amendment, and therefore it cannot.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt at all about what will happen to these people. They will receive a bill for $111 a week for the rest of their lives. There is no conjecture, no doubt, no need for them to get it in writing in an envelope from the Minister, because they are hearing it tonight. They heard it admitted two weeks ago by the Minister for Local Government, Senator Reynolds, when she responded to my questions in her capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs (Mr Humphreys). There is no conjecture about it. These people know that if the Minister has his way, without a response from the Parliament, which is what this amendment provides for, they will get a bill for $111 a week for the rest of their lives, beginning on the first day of the celebration of the nation. I cannot imagine anything more offensive for totally and permanently incapacitated veterans, many of whom have been that way for most of their lives. I cannot comprehend how a government could make such a decision. There are only 750 people involved. Many of them are very aged and very infirm and have been very infirm for most of their lives. It is the most extraordinary, dispassionate, crude decision I have heard from a government.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —Not only have I been accused today of being insensitive; I am now accused of being dispassionate. This is really going too far. As far as the specifics--
—I will throw in `sexist' and `discriminatory', if you like.
—I certainly have not been sexist.
—You have, on the question of ex-servicewomen's rights.

—I have not; perish the thought. Most of the beneficiaries about whom we are now speaking and who are in nursing homes currently meet the patient contribution. However, at present the Repatriation Commission accepts financial responsibility for the patient contribution of those beneficiaries who have been specifically admitted to nursing homes as a result of war-caused disabilities. The exemption from the patient contribution of any group will create an inequitable situation, as in a relatively small number of cases no contribution is being made towards board and lodging. These patients would be responsible for their maintenance at home or in hostels. The absence of such a contribution could in some circumstances create a financial incentive for institutional care. I would not have thought that there was anything dispassionate, sexist, discriminatory or insensitive in any of the remarks that I made. Certainly none of them would be--
—Uncaring; you forgot `uncaring'.

—`Uncaring' is the word that I was just about to use. Great minds think alike, as they say. I would have thought that at this point it might have been appropriate for Senator McLean to withdraw his amendment in view of the explanation that I have given.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In his first response in regard to service women, the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) said that no case had been made out. I put to the Committee that no case needs to be made out. These women are service women. No case is made out for servicemen. The case is that they have served their country. The case for service women is identical-they have served their country. They do not need to go cap in hand to the Government in order to be treated in the same fashion as men. Just because it took 40 years for this Government or any government to deal with service women from World War II in the same way as it dealt with servicemen, why should the service women from Korea and Vietnam have to wait another 40 years?

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister then compounded his rather absurd statement about going cap in hand and making out a special case for being women, which is basically what he was saying--

TALK.START.PARA: —Nonsense!

—Senator Richardson was saying that he said that no special case had been made out. These women do not have to make out a special case; they merely have to have served their country. They should only have to merely serve their country in order to be dealt with in the same way as servicemen. The Minister's second argument was even more absurd than the first. He said that the reason the Government changed its mind over the Second World War service women was that it had done a study. The reason that it will not change its mind over the service women from Korea and Vietnam is that it has not done a study. That probably takes the cake for one of the most absurd reasons in the entire debate for not doing anything. The Government has not made a study and therefore it will not do anything.

SPEECH.PARA: If the Government would say that it is undertaking a study and as a result of that it might do something, then we would revert to the first problem. But now we have two distinct problems as a result of the answers the Minister has given. First, service women somehow or other must make out a special case because they are women and, secondly, the Government will not undertake a study. It has undertaken a study on World War II service women and has decided that they need some assistance but it has not done a study on women who served in Vietnam and Korea, so it has decided they do not need any assistance. As a matter of prima facie logic, I would suggest that as the Government has done a study of women who served in the Second World War and has discovered that they should be treated in the same way as servicemen from the Second World War, if it did a study of the women who served in Vietnam and Korea it would probably come up with the unmistakable conclusion that they should be treated in the same way as men who served in Vietnam and Korea. That seems to be a reasonable proposition.

Finally, we have a situation in which we will have an undue delay on the other matter. That is very good coming from this Minister because it is a classic case taken right out of the Yes Minister series. One of the reasons given in this celebrated series for not doing something was that it would take an inordinate time to get round to making regulations. I wish that I had written down the Minister's words tonight because they probably came right out of the actual text. To claim, in this place, that the reason we cannot amend legislation is that the bureaucrats will take an awfully long time to do their job is an extraordinary proposition. In fact, regulations can be drafted overnight. I have seen it in this place when the Government has had to move that quickly in order to get regulations made in that time. When I originally came into this place and the Fraser Administration was in office, I was in this chamber at 2 o'clock one morning-a stage we may reach tonight-and I was told that it would take three days to get a Bill from here to the House of Representatives and back again. It took exactly three-quarters of an hour for the Bill involved to do that. But I was told there would be an inordinate delay. We are told every year that things are urgent, but if we have an election they are no longer urgent. We are told all sorts of things as an excuse for not doing something. Let us have a reason why we should not do it and I will debate the reason but let not the Minister come in here and say that the bureaucrats will take an awfully long time to get the regulations done.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —There may be an excuse for Senator McLean; there is no such excuse for Senator Macklin. I will go through a number of the points that he has raised. First, I have not stated at any time that the reason we have not extended benefits is that a study has not been done. Let us look at what normally happens with veterans' matters. The organisation that represents the interests of veterans is not the Australian Democrats, thank God. I might say that veterans thank God that that is not the case as well. The Returned Services League (RSL) does it. I know the Australian Democrats are upset tonight, however I wish they would listen even for just a moment. I sat in abject silence and listened to the Democrats.
—At the end of this night the veterans will know who represent them. The numbers will indicate it. It will be in the Hansard.

—Senator McLean should take three deep breaths, not just one. On the points raised by Senator Macklin, it must be remembered that the Government will respond to representations from the RSL properly. When it brings forward a case the Government will look at the case and if it is proven the Government will act. The Government did act. But let us remember that what we have done here, if anything, is discriminate against men, not against women.
—Oh!

—This has naught to do with the United States alliance and naught to do with trees. I ask Senator Sanders please to remain totally calm. World War II service women will have treatment rights without-I repeat, without-a specific repatriation entitlement. Servicemen do not have that. They do not have access to treatment without a specific repatriation entitlement, as Senator McLean would know. So if anything this legislation discriminates against men.

SPEECH.PARA: I find Senator Macklin's point quite extraordinary. He suggests that all these regulations can be drafted overnight-there is no great problem, the complexities or the size do not matter, tomorrow morning we can trot out to the Governor-General's and have them all signed. Let us have a look at what that entails. I have here the treatment principles. They are not on one page; they go through to page 51. They are complex principles. To put those properly drafted into regulations would take time. It cannot be done overnight. It would not matter who was in government, it just cannot be done. All of the Democrats know that and posing will not change the position one bit.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McLean Sen P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have to give some credit to the Minister: he is trying to defend an almost indefensible position. I would like to shift the focus now from the inadequate responses of the Government to what is clearly a totally callous imposition. In a few minutes when we have a division on this matter once again we will witness the extraordinary fact that the Opposition will vote with the Government to enforce this precise thing. I am pleased that the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Chaney) is in the chamber to defend this action. The Opposition's justification will be that it sees this Bill as a Budget Bill. The Opposition has voted with the Government on all these amendments because it defines this as a Budget Bill and therefore it hides behind this extraordinary umbrella. It will support this extraordinary proposal on the ground that supposedly this is a Budget Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: If Opposition senators care to go to the offices of the Senate, they can get a superb paper which was written to educate the likes of us about the distinction between Budget Bills, Appropriation Bills and the like. It will clearly establish that Opposition senators are hiding behind an umbrella in saying that this is a Budget Bill when in fact the Appropriation Bills were passed, giving the money to the Government, the week before last. This is not a Budget Bill; it is all about principle; it is all about policy. Therefore, I believe that Opposition senators will have to think very seriously, when a division is called on this matter, about whether they support it.
Question put:
That the request and the amendment (Senator McLean's) be agreed to.

DIVISION.RESULT.PARA: Question so resolved in the negative.

SPEECH.PARA: Remainder of Bill and clause 76, as amended, agreed to.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The CHAIRMAN

TALK.START.PARA: —The question now is that the Bill be reported.

INTERJECT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Richardson) agreed to:
Leave out all words after `That', insert clauses 3, 11 and 76 be reconsidered'.
Clauses 3, 11 and 76.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RICHARDSON
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for the Environment and the Arts)

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, clause 3, after subclause (9) insert the following subclause:
``(10) The amendment made by subsection 76 (2) applies to payments under the Veterans' Entitlements Act 1986 that fall due on or after 13 November 1987.
Commencement: Day of Royal Assent''.
(2) Page 10, clause 11, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:
``(2) Section 7 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (4) and substituting the following subsection:
`(4) Where:

(a) the amount per annum of the reduction under subsection (3) in the maximum annual rate of pension, benefit (other than a benefit under Part XIII) or allowance applicable to a person in respect of property of the person or the person's spouse that is property referred to in paragraph (1) (c) is less than the lesser of the following amounts per annum:
(i) the amount per annum equal to 2.5% of the value of that property;
(ii) the amount per annum that could reasonably be expected to be obtained from a purely commercial application of that property; or
(b) there is no reduction under subsection (3) in respect of that property;
the maximum annual rate of pension, benefit or allowance applicable to the person shall:
(c) in a case to which paragraph (a) applies-be further reduced by the difference between that first-mentioned reduction and that lesser amount per annum; or
(d) in a case to which paragraph (b) applies-be reduced by that lesser amount per annum.'.
Commencement: 13 November 1987''.
(3) Page 11, Clause 11, leave out from paragraph (3) (g) ``greater'' (wherever occurring), insert ``lesser''.
(4) Page 53, Clause 76, after subclause (1) insert the following subclause:
``(2) Section 53 of the Principal Act is amended by omitting subsection (3) and substituting the following subsection:
`(3) Where:

(a) the amount per annum of the reduction under subsection (2) in the maximum annual rate of pension applicable to a person in respect of property of the person or the person's spouse that is property referred to in paragraph (1) (c) is less than the lesser of the following amounts per annum:
(i) the amount per annum equal to 2.5% of the value of that property;
(ii) the amount per annum that could reasonably be expected to be obtained from a purely commercial application of that property; or
(b) there is no reduction under subsection (2) in respect of that property;
the maximum annual rate of pension, applicable to the person shall:
(c) in a case to which paragraph (a) applies-be further reduced by the difference between that first-mentioned reduction and that lesser amount per annum; or
(d) in a case to which paragraph (b) applies-be reduced by that lesser amount per annum.'.
Commencement: 13 November 1987''.

The Government's proposal for the pension assets test hardship provisions I believe were already fair and equitable, cutting off loopholes to make sure that only those people who needed public income support got it. Nevertheless, given the attitude of the Opposition and the Australian Democrats and because of the need to get the Social Security and Veterans' Entitlements Amendment Bill through Parliament to enable the Government to pay the family package increases, the Government will agree to amend the Bill in the terms that I have circulated. The effect of the amendment will be that in cases where the amount that could reasonably be expected to be obtained from the commercial application of the property in question is less than 2.5 per cent of the value of the property, the 2.5 per cent need not apply. In moving this amendment, I undertake that where a farm is being operated by a family member of the pensioner, for example, the child of the pensioner, and it is not unreasonable to expect that farm to be used for other purposes, the provision will be amended and the legislation will be administered so that the overall financial situation of that family member will be taken into account in determining what rent, if any, that family member could reasonably be expected to pay.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Opposition welcomes the package of amendments, if they can be referred to as such. The amendments are as a result of negotiations by the Opposition with the Government prior to the dinner break this evening. The Government has produced these amendments in response to the coalition's concerns. To put it simply, the Government had planned a harsh application of the assets test to pensioners and veterans. The Opposition moved to have the clauses that would implement the harsher administration of the assets test referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Community Affairs and to remove the clauses from the Bill to allow that Committee to review them while giving the Government the remainder of the Bill.

SPEECH.PARA: The Government has responded to this pressure from the coalition by moving these amendments and giving an undertaking in respect of the guidelines. These amendments represent an acknowledgment that the Opposition's concerns were well founded in the first place. They represent an acknowledgment that what the Government was proposing had the potential to produce an excessively harsh effect on certain pensioners and veterans. With the passage of these amendments the situation will be substantially better than that which the Government was proposing to implement. The coalition is pleased that the Government has seen the light.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Powell Sen J.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats, too, welcome this package of amendments moved by the Minister. I think it is important to point out that the process which has led to the moving of these amendments will lead, therefore, as Senator Vanstone has said, to legislation that is fair and equitable and that meets the needs that were addressed in the original debate on these aspects of the assets test. This process has occurred because, uncharacteristically, the Opposition moved amendments which were supported by the Australian Democrats, we having proposed similar amendments to this legislation ourselves. I think that is an interesting demonstration of the fact that such agreement can be constructive, as it has been in this case. I am sure that the farming community and other people with considerable assets but problems in relation to the nature of those assets are pleased about that process.

SPEECH.PARA: I would not stand here and accuse the Government and the Opposition of having done a deal, even though they communicated over the dinner hour. I think it is absolutely marvellous that this kind of communication can take place and I hope that the next time we negotiate with either the Government or the Opposition, either on amendments similar to this or on others, we will not be accused of having done a deal either. If we are working in the interests of our constituents-which I believe the coalition was, just as we were, in this exercise-a resolution such as this is a just outcome. I think it is one that the Parliament should see very much more often, especially when it comes to Budget legislation which apparently now is no longer sacrosanct.
Amendments agreed to.
Bill reported with amendments; report adopted.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Motion (by Senator Richardson) proposed:
That the Bill be now read a third time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator CHANEY
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the Opposition)

TALK.START.PARA: —I am not keen to detain the Senate at this late hour, given that we have been sitting for some time, but I did want to make a couple of comments in light of the debate which has taken place in the committee stage of the Bill over the last half hour or so. There has been some comment on the fact that the Opposition has taken a general view that we should not support amendments which increase expenditure of the Commonwealth. The position of the Opposition is quite clear on that. We made a statement with respect to our general approach to Budget Bills.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the Senate that we have taken the view for some time that the level of government expenditure is excessive and that we have, therefore, been calling upon the Government to reduce government expenditure. In those circumstances, the Opposition has not seen it as consistent with its stance to turn around and support amendments which would increase the expenditure of the Government. I would like to make that point clear because I think it is a simple point and a point which is obviously of very great importance to the Opposition. We think it is an important point to be understood.

With respect to the matter which was the subject of debate at the end of the committee stage; namely the position of ex-servicewomen in certain theatres of war, there is certainly very great concern in the Opposition at what appears to us to be an inconsistency. The Government has in its amendments just moved by the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) accepted that the concerns of the Opposition warranted some attention and it has made adjustments to the assets test as it applies to that limited group of people who live on family farms usually with younger members of the family. Those farms are simply not producing enough to provide an income for the family which is working the farm and rent for the parents who still own the farm. So there is a genuine economic and social problem. The Opposition is pleased that the Government has acknowledged that by moving the amendments which pick up some of the Opposition's concerns.

My main point in rising now is to say to the Government that we think there is a genuine point of principle. I am pleased that Senator Ryan is in the chamber because she has a particular responsibility within the Government for matters which relate to the situation of women in Australia. I simply say to the Minister for the Environment and the Arts, who is at the table, and to Senator Ryan that I hope that they will take back to the Government the points which have been raised in debate, the concerns which were expressed in the second reading debate by Senator Vanstone on behalf of the Opposition about the extent to which there is a differentiation between male and female ex-service personnel in particular theatres of war.

On the simple point of principle that an Opposition which is continually saying to the Government that we think that government expenditure has to be controlled and, indeed, reduced, we are not prepared to then foist upon the Government on an ad hoc basis increases in expenditure because we do not see that as being a consistent and principled course of conduct. Given that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) today has announced a slightly better outcome with respect to Forward Estimates than he previously thought, I suspect the Government will see its way clear to make some adjustments on this matter. I certainly urge early consideration of them.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I gave notice earlier that I would be moving an amendment to the second reading motion of the Health Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987. I pointed out that the reason we were moving an amendment in this form rather than amending a particular clause of the Bill was related to the difficulty of getting that amendment drafted. Earlier we heard the Minister for the Environment and the Arts (Senator Richardson) speak to this matter. He used a rather contorted argument similar to the one we heard him use earlier this evening in relation to relative disadvantage. I now formally move:

SPEECH.PARA: At the end of the motion, add:
``, but the Senate is of the opinion that recipients of the job search allowance should be entitled to free pharmaceutical benefits without any further income test''.

Senator Richardson argued that if this amendment were carried those who were in receipt of the job search allowance would get an advantage compared with others who were unemployed and on unemployment benefits. I have already pointed out that the $62.50 per year which would be paid by somebody on job search allowance would represent between 1 1/2 and 2 1/2 weeks of his or her annual income, which is grossly in excess of the proportion which would be paid by a person on average weekly earnings in relation to his or her pharmaceutical payments should such a person reach the maximum limit of $250. The amount of $62.50 represents a much larger proportion of the income of those people on job search allowance. So clearly there is a disadvantage to the poor. The fact that a disadvantage may be caused to other groups who are poor, other young unemployed people, seems to me to be rather irrelevant. If such disabilities are imposed by the Government they should be addressed too. This amendment simply seeks to point out that with respect to this piece of legislation, which mentions these particular recipients, the Australian Democrats strongly support the view that these job search allowance recipients should be entitled to free pharmaceutical benefits.

Moreover, I pointed out earlier that, while the amounts involved are very significant in relation to the job search recipients, the amounts involved for the Government are indeed very small. I think that was conceded by Senator Richardson when he said that people in the 16- and 17-year-old age group are by and large pretty healthy. The group most in need of this help, of course, would be those 16- and 17-year-olds seeking jobs who have chronic illness of a nature which would not prevent them from seeking work provided they have medication. I instance those who suffer from such diseases as hay fever, asthma, diabetes and epilepsy-those people who, provided they have medication, are quite capable of both applying for and holding down jobs. I commend this amendment to the Senate and seek its support for it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ryan Sen The Hon S.M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator RYAN
TALKER.ROLE: Special Minister of State and Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health)

TALK.START.PARA: —I think Senator Richardson has already explained the Government's position on this proposal. It is not acceptable to the Government. In our view it would be inequitable to provide free pharmaceutical benefits to one group of unemployed persons and not extend the same benefit to all unemployed persons and their dependants. It is not considered unreasonable that job search allowance recipients make some contribution to the cost of their pharmaceutical benefits scheme prescriptions, as do all other persons receiving unemployment benefits.

The Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 1, subclause 2 (2), leave out `and paragraph 9 (a)' and `, and the first regulations made under paragraph 67 (1) (ac) of the Principal Act as amended by this Act,'.
(2) Page 3, paragraph 9 (a), leave out the paragraph.

The Opposition finds clause 9 of the Bill objectionable and totally unacceptable. Clause 9 seeks to insert new provisions into section 67 of the Migration Act. That section empowers the Governor-General to make regulations in respect of the operation of the Act. Clause 9 (a) of the Bill provides that a fee will be able to be charged against certain decisions taken under the Migration Act. The provision and the first regulations made under the provision are expressed under clause 2 of the Bill to come into effect on 16 September 1987, the day after the introduction of the 1987 Budget. The scheme was announced in the Budget. It was said then repeated in the Minister's second reading speech on this Bill, that the charge will initially be $240 for each appeal for reconsideration. The Government claims, according to the explanatory memorandum of this Bill, that:
This measure is associated with a significant increase in resources devoted to reconsideration of decisions under the Act, and is aimed at partial recovery of the costs relating to that process.

The Opposition acknowledges that this new fee, which might as well be called a tax, is a Budget measure. Because of this we are prepared to see the proposal introduced if, but only if, it meets basic parliamentary standards of legislative propriety. In its present form, the operative clause of the Bill, that is, clause 9 (a), does not do this. It is for this reason that I have moved the deletion of clause 9 (a) from the Bill.

Let me explain the reasons for the Opposition's approach to clause 9 (a). When the Migration Amendment Bill was being debated, and after the second reading stage, the Senate, on the motion of the Opposition, postponed its consideration in Committee of the Whole until the Senate had had an opportunity to consider the draft regulations to be made under clause 9. At that stage the regulations had not even been drafted, despite the fact that their content comprises the real essence of the Bill. Subsequently, last week the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) tabled draft regulations in the Senate. The copy that Senator Reynolds tabled was, I think, draft No. 6. Since then I have seen a copy purporting to be draft No. 12. There may well be more for all I know. We do not know, and we have not been told; nor have we been told how draft No. 6 differs from draft No. 12.

The draft which was tabled is obviously already out of date. In any event, it is long, complex and virtually incomprehensible. To the Opposition it is totally unsatisfactory. It does nothing to alleviate the concerns we had before we saw the draft, which concerns caused us to postpone further consideration of the Bill at the conclusion of the second reading stage.

However, there are other more serious reasons for our rejection of clause 9 (a). These reasons have been brought forcibly to the chamber's attention by the thirteenth report of 1987 of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills, dated 4 November. I understand that that Committee today reviewed its earlier report in the light of comments received by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, Mr Young, but decided not to change that report. In respect of clause 9 and sub-clause 2 (2), which triggers the timing of clause 9-I think it is sufficiently important to bear repeating in this chamber-it had this to say:
Subclause 2 (2) of the Bill provides that any regulations made under the proposed paragraph 67 (1) (ac)-
that is, clause 9 of this Bill-

shall be taken to have come into operation on 16 September 1987, the date on which it was announced that a fee (nominated to be $240) would be payable on application for reconsideration of prescribed decisions.
Research conducted within the Committee has been unable to find a comparable provision to subclause 2 (2) in the statutes.
The Committee strongly believes that this provision, announced at the time of the Budget, is offensive for the following reasons:
It is an apparently novel use of a Bill to attempt to retrospectively impose a fee by regulation.

The imposition of a fee retrospectively by regulation (which cannot be introduced until this Bill has passed the Parliament) is clearly contrary to the provisions of subsection 48 (2) of the Acts Interpretation Act, insofar as the regulations which would provide for retrospective imposition of a liability on a person would not be subject to consideration by the Parliament as required by the Acts Interpretation Act.
The description of the fee as a budget measure is being used to justify the retrospective imposition of a fee which appears to be aimed at recovery of costs, rather than realisation of revenue.

A further matter that should be drawn to Senators' attention is, fees that are payable on lodgment of appeals, on applications for review by courts, tribunals or other bodies have previously been imposed by legislation and have been fixed, as to the amount, by regulations which must be tabled in the Parliament.

That was a unanimous report of a committee comprising senators from the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party, the National Party and the Australian Democrats-every party represented in this chamber. It is a damning indictment of clause 9. Not only is the clause retrospective; so too are the regulations to be established as a result of the clause. The clause appears to be without precedent in our legislative history. No responsible parliament could permit the passage of such a clause. The Opposition is totally opposed to it, and I am very pleased to know that the Democrats share our view.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is our amendment.

—It is my amendment on behalf of the Opposition, Senator. But I am delighted that we are of like mind on this issue. Rejection of clause 9 by the Committee will mean that the Government will have no legislative basis, let alone any moral basis for the $240 charge. It is a disgraceful and classic example of this Government's incompetence and maladministration that fees have been collected, as I understand it, since 1 October in anticipation of this legislation being passed. The Opposition assumes that the Government will refund these fees already collected, and collected not on any legal basis, and will certainly not collect any more. (Quorum formed) I was saying that the Opposition assumes that the Government will refund the fees already collected since 1 October-fees that were obviously illegally collected, or collected certainly not on any legislative basis-and will certainly not collect any more fees unless and until new proposals are adopted by this Parliament in the future.

SPEECH.PARA: I repeat what I said earlier: The Opposition is not opposed in principle to the imposition of this charge, particularly as it is a Budget measure. It is the method that the Government has attempted to adopt to implement its proposal that is the essential basis of our objection. If the Government pursues this proposal and can find a proper and legislatively correct way of implementing it, we will consider it sympathetically and with appropriate expedition, presumably in the autumn session next year. But that is a matter for the Government.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Australian Democrats are opposed in principle to clause 9 (a). It is a totally obnoxious clause. We opposed the clause during the second reading debate, during which time my amendment opposing it was circulated. My amendment opposing it was also circulated earlier this afternoon. The $240 fee for change of status is totally obnoxious and repugnant to all migrants and intending migrants. They are paying, first and foremost, for a system which, as I described during my contribution to the second reading debate, is not really an appeal system. The immigration review panels are not true review panels. I was very surprised to find that the Government was comparing these panels with the Administrative Appeals Tribunal.

SPEECH.PARA: Migrants are being asked to pay $240 for a system of appeal which, in reality, is not an appeal. The people on the panels are appointed by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. The panels are only advisory and, for the most part, they simply rubber stamp the Minister's decision. For example, I know of one lawyer in Perth who represented 10 migrants in such appeals and all 10 were knocked back. Subsequently two appeals were upheld, only because these two people were able to act through a member of parliament. That does not seem to me to be a very just system.

This is retrospective legislation and the fee has already been collected. I was under the impression that the fee had been collected since 16 September, but whether it is 16 September of 1 October it means that a lot of migrants and prospective migrants have been paying a fee for which legislation has not yet been passed. Presumably the people who have paid this fee have just been put in the queue of 11,000-odd people who are waiting to have their appeals heard. Thus, they have paid $240 and they might have to wait a couple of years or so to have their appeals heard in any case. The Australian Democrats are against this clause and this fee. As Senator Short was able to be heard before I was, obviously we will support his amendment but not for the reasons he put forward. Senator Short has indicated that when the regulations are tidied up, he will support the fee. The Democrats will certainly not support it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I shall respond very briefly to Senator Jenkins. I did not say that we would approve the legislation if the regulations were tidied up. The problem is more fundamental than that. I hope I made that point clear during my remarks. I do not want the Minister for Local Government (Senator Reynolds) to be under any misapprehension on that score.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendments agreed to.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Jenkins Sen J.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Pages 2 and 3, clause 7, leave out the clause.

Clause 7 relates to the immigration clearance fee of $5 as stipulated in the regulations which we saw for the first time on 25 November. This fee will be collected by the international air operators. As I said previously, the whole system of having an entrance fee into this country is unsatisfactory. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills regarded this fee as a tax and not as a fee as the Government alleges. Because the Government regards it as a fee, it says that it cannot be added to the departure tax. Thus the $5 fee must be collected in a different way.

There is a major problem about the collection of this fee. The airlines were requested to work out how they would collect this fee, despite the fact that the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said that arrangements for the collection of the fee and its amount would be prescribed by regulation. As far as I can make out in all these regulations, which are very difficult to follow, there does not seem to be any statement about the arrangements for the collection of the fee. I have been led to believe by the Minister that the airlines are supposed to work this out for themselves. The airlines have sent a couple of detailed telexes to the Minister describing how difficult it is for them to do this. At this time of night I really do not want to go through all this-I have pages and pages of detailed descriptions of why various methods of collection of the fee by the airlines would be very difficult. I simply say that the Australian Democrats are opposed to the fee. It is going to cost the airlines probably as much as the $5 again to collect the fee. This will mean that airline ticket costs will go up the $5 plus whatever it costs the airlines to collect the fee. The Democrats are opposed to clause 7 and that is why we seek its removal from the Bill.
9-10 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 9-10 December 1987
9-10 December 1987 SENATE
Thursday, 10 December 1987

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —Whilst we have a great deal of sympathy for the Australian Democrats' views, we will not be supporting the amendment. I shall try to explain briefly why. As I said, whilst we cannot and will not reject a Budget measure outright-that is not what we in fact did with clause 9-we are amazed at the Government's imposition of the $5 fee, particularly so far as it relates to returning Australians. But it relates not just to them. It is a de facto tax on Australian citizens returning home from abroad. The Committee will recall that on 4 November during the second reading debate on this Bill I moved an amendment to the second reading motion to add the following words:

SPEECH.PARA: but the Senate is of the opinion that the imposition of a fee of $5 on Australian citizens returning to their own country by international air travel is an obnoxious attack on the fundamental right of Australians to enter their own country.

I also outlined in some detail our objections to this fee. Let me repeat just some of the problems that we see with it. The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of the Bills said with much justification that this so-called fee may be regarded as a form of taxation and the Committee pointed out that it has in the past consistently objected to the imposition of such imposts by way of regulation, rather than such provisions being contained in an Act of Parliament, and without a limit being set by legislation. The Committee concluded that the Bill may be considered to be an inappropriate delegation of the Parliament's fundamental taxing powers.

Our second objection is that to the extent that the fee applies to Australian citizens returning from abroad it can be regarded as an infringement of their right of free entry to their homeland. Thirdly, to the extent that the $5 fee applies to tourists or other non-Australians travelling to Australia it is really nothing other than an export duty or levy. It is a burden on our foreign exchange earning capacity. The Government says that it is attempting to boost our foreign exchange earnings. It says it wants to boost international tourism to Australia. So what does it do? It puts on another tax, another export duty, another burden on our capacity to earn foreign exchange. Fourthly, the imposition of the new entry tax breaks yet another of the Government's pre-election promises. Before the recent election both the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Treasurer (Mr Keating) said, `There will be no new taxes in the 1987 Budget'. So what do we find? Surprise, surprise, we find this new tax. Perhaps we should not be surprised: this Government's promises are like confetti to be blown away with the slightest breeze.
9-10 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 9-10 December 1987
9-10 December 1987 SENATE

Fifthly, the new tax is to be collected by the international airline operator which brought the passenger to Australia and then the airline operator is to pay the money over to the Government. The practical administrative difficulties in this are horrendous. The Government is getting the airlines to do its dirty work for it-a point that Senator Jenkins made. Let me mention just a few of the practical difficulties. For example, what if the traveller changes airlines once or more en route to Australia, having paid for all his fares and other charges at his place of initial departure? How does the airline which eventually carries the traveller into Australia on the last leg collect the $5? What is to be done about foreign exchange rate changes? Just imagine the confusion and the passenger frustration if the airline attempted to collect the $5 after the passenger had landed in Australia. It seems from discussions that have taken place to date that the cost to the airlines of collecting this tax will be enormous. Amongst the figures that I and the Opposition have seen is the figure of $10 for every $5 collected.

The whole proposal is one great mess. Therefore, the Opposition has much sympathy with the Democrats' amendment. However, because the tax is a Budget measure, and because it does not have the same basic legal and related problems as does clause 9 of the Bill, with which we have just dealt, the Opposition will not support the Democrats' amendment. It follows from what I have said that the Opposition believes that the Government should have an urgent re-look at this proposal-a proposal which has come forward only because of the Government's desperate need for increased revenue to pay for its capacious and seemingly uncontrollable propensity for spending taxpayers' money.
9-10 December 1987 SENATE
SENATE 9-10 December 1987
9-10 December 1987 SENATE

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALKER.NAME: Senator REYNOLDS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Local Government)

TALK.START.PARA: —Senator Short has made a fairly important contribution to this debate in general, and I am pleased that we were able to arrive at some acceptable agreement over the amendment of clause 9. However, I cannot accept some of his comments about the immigration clearance service fee. I just draw to his attention the thirteenth report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which, in regard to the immigration clearance service fee, stated:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is happy to accept that the Immigration Clearance Fee is intended to be a fee for service, and that it appears to bear a reasonable relation to the costs of the service involved.

So I believe that Senator Short was quoting selectively from the Scrutiny of Bills Committee report. The immigration clearance service fee of $5 is to be introduced on 1 January, and I am advised that the airlines have indicated that they will be geared up to collect the fee. The fee will recoup part of the cost of immigration clearances for overseas passengers arriving at Australian airports, estimated at approximately 18 million per year. It reflects the Government's concern that the cost of services should be borne primarily by the user, not by the community as a whole. At present, Australian taxpayers meet the full cost of such clearances and the cost is escalating dramatically with ever increasing numbers of arrivals.

Of course, we are very pleased that there are increasing numbers of arrivals. In 1985-86, 2.9 million passengers arrived and, in 1986-87, the figure was 3.3 million passengers. Obviously, to cope with the increase in passengers and to provide them with better services, the Government will be employing additional staff at airports and overseas posts and it is installing more sophisticated but costly computer systems. The revenue collected from the fee will be about $17m per year and the money will be used to offset the following: costs of immigration inspections at airports, costs relating to passengers refused entry, costs of facilities to detect fraudulent immigration documents, salaries and other costs of airport staff, costs of visa issue, maintenance of movement records and alert lists of undesirable entrants, and general administrative overheads. As I have said before in this chamber, the fee is not unique to Australia. A similar charge is payable and collected by airlines flying passengers to the United States of America. The Department is consulting closely with airline operators to ensure that the necessary legislation and mechanisms to collect the fee will impose as small an administrative burden as possible.

On the question of the fee being a tax, the fee is not a tax as it is imposed for a service provided to the person who pays the fee, and the amount recovered bears a reasonable relation to the actual cost. Of course, that view put forward by the Department and by the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs (Mr Young) has been endorsed by the thirteenth report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee.
