SPEECH.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight we are debating a package of nine Education Bills. As my colleague the shadow Minister for education, Mr Carlton, has said, the Opposition has grave misgivings in respect of certain areas of the Government's education policy and administration. The shortcomings of this policy will be highlighted by amendments which we propose to move at the second reading stage to some of the Bills and by a committee stage amendment to one of the Bills. It is appropriate to move at this stage the second reading amendments to the Bills that follow the States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill (No.2) 1987. In doing so I indicate that because of the late hour and my desire to be as articulate as possible, a desire which I am sure is shared by others, I will relate my reading of the amendments to the comments that I wish to make in respect of those Bills. Following the moving of those amendments I wish to make some other comments. I seek leave to move the amendments together.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —In respect of the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 I move:

SPEECH.PARA: At end of the motion, add `but the Senate deplores the excessive regulation by the Federal Government of non-government schools, which is designed both to impose an external value system on those schools and to hamper the growth of non-government schools and thereby limit parent choice.
In respect of the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987 I move:
At end of motion, add `but the Senate-
(a) condemns Government policies which have denied 20,000 qualified students entry into higher education this year and which promise no better performance in 1988;

(b) notes with concern the failure of the Government to maintain the triennial funding system for higher education, thus introducing uncertainty and potential wastefulness into the planning and expenditure of universities, institutes and colleges;

(c) draws attention to the dangers inherent in allowing centralised bureaucratic bodies to decide whether or not research conducted by universities and colleges of advanced education is in the national interest; and
(d) questions the inclusion of funds for key centres for teaching and research as a part of research funding rather than as a separate allocation concerned mainly with the improvement of teaching.
With respect to the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) I move:

At the end of motion, add ``, but the Senate expresses its concern that the transfer of responsibility from the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training proposed in the Bill is a precursor to the denial of an adequate consultative mechanism and public voice for those directly concerned with running and using Australia's various education systems''.
With respect to the Student Assistance Amendment Bill 1987 I move:

At the end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for its failure to administer Austudy student assistance grants in a timely and efficient manner, thus causing grave inconvenience to students and their families''.

Last, but not least, is the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1987-(Quorum formed) I was in the process of foreshadowing the following amendment to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1987:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate condemns the Government for:
(a) its arbitrary and unnecessary restrictions on the rights of tertiary institutions to attract fee paying students from overseas; and
(b) refusing admission into tertiary education to Australian students who are not awarded a free place but who are prepared to pay a fee for admission on the same basis as overseas students.

This package represents a damning indictment of the previous Minister's policies and administration. Earlier this year Senator Ryan became the longest serving Education Minister. As I recall, unless I am mistaken, the day that she became the longest serving Education Minister was the fateful day that she tabled certain confidential information relating to interest rates. That may be of interest. One would think that the record of achievement of someone who had held the record of being the longest serving Minister would be one of which this Government could and would be proud, but that is apparently not so. Senator Ryan has been removed from the education portfolio. A new broom has come in. The triennial funding that was to begin in 1988 has been abandoned.

The reason this has been done is that the current Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins) says that basically he needs to take a year off to sort out the mess. What that year off means in terms of abandoning the triennium funding is uncertainty. Uncertainty in any area is generally dysfunctional. It is a disincentive to planning; it inhibits innovation and progress. Individuals and families like to be able to plan ahead. Businesses need to be able to plan ahead and invest now for future benefit. Similarly, educational institutions need to be able to plan ahead. But because the new Minister for Employment, Education and Training, as the new broom, is attempting to sweep clean-I understand it was described in the other place as changing gears-it is the educational institutions that will have to suffer the uncertainty while the Government decides where to go from here.

One thing at least is certain; that is, that this Government is turning its back on the policies of the previous Minister, Senator Ryan. The Government is beginning to realise that many of the things the coalition has been saying with respect to education policy are true. The package seeks to address some of the problems. In doing so it will need to accomplish some policy gymnastics of proportions one would previously have thought unbelievable. Despite the Australian Labor Party's opposition to fees for tertiary study-or its alleged opposition, one should say-there is already a fee by another name. We had that semantic debate here that went on ad infinitum with the then Minister saying that the student administration charge was not a precursor to tertiary tuition fees. Senator Ryan lost that debate. This Government now sees fit to allow our institutions to charge tuition fees for higher degrees. I invite honourable senators opposite to turn their minds back to 1981 and the Fraser Government's proposal to do just that. In the event that they choose to do that they will see certain comments by the current Minister, who was then opposing the move. For example, the present Minister said:

Another point that has to be made is that the Government is intent with this legislation on re-establishing the principle of tertiary tuition fees. It is intent on re-establishing a fee collecting mechanism . . . That is why we are intent on opposing it.

Due to the late hour I will not go on to repeat more quotations from those available. But I invite Government senators to turn their minds to these debates, to seek them from Hansard and to see the about-face that this Government has done.

The fees issue, of course, is part of a wider debate-the debate about the resources available to educational institutions and the flexibility of those institutions to use those resources. The Opposition went to the last election offering to maintain existing free places and offering the option to institutions to charge fees for additional places. Senator Ryan, then the Minister-now removed-made much of this policy, ambiguously saying that if the coalition were to win fees would be charged. But what was omitted was that the existing places would be maintained, and there was certainly no reference in the comments of the then Minister for Education about the anomaly whereby overseas students can pay for their places but Australian students cannot. It would be interesting to see what the then Minister for Education will say as the debate on this issue progresses.

It is important for any institutions seeking a degree of autonomy and flexibility to have control over its staff, for without its staff it does not exist. Educational institutions, or at least some faculties in them-for example, commerce and engineering-are competing for staff with the private sector. Others are seeking to create faculties where excellence is the prime criterion for staffing, and they need to be able to compete with other universities for the relevant staff. Accordingly, at the committee stage we will seek to give institutions that autonomy. Unless institutions are perceived by the business community to be in control of their destiny to a reasonable degree, those institutions will have difficulty attracting private sector funds. It is all very well for Senator Button and other Ministers in this Government virtually to kick the can of higher education and say that it is not attracting sufficient private sector funds while at the same time blaming the private sector for not putting the funds in. If the Government will not allow the educational institutions to have the degree of autonomy and control they need, there is no point in hoping that a magic wand will appear and the private sector will invest in institutions which do not have that level of autonomy.

This package also deals in part with the Government's planned structural changes to education, which are to abolish the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission and the Commonwealth Schools Commission, to transfer their administrative functions to the Department of Employment, Education and Training and to establish a new National Board of Employment, Education and Training. Four advisory councils will report to that board-the Schools Council, the Higher Education Council, the Employment and Skills Formation Council and the Australian Research Council. The board will have a full time chairman and three full time executive members who will chair the four councils, and it will have a membership of 13 or 14. The membership will be made up of union representatives, representatives of big business and only two education training providers. The Minister, at his discretion, can attempt to put a balance into this centralist and corporate model with a few appointments at his discretion. However, as there is space for only two education providers, the Opposition is concerned that the wide variety of educational interests will not be properly served. While the membership of the various councils reporting to this board will, as the Minister has said, provide a wider membership and perhaps, therefore, diversity, the coalition seeks to remind the Government that the councils can act only on matters referred to them by the Minister or the board. Independence is not the order of the day for these councils. They have no independent powers of investigation and publication.

To understand the concern in the education community one need give only a cursory glance to the daily papers. If we read them we understand the concern even more. What we read makes a mockery of the Government's assertion that it has widespread support for these measures. If one takes a stronger interest and talks to the people involved one realises that the concern is even greater.

I wish to deal with one other aspect of this legislation, namely, research, in which I have a particular interest. I understand that there will be ample opportunity when debating future Bills to deal with this matter in detail, so I will be brief. The research community in Australia is understandably apprehensive about these proposals. As my colleague the shadow Minister for education, Jim Carlton, pointed out in the other place, there is a real concern that the bureaucracy will override excellence in research and there are very substantial dangers in the Government pronouncing what research is in the national interest. The research community and, for that matter, the Australian community generally have little confidence that the bureaucrats can decide what research is in the national interest. There is little confidence that they understand the lead time required to get back into fields that someone has decided rate low down on the national interest scale, and there is even less confidence that the bureaucrats appreciate the importance of pure research.

We have heard much from this Government about the need for more applied research, some of its comments going as far as stating that universities have been luxuriating and that academics have been pursuing their own personal interests for no benefit. It has caused very deep concern in the research community that this Government does not understand the value of pure research-research which, at the time it is undertaken, may have no apparent economic use whatsoever; it is undertaken purely on the basis of the inquiring mind. Researches would like the Government to indicate that it understands that pure research is the capital on which we draw. It is the lifeblood of applied research; it is the seed from which the benefits of applied research can grow. Without that seed, applied research needs to buy basic research from other countries. That means that we are buying in the raw material for applied research when everybody else has picked it over. We get the remnants, and the detriment of that flows through into the quality of applied research and the quality of the products that are produced as a consequence of that.

In conclusion, this package of Bills is an indictment of the administration policies of the previous Minister for Education. I look forward to the contribution that will be made by my colleagues and, in particular, I look forward to the contribution of the Minister at the end of this debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Macklin, one matter should be clarified. The eight Bills listed under Order of the Day No. 4 are at present before the Chair. I understand that it is proposed that there be a cognate debate on those eight Bills and on Order of the Day No. 5, the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1985. Does the Minister wish to propose that this course be followed?
—Mr Deputy President, I suggest that we proceed in those terms.
—Is it the wish of the Senate that there be a cognate debate on the Bills? There being no objection, it is so ordered.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macklin Sen M.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are dealing cognately with nine Bills which are concerned with restructuring education. A most important statement that was made today is not in those Bills. I refer to the higher education policy discussion paper which was tabled in the other place after Question Time today by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training (Mr Dawkins).

SPEECH.PARA: I propose to look at each of the Bills briefly. I think the major items in the Bills that one would want to discuss can probably be best left to the committee stage of the debate. The States Grants (Education Assistance-Participation and Equity) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987 seeks to adjust the participation and equity program which will finish at the end of this year. The previous Minister said three years ago when the participation and equity program (PEP) was announced that this program was the corner stone of the Government's education policy. We find at the end of this year that the entire corner-stone has been removed. The Government has decided not to embark on any successor program that has similar goals to those that were set by PEP.

The Commonwealth Schools Commission-it is interesting to note that this body held its last meeting on Monday this week-recommended a Commonwealth specific purpose secondary education program to succeed PEP. The aim of PEP was to encourage qualitative change in education in schools and in technical and further education colleges. This was a very worthwhile goal. In fact, when the original PEP program was first suggested I raised doubts about the way in which it could proceed and whether or not it would be successful. As it has turned out, the doubts that I raised at that time have come to fruition. There were a number of administrative problems earlier on with the program which I think discouraged those who were interested in engaging in it. Nevertheless, a very large number of people around Australia with tremendous qualities initially threw themselves wholeheartedly into this program. It was then announced in the subsequent Budget that the funds were to be cut in half.

This is very symptomatic of the way in which this Government has dealt with these programs. I think it is unaware that the psychological gearing up of the people who will undertake these programs is such that grandiose statements such as that which was made by the then Minister about PEP being the corner-stone of the Government's education policy and so forth leads them to believe that the Government itself is committed to the program. Upon that basis they then embark upon spending a great deal of their time, energies and professional expertise on developing parts of that overall program.

The Government, for whatever reason, has decided to do a U-turn in the middle of a two-year program. The program did not even get past its first year of operation. The Government then expects that the professionals whom it has asked to contribute should themselves simply say, `Oh, the Government has changed its mind on this exercise. Right, we will change our direction-there is no problem about that'. It may be that the Government treats education professionals as bureaucrats. While not wishing to cast aspersions on bureaucrats, the professionals who are engaged in this area are not there at the behest of the Government. They are not there to carry out every whim and policy item of the Government. They are there for educational purposes. We would not get anywhere with any of these programs unless those professionals were willing to contribute not just their paid time but also vast amounts of time over and above that paid time as they have done with all of the programs that this Government has instituted and programs that previous governments have instituted.

This is not the first time a government has changed its mind. The Fraser Government had spectacular success changing its mind every couple of years. In one case it changed its mind on a similar program after one year. I have heard from many of these professionals an almost identical comment that never again would they get caught by this type of exercise. We are driving away tremendous amounts of contribution that would come from professionals operating in this area by the ad hoc way in which we deal with these matters.

Having finished with PEP-and as we were saying PEP hopefully was the catalyst for reforms-the Commonwealth Schools Commission wished the Government to continue a role in this area. However, the Government obviously believes that Commonwealth participation in school education is best undertaken indirectly through States grants and grants to private school systems where those schools agree to use funds in particular ways. We are looking at a general funding model to take the place of the previous exercises in which we more or less had control, depending upon which part of the rhetoric one wants to believe-on whether one believes the legislation we have before us, which in many cases tightens the administration of these funds, or whether we believe the report handed down today which urges a deregulation of them. I will come to a detailed examination of some of those extraordinary contradictions that appeared today in the Senate. One Bill seeks to impose a regulation that has never previously existed in regard to the salaries of members of higher education institutions. The paper tabled today raises the issue of how we have to do something about being able to attract by increments specialised, qualified people to our tertiary institutions. The absurdity of having that paper handed down today and discussing this Bill must dawn even on the Special Minister of State (Senator Ryan) who I understand no longer discusses education in Cabinet meetings. With PEP we are confronted with the Government's education corner-stone. I will raise some further points on this Bill, again at the committee stage.

The second Bill, the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1987, deals with one of the most contentious matters up to date in education policy in Australia. The debate has provided a great deal of heat and not terribly much light over a large number of years mainly in terms of the distribution of funds between the private school sector and the State school sector. In addition we have had debates last year on other items of school education such as migrant education and English as a second language.

The Commonwealth's contribution to school education essentially takes two forms. Firstly, there are the general funding programs that were bitten into last year to provide additional funds for the retention of the English as a second language program. These funding programs provide the resources, either to the States for state schools or directly to the schools or to the systemic systems for use in the private or Catholic schools. The use of funds is determined by a whole series of agreements that the Commonwealth has entered into or, with regard to private schools, by a whole series of conditions which have been set by the Commonwealth.

Secondly, there are the specific purpose programs which, until now, were run by the Commonwealth Schools Commission. With the abolition of the commissions, these programs, presumably, will be run through the National Board of Employment, Education and Training, if they are run at all. When one looks at the thrust of the Green Paper on higher education one could be forgiven for thinking that, if the Government is in any way consistent-that is probably an assumption one should not make with regard to this Government-there is likely to be a flow-through to schools. I believe that the Government will not be consistent and that there will not be a flow-through to schools for the very good reason that this Government reneged on its policy and adopted the policy which the Liberal and National parties went to the 1983 and 1984 elections on. The Government neglected its own policy by extending funding to private schools in a way the Fraser-Howard Government had never dared to do.

It is interesting to note that the only guaranteed funds for any educational institutions in Australia go to the private school sector. They are guaranteed for the eight-year program set down last year in the legislation. This year even our tertiary institutions do not get guaranteed funding. We are now experiencing yet another of the continuing rotating hiccups. Programs used to be over a triennium but we now have a one-year lead time while we rearrange all the programs each year.

In the 1987-88 Budget, as I have already mentioned the Government has failed to provide successor programs to two of the most important special purpose programs, the participation and equity program and the basic learning in primary schools program. The Government's interest in computers has also disappeared. The Leader of the Government in the Senate (Senator Button) was telling us that we need to get with the times in terms of technology. So what do we do? We decide to undermine our base in this area by pulling out of a useful program, saying, `Somebody else can pick up the tab'. It is very odd that we should believe that somehow or other the tertiary sector will be able to produce the qualified people we are looking for if we do not have those people coming forward from the schooling sector.

It is also very odd to believe that those people will come forward from the schooling sector unless we fund it adequately and attract qualified people to the teaching profession. I have mentioned time and again in this place that currently in Australia we have a dearth of teachers in important areas, particularly mathematics and science. The problem is that many of our best maths teachers have been seconded to teach computer science. Many of our best science teachers have then had to be seconded to teach maths, and domestic science teachers have had to be seconded to teach science. Our schools are in a shambles, and we expect them to produce reasonable people for entry into higher education institutions. It is a structural problem, a problem of foresight. It is a problem which is shared not only by the Government but also by other groups within the community. One of those groups is the Press. Its reporting of education is woefully inadequate. Members of the Press seem unable to work out that a teacher surplus in some curriculum areas does not mean that there is a teacher surplus in every curriculum area. So they publish scare reports in the newspapers which, naturally enough, have an effect on those people who are looking at their career prospects. They change their career prospects and they do not go into teaching, and we lose some of the best and most talented people from the profession that they should go into, because it is the basic profession for all types of things that the Government is talking about in its other policy areas. We are not in these Bills talking about a peripheral area; we are talking about an area that is basic and fundamental to the nation. I wish to raise some points again about the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Amendment Bill when we come to the committee stage.

I wish to turn now to another group of Bills-the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill 1987, the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill (No. 2), the Maritime College Amendment Bill, the Canberra College of Advanced Education Amendment Bill and the Australian National University Amendment Bill. They are essentially linked together, and the last three Bills are consequential amendment Bills flowing from the fact that the Commonwealth has legislative control over the Maritime College, the Canberra College of Advanced Education (CCAE) and the Australian National University.

I want to refer to some of the items which were raised today in the Green paper-a document full of platitudes. In fact in recent times I have seen only one better document for platitudes, and that was at an Inter-parliamentary Union conference, when we managed to pass a five-page resolution on the Iran-Iraq war which both Iran and Iraq were able to vote for. I think the people who drafted that resolution must have been co-opted to write a great deal of this particular paper. I understand there is now a computer program which will generate platitudes, so some of them might have come out of that as well.

This document is most extraordinary. When we eliminate all of the guff and get down to some of the mechanisms, we find some extraordinary propositions. I refer to page 29 of the higher education policy document, which talks about `educational profiles'. I have tested this out on a few people and asked them what they believe is the intent behind this particular exercise when the Government says that it is going to set up these profiles and that they will take the form of statements, identification of mission and so on. It then says:

These educational profiles should both describe an institution's existing course mix and indicate the areas that the institution wishes to develop as strengths for the future. They will be subject to a process of discussion with the Government to enable both parties to agree on a contract . . .

On the one hand, we have the Government, and on the other hand we have a single institution-not all of the universities, the CAEs and the TAFE colleges. What are we going to use for these education profiles? The first item is the level of funding available to the institution from the Commonwealth to implement its chosen academic goals. I ask honourable senators: What type of debate will that be between the Commonwealth, with the money, the bureaucracy and everything else, and the institution? What leverage could an institution possibly have in such an unequal contest? It will be, and obviously is, the clearest case of divide and conquer that I have ever seen put down in any document, because the Government well knows that the only way that an alternative paradigm to what this Government is trying to do in education is going to come forward is by the co-operation of the universities, the CAEs and the TAFE colleges looking to develop, as they are at this very moment, an alternative paradigm to what the Government is seeking to thrust on the education sector.

This education profile in this paper today will mean that that will not be possible. Every institution will be screwed to the floor by this particular exercise and will, in fact, have no criteria upon which to judge whether it is being usefully dealt with, successfully dealt with or fairly dealt with, because the criteria that will apply to a particular university, say in my State, will obviously be different to the criteria that will be applied in another State. (Quorum formed) I thank Senator Knowles for calling a quorum. In fact, she has called me back to the speech that I should be making. I should not get carried away with the Green Paper which was introduced today.

I wish to refer briefly to three additional items in the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Bill. I refer first to the fees for certain courses which can be applied by ministerial discretion. When we reach the committee stage we will consider a most extraordinary clause-clause 9-which we will, I am quite sure, deal with in some detail. In particular, I refer to the fascinating part of the clause which reads, `earned a living at any time'-something that has previously been unknown to man or beast in a legislative form. However, presumably the Minister will be able to tease out the relevant definitions of `earned' in this instance, of `living', in this instance, of `earning a living' which could be different from both of those definitions, and of `any time'. I will also be interested when we consider clause 9 to find out what `educational qualifications' could possibly mean. It is undefined in the Bill. It is not defined in any education Bill. So we will be interested to look at what `educational qualifications' means. We will also be interested to look at what is meant by a `vocational qualification'. Does this refer to a kindergarten graduation form? I believe that that is a vocational qualification; it is obviously very useful. Does it relate to primary or secondary school--

TALK.START.PARA: —The minimum requirement for a senator.

—It would be an excellent requirement for a senator. Perhaps it should be compulsory. I will leave those delights until the committee stage, but I foreshadow that clause 9 should be of some interest at that stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I wish to raise concerns the higher education administration charge. The Government is pursuing this policy. I have forecast for the last two years that in academic year 1989 we will have full recovery of fees. Despite the policy of this Government when it went to the people at the last election and despite its policy when it went to the people at the previous election, in academic year 1989 we will have full recovery of fees, so people should start to save their pennies if they want their kids to be able to continue in higher education.

TALK.START.PARA: —It would be dishonest, if they do.
—It is totally dishonest. In fact, it would be adopting the Liberal-National Party policy--
—At least we had it up front.
—At least it was up front.
—Do you think they will sink so low as to do that?

—If Senator Boswell reads the Green Paper he will see that it sinks a lot lower than that. The third point that I wish to raise briefly concerns the limitations on the ability of higher education institutions to pay salaries. This Bill introduces for the first time a requirement whereby universities can be penalised if they go beyond the Remuneration Tribunal's salaries with regard to-
—Not for the first time; it has been there for years.
—It has been done before with vice-chancellors, I know that. On page 61 of the Green Paper we find this quote:

SPEECH.PARA: Academic salaries are paid at uniform rates across all disciplines according to a position held by an academic. They do not necessarily reflect the salary rates available in other sectors of comparable professions. This, together with other considerations such as a regional location of some institutions, means that some academic positions are difficult to fill.

It then goes on with a very reasonable discussion of why there should be special allowances. It also talks about access to consultancy income, salary structures, superannuation and so on. That section of the Green Paper at least meets the reality and in Australia that reality is quite stark.

I refer to a publication from the National Remuneration Centre. Let us look at the example of payment for an engineer, grade 4, aged from about 35. We see that regular total cash remuneration is, in 75 per cent of cases, $60,000-and that is at the age of 35. Let us look at professional scientists, grade 4-75 per cent of these receive $64,000. Data processing managers, grade 4, receive on average $56,000. But what do we find when we look at what we are paying our academics? We pay a professor a top salary of $58,000-less than most of those that I have just mentioned. Yet we expect to get good computer professionals to stay in academia. Why would they do so? The same applies to scientists and biological scientists; the list is endless. We have enormous difficulty because of the attractions of the outside professions which are looking for qualified people and people with skills. Those people with skills are easily found by headhunters in any department of any university.

TALK.START.PARA: —What else are they going to do?

—I acknowledge that one! This Bill runs against the very point in the Green Paper that we are debating on the self same day. I am sure the Government would not have wanted to organise that; it was a quirk of history whereby we got the lie to a very important item within the States Grants (Tertiary Education Assistance) Amendment Bill 1987.
—Do you want an extension of time?

—That would be very pleasant, Senator. In the last couple of minutes that I have I wish to refer to the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1987 and the enormous problems that have arisen as a result of the Government's inept handling of this area. On previous occasions I have moved for the ability to have the charge broken up and I have made a whole series of other suggestions on the basis that my Party does not support the charge but realises that the charge will remain there. I believe that there are better ways of administering that charge-for the benefit of students coming from overseas and for our reputation overseas. Recently I have visited both Malaysia and Thailand and I can assure honourable senators that our reputation there has been severely damaged by the exercise of enticing students to come from overseas to this country and then seeking to deport them. Whether or not that sounds like a fair and reasonable description of what is happening, that is the way in which it has been put to me in those countries. I would suggest that when we seek to organise something with regard to overseas students we should seek to organise it in a way that enhances Australia's reputation in this area, not denigrates it.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Patterson Sen K.C.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not want to hold up the business of the Senate this morning for too long at this eleventh hour of this session of Parliament although some of my fellow senators have not been too reluctant to do that today. I feel compelled to speak on this package of Bills today. Having worked in a college of advanced education for the past eleven years and having been a member of Monash Council for the past eight years, it would be remiss of me not to contribute to the debate on education. I refer to a media release by the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, Mr Dawkins, on 5 December in which he made the statement that the amount provided for tertiary education in the university sector for 1988 represented an increase of 2 per cent in real terms over that in 1987.

SPEECH.PARA: We all know that we can have lies, damned lies and statistics. Often figures can be presented to us in favourable terms but closer analysis may reveal that all is not what it seems. The Minister may well claim that there has been an increase in real terms but with that increase the university and college sector is teaching more students. The student-staff ratio in Australian higher education is disgraceful and may be those 20,000 unplaced students are well off not being jammed into overcrowded lecture theatres. In the first term of this year I taught in lecture theatres with students sitting in aisles, unable to see the blackboards and overhead screens. Some of my staff complained that the students and staff were subjected to severe fire risks as a result of overcrowding-antiquated conditions in modern times.

As I mentioned in my maiden speech, the higher education sector has been severely affected by the economic situation and, despite an apparent increase in funding in real terms, the cost of equipment and library acquisitions has left universities behind the eight ball. On 28 October I mentioned libraries. In the higher education supplement in the Australian on 4 November 1987 Professor Davies, a recently retired Adelaide academic, said of the University of Adelaide Barr Smith Library that the number of volumes received:
had dropped from an average of about 26 thousand annually in the mid 1970's to an average of about 17 thousand in the past few years.
He went on further to say:

If a halt is not called at once to this serious downward trend, the Barr Smith Library, from being one of the best university libraries in the country, will soon become a second-rate provincial non-entity.

I am sure that many librarians throughout universities in Australia would be echoing his sentiments. Not only are universities facing uncertainty associated with the impact of the national economy on their operations; they are also affected by the uncertainty resulting from the failure of the Government to maintain the triennial funding. As Senator Vanstone has mentioned, this has created an environment which is not conducive to research, teaching and planning. The answer is not necessarily pouring more taxpayers' money into the higher education sector. We must free up the sector to be more innovative and self-supporting.

However, if the Minister is attempting to do this he needs to be sure that the Labor governments in the States are not working against him. If the suggestion in the review of governing bodies of universities in Victoria which has been under discussion were implemented, it would mean the governing bodies of each university would be look alike clones. Educational institutions have their own individual identity and the composition of the governing bodies should be flexible and not fixed. The Minister, in his discussion in the community, seems to be running with the foxes and hunting with the hounds. When speaking recently at the Royal Melbourne Institute of Technology (RMIT) he said:

Unless the universities, and particularly the older ones among them, can shake off their ingrained resistances to change, can put the lie to their image as ossified bodies incapable of adaptation, then the opportunities associated with the changes now needed in the higher education sector will simply pass them by. It will be the innovative, more dynamic institutions-colleges and institutes such as RMIT-who will reap the benefits of the `new age'.

I wonder whether the Minister would be as happy to say that at Melbourne, Sydney or Adelaide universities. I do not know to which universities he was referring, and of course some of the older universities may have some tired, tenured academics, but the Graduates Gazette of the University of Sydney and that university's annual report, and the annual report of the University of Melbourne, demonstrate that the two oldest universities in Australia have many departments of international standing producing outstanding students and research. The universities and colleges, both old and new, ought to be credited for what they have achieved, given their limited resources.

These Bills cover a wide range of issues in education. It is not possible at this time of the morning to pursue them in depth. However, I concur with Mr Carlton who, in speaking on these Bills in the House of Representatives, expressed the Opposition's concern at the transfer of the functions of the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission to the Department of Employment, Education and Training. By reducing the input of those directly involved in higher education we face serious risks, just as we face serious risks if centralised bureaucratic bodies decide whether or not research conducted by universities and colleges of advanced education is in the national interest.

I will not debate this issue tonight, despite the fact that I see it as of the utmost importance. The suggestions that the Minister is making indicate that he does not understand the psychology of the researcher. The sort of verve and commitment that we have seen on the part of Australian researchers who have made major contributions to pure and applied research in Australia is based on intrinsic rather than extrinsic motivation. The discussion on the Minister's higher education policy paper will enable me to debate this fundamental and basic issue further. To save myself the wrath of my fellow senators, I will refrain from speaking further in this debate.
Opposition senators-No!

TALK.START.PARA: —However, I must state that I regret that such important Bills on education are being discussed with such haste in this House. I thank my fellow senators for their support in asking me to continue my speech, but I will refrain from doing so.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Wood Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I promise not to be as kind as Senator Patterson. The provision of financial assistance to students has shaped the face of higher education in Australia. Prior to the Second World War, the distribution of student assistance was closely linked to the labour power needs of State governments and private capital. Scholarships, bonds and bursaries were available in limited numbers for students who wished to train and work as teachers, engineers or technicians. Most students, however, relied on private means and access to study was duly limited to an exceedingly small section of the population.

SPEECH.PARA: This situation changed dramatically in the 1940s with the involvement of the Commonwealth Government in the funding of post-school education. In 1943 the introduction of a federally funded scholarship and reconstruction training scheme conditioned an astronomical growth in student numbers, which was limited only by the demise of the training scheme at the end of the 1940s. With the establishment of an ongoing Commonwealth scholarship scheme in 1951, student numbers continued to increase, but at a slower rate than in the five years after the war. The year 1961 saw the introduction of scholarships earmarked specifically for post-graduates, to induce students to remain at university for further study.

The development of financial assistance to students over this period essentially revolved around the issues of access and attrition; when government was concerned about labour market requirements, declining access or high dropout rates from educational institutions it would generally meet these needs by increasing the accessibility of grants. The combined needs of developing human capital and enhancing equality of opportunity led the Labor Government in 1973-74 to revolutionise the system of student financing by replacing the competitive undergraduate scholarship scheme with the non-competitive means tested tertiary education assistance scheme (TEAS). It was intended that TEAS would meet the basic needs of student studying full time towards a first degree. State teacher education scholarships, which had preceded and paralleled the development of federally funded student assistance, were phased out as TEAS was phased in.

However, the social and economic climate altered in 1975 and a new government assumed power-I do not need to tell honourable senators which government-with the stated intention of reducing government spending and placing welfare services on a user-pays footing. This involved the gradual phasing out of student grants and the introduction of a commercial student loans scheme. Due to the opposition from the education lobby, the Government failed in its attempt to establish a loans scheme but, between 1975 and 1983, the level and accessibility of the two main grant schemes, TEAS and the Commonwealth post-graduate awards schemes, declined markedly. The social consequences of this decline were felt in the late 1970s and early 1980s, with a shift from full time to part time study in both undergraduate and post-graduate study modes, disturbing drops in youth participation in higher education and a decrease in the number of students from less privileged groups-that is, women and those of low socio-economic status.

In recognition of community concerns with these trends the Hawke Labor Government, first elected in March 1983, promised to rectify the situation by upgrading TEAS to the level of the single unemployment benefit and raising the level of the income test ceiling. After consideration of the introduction of a single youth allowance coinciding with the International Year of Youth, the Government decided to rationalise existing youth support schemes to establish a new scheme-Austudy-to be phased in from 1987 on. However, Austudy has not marked a turning point in student financing. It has carried over many of the poverty traps which characterised the TEAS scheme and the level of, and eligibility for, assistance have continued to contract as, year after year, the Federal Government has reduced the public commitment to higher education and training in Australia.

The decline in the availability of student financing has been accurately charted by the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission's Review of the Efficiency and Effectiveness in Higher Education, published in 1986, which noted that a factor affecting the socio-economic composition of higher education is the nature and availability of financial assistance to students. Tuition fees for higher education were abolished back in 1974. At the same time, there were major changes in government schemes of financial assistance. The Commonwealth Government replaced the Commonwealth scholarship scheme, which provided a means tested living allowance to 17 per cent of full time students, with the tertiary education assistance scheme, which provided similar means tested allowances to all full time students. State governments started phasing out scholarships for teacher trainees, which provided generous non-means tested allowances to over 30 per cent of full time students. The result has been that less than 40 per cent--

TALK.START.PARA: —I take a point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President. I ask you whether standing order 406 is being breached.

—I think that Senator Wood is using copious notes. I also draw to his attention that he should try to relate his speech to the nine Bills before us. Will Senator Wood please continue, bearing in mind the standing orders?
—I do not usually use copious notes,
—Don't dispute the ruling of the Chair.

—I am not disputing the ruling of the Chair. I am just pointing out that, at this hour of the night, I wish to be as precise and succinct as I can be. Therefore, I would like to rely on my primary sources as much as I can. Senator Hill, who was instrumental in having me gagged earlier this evening, is now objecting. In short, the decline in financial assistance also has been demonstrated at the University of New South Wales. A comparison with 1974 figures demonstrated that there had been a marked decrease in Government funding to students in this sector of education. Scholarships have declined and there is a corresponding increase in the number of students being supported, either by their families or by themselves. Contrary to Government rhetoric, student financial assistance is continuing its rapid decline which was first set in place under the Fraser Liberal Government.

SPEECH.PARA: There is an assumption in Austudy that full time students up to 24 years of age receive financial support from parents. The age at which students are deemed to be independent by the Department of Employment, Education and Training is 25 years of age. This figure is arbitrary and bears no relation to reality. It is our view that 18 years be considered the cut off point for dependent status. Most Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development countries have sought to lower the age of independence.

Other criteria for the granting of independent status are also problematic, the most difficult being that on the ground of significant labour force participation. That issue will come up later in the committee stage of the debate. Until recently students were granted independent status if they could prove participation in the labour force for two years out of five. This criteria was changed by the Labor Government to two years out of three. Recently in the mini-Budget it was changed to three years out of four on the basis of a full week being 35 hours rather than the previous 25 hours. Clearly this measure has been introduced to reduce access to assistance. The Sydney University Student Representative Council welfare officer estimates that at least 9,000 students will not gain access to financial assistance as a result of this decision.

I am opposed also to an incomes test because this places student grants in the residual welfare category which fosters a `blame the victim' mentality for being unsuccessful for not having the means of self-support. I favour a universal welfare scheme as proposed by the Henderson Commission of Inquiry into Poverty and other inquiries such as that done by Dr Wilenski, who later pressed for a universal youth allowance to be paid to all those young people not in the labour force. It was from this idea that the Austudy concept was developed. At the very least the present cut off point for assistance to students who are not dependants is the ludicrous figure of $16,000 for total parental income. This is absurd.

It was the Labor Government which first decided in the 1985-86 Budget to tax student allowances. Currently students are allowed to earn no more than $2,000 over their total grant. Opening this to taxation has taken a huge bite out of yearly earnings, with students paying tax at a high marginal rate. In this scenario the level of allowable earnings should be increased substantially. The result of this decline in accessibility to financial assistance has been to throw students back on to their already overburdened families for support.

I was a student at Macquarie University when these fees were introduced. Studies at Macquarie University have shown that the fee introduced by this Government-it is a fee-has resulted in the rapid exit of mature age students from that university and, more specifically, mature age women students. It is interesting that this fee alone has been responsible for seeing the decline in the access of women to tertiary education. Mature age women are seeking to enter higher education. These are the people who are being specifically disadvantaged by the fee. I agree with Senator Macklin. I have no doubt that, despite Australian Labor Party policy, this Government will move to full cost fees by the end of its term.

We are also debating the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill. It is instructive to look at what happened to fees for overseas students. I think that is a mirror of what will happen to fees for the general body of the student population. We will see increase after increase to the fee. The Government will probably give up trying to pretend that it is an administrative fee and we will see an introduction of full cost fees. We will have gone back 20 years in assistance to students in higher education. Higher education is, once again, becoming the enclave of the sons and daughters of the wealthy. I think that this is something to be resisted.

I say in conclusion that, as a youth worker, I have seen the value of the participation and equity program (PEP). I have used it at various levels and seen its benefits to students in school and out of school. At the school which my children go to, PEP has been the main factor responsible for getting parents more involved in the education of their children. It is a tragedy that PEP will be abolished. Given that in my Party I am my own Whip, I conclude my remarks.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to speak about only one of the Bills that we are debating at the moment-the Overseas Students Charge Amendment Bill 1987.
—Just faint gracefully.

—I could not faint gracefully. This debate gives me the opportunity, if I am not distracted, to stress the importance of an overseas student program under which foreign students are educated in Australian institutions. It is important from the point of view of benefits to Australia and to the developing nations around us, from the Pacific and Asia whence most of these students come. It enables me to express concern at the reducing sum this Government appropriates through our aid vote in subsidising the costs of such education. Put in the context of what is happening in relation to this Government's approach to foreign aid, that is not surprising.

SPEECH.PARA: In the last few years we have seen dramatic erosion of our aid efforts. I remind the Senate that since 1984 there has been a 20 per cent real reduction in our aid, a position which is quite deplorable and of which the Government should be ashamed, particularly considering the undertakings it gave when it came to government. (Quorum formed)

The appalling record of this Government in relation to foreign aid, to which I was referring, would seem to be based on the misconception that overseas aid is charity-not that there is any reason to be ashamed of charity. But in fact probably the greatest beneficiary of Australia's aid program is Australia itself. Why? It is because it promotes our country; it promotes and encourages the role of our goods and services; it complements our foreign affairs, defence and trade activities. Unfortunately, the field of education support has suffered along with other cuts in foreign aid. In 1984-85 our assistance for overseas students was $98.6m. In 1987-88 it is only $85.2m-in real terms, quite a substantial drop. Similarly, training support has dropped from $5.9m in 1985-86 to $5.2m in 1987-88.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. I just ask whether the honourable senator is breaching standing order 406.
—No, he is not.

—Thank you, Madam Acting Deputy President. I was having some difficulty with my copious notes. Before I was rudely interrupted, I was going to say that there are probably few areas in which Australia can better help our developing neighbours than that of education assistance. It helps them to help themselves. It helps them to develop so that they need not be so dependent in the future upon aid. It helps them to lift themselves to a standard of living which will enable opportunities for trade with us in the future. Senator Haines should listen to this. It gives us the opportunity to educate and influence the future leaders of our neighbour countries in the value systems we think important and which can best ensure peace and stability in our region. It gives us the opportunity to promote goodwill, not only with the students' parents, who long for better opportunities for their children, but also with the current leaders of such countries, who are obviously striving to lift the standards of living of their people.

SPEECH.PARA: There are so many benefits in Australia's providing this service to the region. Yet the number of students this Government is prepared to subsidise is now reducing. I refer firstly to those who are fully subsidised under our system. I remind honourable senators that in 1982 the figure for such students was over 3,000.

TALK.START.PARA: —You cannot remind them of something most of them did not know about.
—Well, they know about it now. In 1986 the figure was reduced to 2,588. The figure for 1987 was approximately 2,300.
—It sounds a bit like their record in foreign aid generally, doesn't it?

—It does. I remind the Leader of the Opposition that, if I go back to the first page of my notes, I find that in the last few years there has been a dramatic erosion of our foreign aid. In fact, since 1984 there has been a 20 per cent reduction in real terms. Let us look at that in the context of partly subsidised overseas students because under this legislation they will have to pay an increase, from 45 per cent to 55 per cent, in actual costs. Because of that increase in costs their number is also reducing. Secondary students who were subject to the quota in 1983 got up to the figure of 5,397. By 1987 that figure was down to 3,410-a substantial reduction in the number of overseas secondary school students whom we are supporting under this scheme. Under the quota the number of tertiary students rose steadily to 14,605 in 1986. In 1987 that figure was reduced to 14,400 and this year it has reduced further to about 13,300. So again we see this continuing picture of less money being provided by this Government and fewer overseas students from our developing neighbours able to be supported within the system in this country. I think that is something this Senate should deplore.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated, the percentage cost that they are expecting to pay is increasing and is now reaching very substantial sums. In real terms, for the more expensive university courses, these students are now having to pay over $7,000 a year and $6,300 for other courses, which certainly is not an insignificant sum. It seems to be filling the places in university courses and technical and further education (TAFE) courses. That means that the contribution of Australia is being reduced because the subsidy for those who are in TAFE is significantly lower. We find that of the 3,500 new students to be admitted under this scheme this year, only 1,500 will be in tertiary institutions, which, as I indicated earlier, certainly causes me concern, and I would hope that it causes this Senate generally concern.

Two aspects remain pleasing. The first aspect is that, as a result of an amendment to earlier legislation pressed by the Opposition, those who started their courses at a particular fee structure will be able to finish their courses on that structure. The second pleasing aspect, provided that the Government does not renege on its undertaking, is that we note that the 55 per cent figure that will apply-the payment required-according to the Minister will be for the triennium starting in the year 1987-88. We trust that the Government will keep to that undertaking. With regard to the third category, that is, full fee paying students, there is still enormous potential for this country.

One needs only to look briefly at the market to appreciate what a small sector is being realised by this country. It is estimated that there are approximately one million students studying outside their home countries, but of those only 1.2 per cent come to Australia. The United States of America takes approximately 32 per cent, France 13 per cent, Canada 3 per cent and so on down the scale. When one looks at the source of students to Australia one sees that interesting anomalies are also apparent. Of the approximate 14,000 students who come under this category it is interesting that we get only 1,000 from Indonesia out of a population of 176 million. Taiwan, with a population of about 20 million, does not even get into the figures, which I must say I find astounding. From Korea we get only 125 students out of a population of some 43 million. The Philippines which has a population of 60 million and which needs education particularly in view of its current crisis, as do so many developing countries, also is not included in the figure. So it is either none or a mere handful.

Why is this occurring? It is occurring because most of these countries traditionally look to the education facilities of the United States of America, which in many cases is considerably more expensive for them than sending students to Australia. So there is an education failing on our part in terms of what services we have to offer in that area. It is interesting also to look at Malaysia, which has some 65,000 foreign students studying overseas. Although Malaysia is our greatest source of overseas students, only 8,000 of those 65,000 come to this country. So there is obviously room for extensive improvement, even in relation to Malaysia. As I indicated, the developing nations in Asia, in particular, and also the nations in the Pacific are yet to be convinced of the education facilities that we offer in this country.

We need to indicate that education facilities are available in Australia if we are to attract students. But it is also important that we should offer the right courses. There has been a considerable demand for technically oriented courses, business courses, et cetera. It is no good us going, as we have perhaps in so many other trading areas, and telling our potential trading partners what is good for them. We must be prepared to respond to their market. Furthermore, the quality of what we offer must be high. We must realise that we are in competition with countries such as the United States and the European nations.

I have indicated the general benefits that will flow from offering these facilities to overseas students. But if we look at this matter from the point of view of full fee paying students we can see the obvious additional benefits in respect of foreign currency and the economies of scale that can benefit Australian students here. The Australian economy would receive an obvious fillip in terms of the accommodation, sustenance, transport and so on that is necessary to sustain these students while they are in Australia. What is the potential revenue to Australia from this largely untapped source? I can do no better than to refer to the work of Mr George Tarjan, the Manager of the Trade and Services Branch of the Australian Trade Commission, who indicated that he believed that revenue of $24m in 1987 could very quickly be turned into revenue of at least $100m if our institutions opened their doors and if we marketed their services in the way in which I have indicated. There are also other profit making opportunities through education that are clearly--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about them; don't hesitate.

—I am going to, because it will be good for the Minister to learn. Apart from the full courses, there are other profit making opportunities in the field of education. There are obviously opportunities through external courses that we do not yet offer sufficiently in this country and which can be profitable. There are opportunities through specialist short term courses that can be much more extensively adopted. There are also opportunities in the provision of education consultants funded by international aid organisations. There are, of course, also opportunities in the area which this Government wishes to avoid-that of private education institutions which could clearly offer a service if we did not have the blinkered attitude that we have had from this Government that, for no other than irrational reasons, will not allow that facility to be offered.

SPEECH.PARA: As I have indicated, this is one area in which Australia can provide a really worthwhile service to our neighbours and make a profit as well. To me, there does not seem to be anything wrong with that. If we did make that profit, it might better enable this Government to find places for the 20,000-odd young Australians who cannot find places in Australian tertiary institutions. Outside of the profit areas, I remind the Government, there are many areas in education in which we can be of help to our neighbours. Some time last year I mentioned the absence of books in Philippine primary schools. This touched me. To provide books is one simple way in which we can be of assistance to our neighbours. I drew the Government's attention to this, but it took little notice.

In my experience, one of the best ways in which we have contributed to developing nations is through the provision of teachers. The service that has been provided by Australian teachers in Zimbabwe, for example, is quite legendary-not only the services they provide to students in that country but also the goodwill they promote and extend for Australia's benefit.

Overseas education facilities is an area in which Australia can make a worthwhile contribution to the development of our region. The three-phase structure that we have at the moment of totally subsidised, partly subsidised and full fee paying appears to me to be a sound structure. However, it is a matter of great regret that the Government is cutting support for the first two. I argue that it is short-sighted and I urge the Government to reconsider it as a matter of urgency.
Debate (on motion by Senator Tate) adjourned.
Senate adjourned at 1.47 a.m. (Thursday)

PROCTEXT.PARA: The following paper was tabled:
Environment Protection (Nuclear Codes) Act-Order pursuant to subsection 9 (1), dated 18 November 1987.
The following answers to questions were circulated:

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is there any legislative or other practical limitation which precludes the provision of witness protection once a person has given evidence or finished being of assistance to the National Crime Authority (NCA) or any other and what investigating Authority?

(2) In the 1986-87 financial year did: (a) the Australian Federal Police; (b) any other and what State police force; (c) any other and what organisations carry out and what amount of this type of witness protection on behalf of the NCA. Did any and what proportion of such work relate to: (i) Commonwealth references; (ii) State references?
(3) What was the expenditure by each State police force in connection with this activity?

(4) What proportion of State expenditure during 1986-87 in terms of: (a) salaries, overtime and allowances; (b) direct costs including food, accommodation and travel has been or will be recouped from; (i) the National Crime Authority, (ii) the Australian Federal Police, (iii) any other Commonwealth agency?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) There are no Commonwealth legislative limitations to the duration of witness protection once a witness has given evidence or ceases to be of assistance to the National Crime Authority (NCA) or other investigative authorities.
However the AFP Witness Protection Branch, which also provides its services to a number of other authorities, has or may have the following practical constraints placed upon it:
the question of continuing financial support from client authorities;
specific terms and conditions for the provision of protective services contained in Memoranda and Understanding;
the diminution of threat against the witness and as a consequence the necessity for continued full service or otherwise; and

the decision by the witness to terminate any arrangement for this or her security, or to enter the final relocation phase of the program which may involve the removal of close protection arrangements.
I understand that no legislative limitations exist, but that similar practical constraints apply, to the provision of witness protection by State authorities.
(2) (1) Yes. During the 1986-87 financial year the AFP performed protection duties on four witnesses for the NCA.
(i) and (ii) Three of the witnesses under AFP protection relate to joint Commonwealth and State references; the other witness is related to a purely Commonwealth matter.
(b) Yes. During the 1986-87 financial year the N.S.W. Police performed protection duties for the NCA on two witnesses.
(i) and (ii) These witnesses were both related to joint Commonwealth and N.S.W. references.
(c) No other organisation carried out witness protection duties on behalf of the NCA in 1986-87.
(3) The New South Wales Police Department has not been able to provide this information to date.

(4) (i) No formal arrangement exists for the reimbursement of the costs of witness protection provided by State agencies to the NCA. However, cost-sharing arrangements apply to joint Commonwealth/State References, under which all project-specific costs (including operational expenses) are divided between the Commonwealth and the State (or States).
(ii) As mentioned above the AFP carries out its own witness protection.
(iii) Not applicable to any other Commonwealth agency.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What is the extent of additional resources (both financial and other) that the NCA would require to set up its own witness protection facilities given the statement on page 42 of the National Crime Authority Annual Report 1985-86 that: ``Although section 34 empowers the Authority to set up its own witness protection facilities, the Authority does not at present have sufficient resources to do so, and must, in effect, rely on facilities already in existence''?
(2) What actions has the NCA taken to date in attempting to secure these additional resources?

(3) What progress has been made to date in the formation of a national scheme to co-ordinate witness protection arrangements throughout Australia apart from the proposed inquiry by the Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) and (2) The Authority has not given detailed consideration to this question; it would not consider it feasible or desirable to establish its own witness protection facilities. The Authority, therefore, has taken no steps to secure additional resources for this purpose.
(3) While a formal national witness protection scheme has not yet been established, co-operation and co-ordination exists between State and Commonwealth agencies on witness protection arrangements.

In addition the Australian Police Ministers' Council also considered the issue of national witness protection arrangements at its meeting in Hobart on 27 November. The Council agreed that, while any final decision on improved national witness protection arrangements should await the report of the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the NCA on witness protection, relevant jurisdictions should confer as a matter of urgency on interim arrangements for witness protection, having regard to the recommendations of the National Police Research Unit.

The Australian Federal Police, Attorney-General's Department and National Crime Authority are each preparing a submission to the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the National Crime Authority providing comments on the issue from their particular perspective.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Ms Lorraine Cohen and Mr Aaron Cohen

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) On what date were Lorraine and Aaron Cohen arrested in Malaysia in relation to the charges recently faced by them?
(2) On what date did: (a) the Department of Foreign Affairs; (b) any other and what Australian authorities, first become aware of their arrest and the nature of the above charges?

(3) On any and what date did (a) the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence; (b) the National Crime Authority; (c) the Department of Foreign Affairs; (d) any other and what Australian authorities, first advise the Malaysian authorities of the findings of the Stewart Royal Commission in relation to Lorraine Cohen?

(4) On any and what date during the trial of the Cohens did any and what Australian authorities advise the Malaysian High Commission of matters in relation to the findings of the Stewart Royal Commission?
(5) Why was it considered to be necessary for the Malaysian High Commission to be so advised at that stage.

(6) At the recent trial in Malaysia, in any and what manner and to any and what extent did the prosecution seek to lead evidence in chief or by way of rebuttal designed to establish that Lorraine Cohen was or had been a heroin trafficker, dealer or distributor.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Lorraine and Aaron Cohen were arrested at Penang, Malaysia on 9 February 1985.

(2) (a) I am advised that the Department of Foreign Affairs became aware of the arrest through media reports at the time the events took place. In this regard, I refer the honourable Senator to the answer given on behalf of the Minister for Foreign Affairs by Senator Evans in the Senate on 27 May 1985.

(b) The Australian Federal Police liaison officer in Malaysia was advised of the arrest of the Cohens shortly after their detention. As they were travelling on New Zealand passports, advice of their arrest was immediately passed to the New Zealand High Commission which provided consular assistance.
(c) I have no reason to believe that other Australian agencies became aware of the arrests other than through media reports at the time.
(a) the ABCI has not, on any occasion, provided information concerning the Cohens to the Malaysian authorities;
(b) the National Crime Authority took no action to draw to the attention of Malaysian authorities the findings of the Stewart Royal Commission in relation to Lorraine Cohen;

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Transport and Communications, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Could the Minister outline which interests, companies or individuals hold the controlling interests in the Australian media in the following areas in view of the obvious confusion in the community on the issue: (a) television stations, (b) radio stations, (c) printed newspapers and periodicals, (d) news agencies and (e) public relations and lobbying companies, groups or individuals.
(2) What controls does the Federal Government have over the manifold media deals currently in vogue to the general confusion of the public at large.
(3) Does the Federal Government regard the safeguards it already has in place as adequate for the protection of the public against the establishment of media monopolies within Australia.
(4) What measures has the Federal Government in place to (a) monitor and (b) control the ownership of all parts of the Australian media in the future.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) (a) & (b) The attached tables show major shareholders in licensee companies of television stations and radio stations as at 9 October 1987. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT) publishes quarterly a list of shareholding interests in radio and television stations. This document is available to the public and provides a more comprehensive picture than is possible in the space of this response. Copies of the most recent edition of this publication are in the Parliament Library.
(c), (d) & (e) The Commonwealth has no specific constitutional power over the ownership of print media, news agencies or public relations and lobbying companies.

The merger provisions of the Trade Practices Act 1974 and the general thrust of the Foreign Takeovers Act 1975 affect patterns of control in the print media industry, but the Government does not directly regulate the industry.

With regard to newspapers, as part of its role in administering the cross-media provisions of the Broadcasting Act 1942, the ABT publishes, in the document mentioned above, details of principal shareholders in newspaper publishing companies.
The Department of Administrative Services maintains a register of lobbyists. There is no legislation involved and registration is not mandatory.

(2) Transfer of ownership of broadcasting licences and changes in ownership of shares in companies holding licences are subject to approval by the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal (ABT). The ABT must approve all such transactions, ensuring that the cross media, audience reach, concentration of ownership and foreign shareholding limits of the Broadcasting Act 1942 are observed.

(3) Yes. Recent amendments to the television ownership and control provisions of the Broadcasting Act 1942 (the Act) enable the ABT to apply cross media rules and an audience reach limit of 60% of the Australian population.

The cross media rules of the Act specifically prohibit persons from having a prescribed interest in a television licence if they have a prescribed interest in a commercial radio licence with a monopoly in the service area of that television licence, and/or if they have a prescribed interest in a newspaper associated with that area.
These amendments were intended to promote a separation between television and print media interest and to reduce the incidence of media monopolies in regional areas.

(4) The Government closely monitors the ownership of the Australian media. The Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, under the Broadcasting Act 1942 monitors and approves transactions involving broadcasting licences.

Newspapers and other print media outlets are not licensed although the Government has powers which may affect the print media industry under the provisions pertaining to monopolies and foreign ownership in the other legislation I have just mentioned.
