QUESTION.SPEAKER: Jones Sen G.N.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Attorney-General, upon notice, on 15 September 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: During the years 1985-86 (a) how many arrests were made in relation to individuals or companies for drug trafficking in each of the Australian States and Territories; (b) how many convictions were obtained in relation to arrests in each of the States and Territories; (c) in each State or Territory, what was the breakdown of convictions in numerical and percentage terms for (i) heroin dealing (ii) cocaine or cocaine product and (iii) marijuana or associated products; and (d) of those (i) arrested or (ii) convicted, what was the breakdown of the Nationalities of those involved during the two years under review.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Attorney-General has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The AFP is the primary law enforcement agency responsible for investigating major drug syndicates importing drugs into Australia. It has recently established a computer based system for the collection of statistics relating to the seizure and control of drugs by Federal agencies, which will in future give the AFP easy access to information of the type requested. Other drug offences committed in Australia are the responsibility of State police forces.

The Office of the Director of Public Prosecutions has recently introduced a Case Matter Management System for maintaining records of Commonwealth prosecutions, but this system is not yet sufficiently sophisticated to produce statistical information of the type requested in a complete and manageable form.

While the AFP keeps records relating to its own drug operations, it does not hold such information about State police activities. The information requested on drug trafficking pertaining to all States and Territories will not be available until the Australian Drug Data Base (Law Enforcement Component), currently being developed by the Australian Bureau of Criminal Intelligence, is established. In the interim, information of the type requested should be sought direct from the appropriate agency of each State or Territory.

In accordance with the 1985 Charter of Objectives and Priorities, drug trafficking and organised crime are given the highest priority by the AFP. Effective law enforcement in these areas is not measured by the number of arrests and the quantity of drugs seized, but by the significance of those arrests and seizures. A full breakdown of arrests for drug trafficking is available only for the financial year 1986/87.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce, upon notice, on 3 November, 1987:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce aware of claims in the local press about smuggling of gold from the Solomon Islands.
(2) What mechanisms does the Customs Service use to ensure gold entering Australia has not been smuggled out of foreign countries.
(3) How much gold has entered Australia from the Solomon Islands each year since 1980.
(4) What are the names of the companies that have imported this gold.
(5) Has the Customs Service been investigating these claims, and if so, what has it discovered.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, certain press articles have been brought to my attention.

(2) It is not the Australian Customs Service's (ACS) responsibility to check the means by which goods imported into Australia have been exported from their country of origin. This is the responsibility of the authorities of that country.

In order to assist Australian industry the ACS administers strict tariff regulations and conducts physical and documentary checks on all imported goods, to ensure that the correct amount of duty is paid.
The ACS also administers non-tariff restrictions or prohibitions on imports of goods such as dangerous weapons, narcotics, quarantinable goods, protected wildlife species and so on.

Gold imported into Australia is subject to the normal checks imposed upon other imported goods. Aside from quarantine controls over imported gold ore, no prohibitions or restrictions are applied specifically to gold, although as part of a general embargo on trade with South Africa, the importation of gold (along with a number of other goods) from that country is prohibited.

Concessional rates are granted for certain goods imported from Forum Island countries. Gold imported from the Solomon Islands falls within this category and is therefore admitted free of duty and at a sales tax rate of two per cent. As this gold is duty-free it poses no revenue risk in Australia.
(3) According to Australian Bureau of Statistics figures, the quantity and value of imports of gold into Australia from the Solomon Islands since 1980 are as follows (to rounded figures):
Total quantity (ore and bullion)-153,756 g total quantity (ore and bullion and other)-$2,059,000
(4) A total of nineteen companies or individuals have imported gold during the period just mentioned. The ACS is not authorised to release the names of these companies or individuals.
(5) The ACS has not been involved in any investigative operation into claims of gold smuggling from the Solomon Islands.
